Qualitative Management and Leadership

Self Management, Skills and Strengths

Unwritten laws of engineering

  • Demonstrate the ability to get things done
  • Develop a “let’s go see” attitude
  • Strive for conciseness and clarity
  • A valuable personal trait is the ability to get along with all kinds of people
  • but don’t be too affable
  • Your personal integrity is one of your valuable assets
  • Never underestimate the extent of your professional responsibility and personal liability
  • Engineers shall perform services only in the area of their competence

  • Stereotypes:

Manager

Individual Specialist

  • Extrovert, cordial, affable
  • Likes people
  • Dominant
  • Seeks to understand other views
  • Likes organising things
  • Interested in business, costs, use, practice
  • Able to do many things
  • Excels at communication
  • Fast, intuitive decision making
  • Introvert, reserved
  • Likes technical work
  • Unassuming
  • Seeks the facts of the matter
  • Likes doing things
  • Interested in science, maths, devices, function
  • Able to do intricate things
  • Excels at analysis
  • Methodical decision making

Depth vs breadth of skills and strengths

  • You can change yourself, like Steve Jobs

  • Topchik’s 5 stages of development for personal growth:
  • Attention getting (lacks knowledge, makes mistakes, misses deadlines)
  • Flying blind (keeps busy, works late, fearful of admitting weakness)
  • Steadiness (completes assignments, has little interest in developing)
  • On the rise (high work, quality work, trustworthy, wants to learn more)
  • Doing (completes work early, well respected, keen to advance)

  • BCS (British Computer Society)’s SFIAplus:

  • If you have a range of strengths, you will boost your effectiveness raking.
  • You should develop skills that complement what you do best already
  • Someone with no strengths: 34th percentile
  • Someone with 5 strengths: 91st percentile

  • You can fill out this table to identify your strengths and skills:

  • Strength: Are you good at this skill?
  • Passion: Are you interested in this skill or value it?
  • Needed: Does this skill fall in line with the company’s values?

Mono-tasking vs multi-tasking

  • Mono-tasking: doing one thing at a time
  • Multi-tasking: doing lots of things at a time

  • Psychologists have a notion of “flow”
  • It’s when you “get in the zone” and enter a full immersion in your work.
  • Mono-tasking is usually good, because you can get in the flow, which you can’t do with multi-tasking.

  • There is an agile method called Crystal Clear (not to be confused with Crystal Methods)
  • Basically, a bunch of developers are in a room with whiteboards and stuff, and distractions are kept away.
  • It upholds this notion of “flow”.

  • Your phone can break your flow.
  • Put it away while working (unless you’re working with your phone).
  • There’s lots of other things that can break your flow, like a meteorite or a text from your ex.

The Eisenhower principle

  • Who is Eisenhower?
  • He was a high ranking general.
  • He had a principle.
  • The principle said this:

Urgent

Not Urgent

Important

DO IT NOW!

SET TIME ASIDE FOR DOING IT!

Not Important

DELEGATE IT!

WHY ARE YOU DOING IT?!

  • Steve Wozniak said that perhaps the thing you need to run a business is to get rid of worthless things.

7 habits of highly effective people (Covey habits)

  1. be proactive
  • aim to shape events and your working environment
  1. start with the end in mind
  • identify what you want to achieve, avoid distractions
  1. put first things first
  • prioritise activities that help you achieve your aims
  1. sharpen the saw
  • take time to rest, renew, and update your skills
  1. think win-win
  • seek common ground and a solution that suits all parties
  1. first understand, then try to be understood
  • diagnose the problem before you prescribe the cure
  1. synergise
  • when the outcome is greater than the sum of the parts

  • I know this looks like something out of r/GetMotivated, but here’s how to be more proactive:

Decision Making

  • You have a business.
  • You have a whole bunch of products you’re selling.
  • Which products should you invest in?
  • If your only goal is to become rich, you will never reach the truth. The truth that you will never achieve that goal.

  • Boston Consulting Group Product Portfolio Matrix
  • That’s a long name. Let’s just call it the Boston Matrix.
  • For those of you who didn’t do Business Studies GCSE, the Boston Matrix is a four-way categorisation of a business’ products and franchises.
  • The four categories are as follows:
  • Star - High market growth, high market share. Invest!
  • Problem child / Problem / Question Mark - High market growth, low market share. It should be booming, but it’s not. Maybe take time to nurture it.
  • Dog / Pet - Low market growth, low market share. It’s a dead product in a dead market. Like Hirohiko Araki, we must kill the dogs.
  • Cash cow - Low market growth, high market share. It’s in a dead market, but it’s still making tonnes of money, so play it safe.
  • Bottom line:
  • Invest in your stars
  • Keep cash cows going
  • Select a few of your problem children to grow
  • Kill the dogs

  • Multiple Criteria Decision Making / Evaluation
  • I know that title just sounded really buzz-wordy, but bear with me.

  • OK, so we have Boston Matrix, but it doesn’t cover all cases in business.
  • We can also make decisions based on a number of criteria, e.g. if A and B, then do C

  • Most alternatives to Boston Matrix have a range of attributes or decision criteria that it uses.
  • the cheapest alternative is rarely the best in all respects
  • comfort, durability, sustainability, attractiveness, accessibility, …
  • these criteria all have to be factored into the decision making process
  • A well known and widely studied problem in operational research
  • the Wikipedia article lists a large number of different approaches
  • A Pareto optimal solution is desirable, where possible
  • meaning no adjustment is possible without making some criterion worse
  • Note that MCDM is not a roman number (Zionts, 1979)

  • Evidence Based Decision Making
  • You can also make decisions based on existing evidence.
  • Major business decisions are made by a board, committee, or panel
  • diverse groups are known to make better decisions
  • they weigh up the evidence more carefully
  • but note the theorems of Arrow and Gibbard-Satterthwaite (which is proven based on Arrow’s impossibility theorem)
  • so there has to be a way to break a voting tie, for example a casting vote
  • As the future is unknown, however, outcomes cannot be predicted
  • researching more data to improve your predictions could take forever
  • so you have to stop at some point and make the decision
  • A formal record is usually made of the decision and rationale
  • this helps to defend against later accusations or legal action

  • Decision Matrix
  • You can also put your choices into a matrix and give them attribute scores, and then the total can tell you which decision you should take.

  • If you value some attributes more than others, you can give weights, too.

  • A decision matrix turns multiple criteria into a single one.
  • Kind of like an F1 score.
  • However, accountants prefer to use monetary metrics, because a business that doesn’t make profit will not survive.
  • It’s like an animal that doesn’t eat, or a non-deterministic finite automata path that has no viable edges for its input symbol.

Investment Appraisal

  • Which projects should the company invest in?
  • This is called Capital Budget Decision, or Capital Investment Appraisal.
  • Objective: accept all those investments where the returns are in excess of the cost of capital (basically, invest in projects that make money)
  • Here’s another graph:

  • Six stages on capital budgeting:
  1. Identification Stage - look for opportunities to invest in
  2. Search Stage - look for alternative opportunities to invest in
  3. Information-Acquisition Stage - determine the costs and benefits of bringing each opportunity to fruition
  4. Selection Stage - pick projects for implementation
  5. Financing Stage - obtain project financing
  6. Implementation and Control Stage - start the projects and monitor performance
  • A very similar, more well-explained process, can be found here.

  • Time value: the value of money now compared to money in the future (the present value of money now is worth more than the same value in the future. If it doesn’t make sense, watch the video on this page)
  • Future value: Amount to which investment will grow after earning interest (by interest we mean time value as time goes on)
  • Present value: Value today of future cash flow

  • There’s four methods to evaluate investment proposals:
  • Methods that ignore the time value of money:
  • Payback method
  • In the payback method, we pick the project who has the quickest payback period.
  • We put in an initial investment and each year the project will “earn money back”.
  • We pick the project that breaks us even the quickest.
  • With non-uniform cash flows: add cash flows period by period until the initial investment is recovered; count the number of periods included for payback period
  • Example:
  • Our company wants to invest in either project A or B. Which should we invest in?

A

B

£

£

Initial investment cost

12,000

10,000

Year 1

7,000 (7,000)

6,500 (6,500)

Year 2

2,000 (9,000)

3,500 (10,000)

Year 3

3,000 (12,000)

2,000 (12,000)

Year 4

8,000 (20,000)

1,000 (13,000)

Year 5

6,000 (26,000)

1,000 (14,000)
  • For each year, project A and B yield money. The value in the brackets is the sum of the earnings so far.
  • As you can see, project B earns back our initial investment in year 2, sooner than A who does it in year 3.
  • Therefore, according to the payback method, we pick project B.
  • Advantages:
  • Widely used
  • Simple to understand
  • Appropriate where liquidity constraints exist and a fast payback is required
  • Appropriate for risky investments in uncertain markets
  • Often used as an initial screening device
  • Disadvantages:
  • Ignores time value of money
  • Ignores cash flows after the payback period
  • Accounting Rate of Return (ARR)

  • Accounting Rate of Return (ARR) is a metric that tells you the project’s profitability.
  • Required Rate of Return (RRR) is the minimum return an investor will accept for owning a company’s stock (go here for more info). It’s also called the discount rate, hurdle rate, cost of capital or opportunity cost of capital.
  • Accept the project only if its ARR is equal to or greater than the RRR.
  • If the projects are mutually exclusive, pick the one with the highest ARR.
  • It’s widely used because it evaluates manager performance, but it ignores the time value of money again.
  • [citation, citation]
  • Methods that take into account the time value of money:
  • Discounted Cash Flows
  • Discounted cash flow (DCF) is a valuation method used to estimate the value of an investment based on its future cash flows. DCF analysis attempts to figure out the value of a company today, based on projections of how much money it will generate in the future [citation].
  • It uses the time value of money (interest) and RRR.
  • Net Present Value (NPV)
  • NPV calculates the expected monetary gain or loss from a project by discounting all expected future cash inflows and outflows to the present point in time, using RRR.
  • Only projects with a zero or positive NPV are acceptable.
  • Three-step method:
  1. Draw all the relevant cash inflows and outflows
  2. Convert inflows and outflows into present value figures
  3. Sum the present value figures to determine NPV.

  • Independent projects with a positive NPV should be accepted.
  • With mutually exclusive projects, the project with the biggest NPV should be accepted.
  • Example:
  • A company wants to pick between project A and B. RRR (required rate of return) is 10%. Which should we invest in?
  • Step 1: Draw the cash flows

  • Step 3: Calculate the NPV of A and B by summing up the cash inflows and taking away the initial investment:
  • NPV of A: -£17,466
  • NPV of B: £71,150
  • B’s NPV is positive, so we should go with B.
  • Internal Rate of Return (IRR)
  • IRR represents the discount rate that equates the present value of initial outlay to the present value of the expected cash inflows.
  • If that made no sense, think of it like this: what value of RRR would make the NPV of the project equal to zero?
  • That value of RRR is the IRR.

Agile Project Management cf Traditional

  • If you’ve done SEG, you pretty much already know what this topic is going to go over.

  • Agile Manifesto:
  • We are uncovering better ways of developing software by doing it and helping others do it. Through this work we have come to value:
  • Individuals and interactions over processes and tools
    Working software     over comprehensive documentation
    Customer collaboration over contract negotiation
    Responding to change over following a plan
  • That is, while there is value in the items on the right, we value the items on the left more.

  • Waterfall:

  • Death March project:
  • Recurring schedule slips
  • Negative effect on customer relationship & trust
  • Integration problems
  • Testing period is reduced

  • Anecdote 1:
  • Project managers can say that they can meet a deadline, but meeting a deadline isn’t the same as making a good product.
  • If you think you need a few more weeks to do a better job, make sure you speak up and tell your macho management.

  • Brooks law: “adding human resources to a late software project makes it later”
  • If one woman can make a baby in 9 months, can nine women make one in 1 month?
  • No, stupid. What the hell.

  • The logic behind that statement is the same as the logic behind this statement:
  • If one developer can make the project in 6 months, can three developers make it in 2 months?
  • If we had 180 developers, can we do it in one day?
  • If we had 4,320 developers, can we do it in one hour?
  • If we had 259,200 developers, can we do it in one minute?

  • This is Brooks law.

  • All agile methods have this in common:
  • Activities are not in series, but can occur in parallel
  • There is regular revision of product backlog & plan
  • Renegotiate with the customer each iteration / sprint
  • Developers make and track their own estimates
  • Regular delivery ensures high morale and mutual trust
  • Sustainable development pace avoids burn out
  • Code is tested as it is written
  • better for support for testing and interface definition
  • eg automated regression test included in build system

  • In agile, you sometimes have to scrap things to change the direction of the code.
  • Isn’t that a waste of time and a waste of your code?
  • Well, it’s better to do that now during development than later on where it’ll take ages.
  • It’s better to waste a few weeks work than throwing away years of effort down the line.
  • Software is flexible.

  • “Working software in 90 days or your money back”
  • That’s pretty much agile back in 1988.
  • You fix a set period of time to work, and a set of tasks to complete, and then complete them
  • This was originally called a “timebox”.
  • Nowadays they’re called iterations, or sprints.

  • User story:
  • As a <persona or role>
  • Which user
  • I want to <some goal or interaction>
  • What the feature actually is
  • so that <added value or benefit>
  • What the user wants to get out of that feature

  • Traditional view:

  • Trade-off: take two, leave one
  • What’s missing here is the added value for the customer.

  • Anecdote 2:
  • In a software firm that uses waterfall, they brought in project managers and asked them:
  • “Over the last 12 months, how have you added value?”
  • They all said that they haven’t released any projects yet but they will next year.
  • If they had used agile, they would’ve had usable releases every other week.

  • How do you estimate tasks?
  • You can use planning poker!
  • Don’t know what that is? Look here.

  • Burndown charts should go down:

  • Meetings:
  • Formal meeting at the start of each sprint
  • Formal meeting at the end of each sprint
  • At regular intervals, have sprint / project retrospectives (where you reflect on everything you’re doing)
  • Daily scrum (stand up and state what you accomplished yesterday, what you’ll do today and what you need help on / what obstacles stand in your way)

  • In agile, you can also help each other out
  • Someone can move a task to “blocked” when they’re stuck, and someone else can pick it up

  • This contrasts Brook’s law.

  • Weaknesses of agile:
  • May be misunderstood
  • Developers need high skill levels
  • Coordination across large projects is complex
  • Customers may not want it

Project and Team Retrospectives

  • If the team does not work well together, the project will fail.
  • Teams need to share work equitably and make the best use of everyone.
  • You need a good balance of time on task and social bonding activities.

  • If you remember SEG, you’ll also remember Tuckman’s team formation stages:
  • Forming (I’ve only just met them)
  • Storming (They’re all dickheads)
  • Norming (I guess they’re not that bad)
  • Performing (They’re alright)
  • Adjourning / Mourning (The final goodbye *tears*)
  • There’s also Belbin’s standard roles:
  • Resource investigator
  • Team-worker
  • Coordinator
  • Plant
  • Monitor evaluator
  • Specialist
  • Shaper
  • Implementer
  • Finisher completer
  • Also remember Drexler & Sibbet:

  • ... and Lucke & Luckman:
  • clarity
  • challenge
  • commitment
  • feedback
  • task complexity

  • Keen & Digrius defines a bunch of business case development roles and steps:
  1. Scope – who expects what (project manager)
  2. Criteria – who cares about what (politician)
  3. Align criteria – connect the dots (salesperson)
  4. Calculate – show the money (detective)
  5. Analyse – find the winner (analyst)
  6. Prove – who says so? (investigative reporter)
  7. Story-tell – explain it (attorney)

  • There’s many different ways to communicate:
  • Group meetings
  • Email
  • Slack
  • Phone calls
  • Texts
  • However, when you start a new group, face to face meetings are best

  • Here’s a bunch of questions that can help quantify meeting effectiveness:
  • Was the purpose of the meeting made clear in advance?
  • Did participants have enough time to prepare for the meeting?
  • Were the right people invited and able to attend?
  • Did the meeting begin on time or no more than 3 minutes late?
  • Was there a clear agenda?
  • Were the meeting objectives discussed at the start of meeting?
  • Were participants prepared for the meeting?
  • Did attendees interact and participate effectively?
  • Were action items and responsibilities identified and correctly noted?
  • Did the meeting accomplish its intended purpose(s)?
  • Did the meeting end on time or no more than 3 minutes late?

  • Lencioni’s Five Dysfunctions of a Team (2002):
  • For each cause in the pyramid, an effect (or dysfunction) will occur in the team.

  • The Ideal Team Player (2016):
  • Team members can be categorised in this three-way Venn diagram.
  • For example, if you’re humble but not hungry (motivated) or smart, people will use you and you’ll be a “doormat”.
  • If you’re hungry and smart, you’ll be the “skillful politician”, meaning you’re good at what you do but you’re a real twat doing it.
  • To be an ideal team player, you want all three traits.
  • Kind of like the Triforce, except instead of having a wish granted, you’re the best in your team.

  • The Thinking Environment (Time to Think, Kline 2006):
  • Everything we do begins with thinking
  • Thinking is good → Decisions are good → Actions are good → Outcomes are good
  • So how do we think good?
  • Ten components need to be present:
  1. Attention
  2. Equality
  3. Ease
  4. Appreciation
  5. Encouragement
  6. Feelings
  7. Information
  8. Diversity
  9. Incisive questions
  10. Place
  • We think the least well in the presence of:
  1. Ridicule
  2. Competition
  3. Intimidation
  4. Perfectionism
  5. Cynicism
  6. Criticism
  7. Powerlessness
  8. Self-doubt
  9. Formality
  10. Physical discomfort
  11. Seduction
  12. Low expectations
  13. Addiction
  14. Stereotyping
  15. Pity

  • How do we set up meetings with a good thinking environment?
  1. Begin with a positive reality (without being gushy)
  2. Give everyone a turn
  3. Let them finish
  4. Identify assumptions and ask incisive questions
  5. Divide into thinking pairs
  6. Go round again
  7. Give permission to tell the truth
  8. Allow people’s feelings
  9. End with a positive turn

  • Team Effectiveness Questionnaire:
  • The London Leadership Academy and NHS developed a questionnaire
  • You can use it to assess the effectiveness of your team
  • There are eight dimensions:
  1. Purpose and goals
  2. Roles
  3. Team processes
  4. Team relationships
  5. Inter-group relations
  6. Problem solving
  7. Passion and commitment
  8. Skills and learning

Management Accounting and Finances

  • The fundamental accounting equation:
  • Assets = Liabilities + Equity
  • Assets: the value of stuff you own
  • Liabilities: debts you haven’t paid yet
  • Equity: debts you’ve already paid
  • If something happens to one side, it also happens to the other side.
  • Changes to each side is called debits and credits.
  • These changes are logged by double entry bookkeeping.

  • For example, if you get a car worth £20,000, and you’ve already paid £15,000 towards it but still need to pay that £5,000 extra, then:
  • Your assets will be £20,000
  • Your equity will be £15,000
  • Your liabilities will be £5,000
  • £20,000 = £15,000 + £5,000, so we’re balanced!
  • If you then loan £300 from someone, then:
  • Your assets will go up by £300 and will be a debit
  • Your liabilities will go up by £300 and will be a credit

  • What? You’re still confused?
  • Don’t worry; I was too. Have a read of this, this and this.
  • Now, I’ll do what the slides don’t (but should) do: explain.
  • Each account can either have a "debit" or "credit", or "left balance" and "right balance", respectively.
  • Assets have debit (left balance) and liabilities and equity have credit (right balance).
  • An account can be "debited" or "credited", meaning money is being removed/added from that account.
  • The value of the account either increases or decreases depending on the account type. For example:
  • If a debit was recorded in a debit account, the debit account's value would increase
  • If a credit was recorded in a debit account, the debit account's value would decrease
  • If a debit was recorded in a credit account, the credit account's value would decrease
  • If a credit was recorded in a credit account, the credit account's value would increase
  • The rule is: if the transaction is the same as the account type, it's an increase. If not, it's a decrease.

  • Because the assets account has debit (left balance), on the image above it shows debits increasing and credits decreasing underneath assets because if assets was debited the value would increase and if it was credited the value would decrease. The same goes for liabilities and equity, but it's the other way around because they're credit (right balance) accounts.

  • So credit and debit doesn't necessarily mean add / subtract money; it totally depends on what kind of account is being credited / debited.

  • In double entry accounting, every debit that is recorded must be matched with a credit.
  • For example, if assets is credited (decreases), then some right balance account (either liabilities or equity) must be debited (also decreases)
  • If liabilities or equity is credited (increases), then some left balance account (assets) must be debited (also increases).
  • That way, the sum remains balanced.

  • There are two main branches of accounting:
  • Financial accounting
  • annual reports of the company’s situation
  • these are published to shareholders and the public
  • must be audited to confirm their correctness
  • used by investors to decide whether to buy, hold or sell shares
  • basically, more money oriented
  • Management accounting
  • provides additional and more up to date information
  • typically include data which is company confidential
  • used to monitor, measure and manage performance
  • and support management decision making
  • basically, more oriented towards making decisions
  • There’s also more, like tax accounting, forensic accounting, accounting information systems etc.

  • Financial Reports:
  • Balance sheet shows assets, liability and equity at a defined moment
  • Profit and loss report shows income and expenses
  • Equity statement shows retained earnings
  • Cash flow statement reports on operating costs, investing & finances
  • These last three relate to a stated period of time, eg the reporting year
  • Typically also includes a financial review or management discussion
  • The report assumes that the company is a “going concern”
  • hence can pay its debts as they fall due – but if not this should be flagged up
  • in case of insolvency, shareholders have lower priority than loan providers
  • assets usually have lower value if they have to be liquidated (sold off) in a hurry (like the Steam Controllers)

  • International Financial Reporting Standard (IFRS):
  • Standards are put in place so companies don’t make crappy financial reports (or misleading ones).
  • Fundamental characteristics include:
  • Relevance (needs to be recent and refer to relevant stuff)
  • Faithful representation (no lying)
  • Enhancing characteristics include:
  • Comparability
  • Verifiability
  • Timeliness
  • Understandability
  • IFRS standards are required or permitted in over 140 jurisdictions

  • This is the financial report for the uni:

  • You can also do graphs, which are easier to read but may be less precise or misleading.

  • Financial Analysis:
  • How can you tell if a company is worth investing in?
  • Access online financial analysis from Yahoo or MSN
  • You can also look at a company’s key metrics:
  • Market Capitalisation (market cap): share price × number of shares
  • Earnings Per Share (EPS): profit ÷ number of shares
  • Price Earnings (PE) Ratio: profit ÷ market cap
  • Beta: a measure of volatility cf the rest of the market
  • Also check how these change over time, and how they compare to those of competitors

  • Management Accounting: analysing information to advise business strategy and drive sustainable business success (CIMA)
  • Focus more on the present and future using predictive models instead of historic cases
  • Financial data is available on demand these days
  • This includes:
  • Analysis and control of costs
  • Profitability analysis and optimisation
  • Plus quantitative risk management
  • Sources of financing
  • Insurance
  • To do this, reporting at a finer grain is needed e.g. individual products, divisions

  • Planning and Control:
  • In a company, you have objectives.
  • To reach those objectives, you need a strategic decision of long-term plans.
  • To execute those plans, you need operation decisions upon short-term plans (budgets).
  • These all need to be monitored and controlled.

  • Budgeting:
  • Involves different levels in an organisation
  • Top-down approach:
  • Managers tell lower levels what needs to be done with a set amount of resources
  • “We need those div tags vertically aligned!”
  • Bottom-up approach:
  • Lower levels tell managers what they can achieve and what resources they need
  • “Sir, it’s only 2008, flexboxes haven’t been invented yet”
  • Participatory approach:
  • The budget is negotiated between different levels
  • Could lead to compromises

  • Avoidable costs: costs that can be eliminated or reduced by picking one alternative over another
  • Unavoidable costs (or sunk costs): a cost that has already been incurred and cannot be avoided, no matter what a manager decides to do

  • Cost centres: an identifiable part of an organisation
  • Costs can be assigned and aggregated between cost centres.
  • In a manufacturing setting, a cost centre could be:
  • a single factory
  • a particular department or activity (e.g. assembly, foundry, inspection)
  • a machine or group of machines
  • an individual or group of individuals
  • Cost centres can usually be identified where
  • many costs can be allocated to specific parts of the organisation
  • someone has responsibility for that part of the organisation

  • Why measure cost:
  • Why do we do it? For fun?
  • To help in determining the selling price
  • To help in production planning
  • To maintain management control
  • To support management decision making
  • Costs can be aggregated by
  • element (material, labour, …): useful for cost control
  • nature (direct, indirect): useful for cost accounting
  • function (production, non-production): useful for financial accounting
  • behaviour (fixed, variable, …): useful for budgeting and decision making

  • Classification of Costs:
  • Fixed: It stays the same no matter the activity level

  • Variable: Cost is directly proportional to activity

  • Costs can also be semi-variable

  • ... or semi-fixed (stepped cost)

  •  - profit
  •  - sales price
  •  - quantity sold
  •  - fixed costs
  •  - variable costs per unit sold

  • You can fill out these scorecards to document how people see your company:

  • Here’s a few examples of it filled in:

  • The balanced scorecard keeps companies looking, and moving forward instead of backward

  • Ethics and Externalities:
  • The balanced scorecard doesn’t include stuff like social, environmental and ethical aspects.
  • Stuff like:
  • Laying off employees will affect their families
  • Companies are not liable for environmental damage
  • How can we trust companies?
  • Sometimes company executives band together to protect themselves
  • However they can be found out if they do bad stuff

  • International Transfer Tax:
  • Normally, companies pay tax based on their profits.
  • However, big companies transfer profits to different countries.
  • That means they pay less tax.
  • That’s good for them, but not good for the country, and therefore not good for us!
  • Stuff like the IFRS tries to resolve issues like these.

Activity Based Costing; Procurement

Traditional vs Activity

  • The Profit Model from before is simple.
  • A bit too simple...
  • Most companies don’t have just one product; they typically have many.
  • Stuff like sharing overheads and investment decisions get more complicated.
  • Overheads need to be shared across multiple products / services, called overhead allocation, absorption or conversion.

  • First off, how do we value the products we make?
  • Well, we should start off with what costs were spent to make them.
  • There are two kinds of costs:
  • Direct costs: costs that can be directly mapped to a product or service
  • If you make a wooden table, you know exactly how much wood is needed to make that table.
  • If it costs you £1 per kg of wood, the cost of the wood would be a direct cost
  • This can apply to direct labour too, if the labourer charges you a fixed cost per table.
  • Indirect costs (overheads): costs that can’t be directly mapped, usually because it goes towards lots of other products / services
  • Let’s just say you had an electric saw that cost you £5 to run for 1 hour.
  • You have no idea how much saw time you need for each product.
  • You make 2 chairs and 1 table, and you used up 4 hours of the saw, resulting in £20.
  • What product does the £20 go to?
  • That £20 is an indirect cost!
  • Other examples include maintenance, storage and handling, wasted materials, testing and faulty items.
  • General business overheads include:
  • accounting fees
  • advertising
  • insurance
  • interest
  • legal fees
  • labor burden
  • rent
  • repairs
  • supplies
  • taxes
  • telephone bills
  • travel expenditures
  • utilities
  • There’s two ways to trace these costs to products:
  • Cost tracing: used for direct costs. Directly maps costs to the product being produced
  • Cost allocation: used for indirect costs (overheads). Uses estimates and models to apply costs to products
  • Here’s a picture to illustrate this:

  • Financial statements include closing inventory (the stock a company has at the end of an accounting period) as current assets using the minimum cost of production and net realisable value (estimated selling price of stock)
  • Notice how we use one of two systems for trying our best to pair indirect costs to objects: traditional (TCS) and activity (ABC).
  • If this doesn’t make a lot of sense, watch Deborah’s video. She’s good.

  • Traditional Cost System:
  • This one’s the easy one.
  • You simply share the overheads proportionally based on direct labour hours, or a cost driver (a single factor that determines cost).
  • If uptime for server A costs you £1 / hour and server B costs you £2 / hour, and the total overheads are £9, then we can use uptime as a cost driver and £3 goes to server A and £6 goes to server B.
  • This is quick, cheap and easy to understand but not all overheads are the same.
  • Sure, running server A may cost £1 / hour, but the rent for the data centre makes it way more expensive than server B, but since we’re using uptime as a cost driver, we’re allocating more overheads to B than A, even though A costs more.
  • Sometimes we need a more accurate costing system.

  • Traditional Cost System (two stage allocation rate):
  • You can do a variation, called the two stage allocation rate.
  • You still only have one cost driver, but you split up overhead costs into different production areas / departments / cost centres
  • These can include stores, cutting, assembly, finishing etc.
  • For example:
  • You make a wooden chair. The wood cost £20.
  • However, the wood didn’t just come from one place.
  • £5 of the wood came from Morning Wood Ltd.
  • £5 of the wood came from Edward Woodward and Son
  • £10 of the wood came from Barking Mad Co.
  • We’re splitting up the overhead costs to different cost centres.
  • We’re still applying one cost driver, but the overhead cost is now more fine-grained.

  • Activity Based Costing (ABC):
  • ABC is more fine-grained than TCS.
  • Instead of one cost driver, we have multiple.
  • We identify cost drivers by mapping activities to cost drivers.
  • We just calculate the proportions for each cost driver, and then add them up into a total.
  • For example:
  • Total wood costs: £9
  • Total cutting costs: £15

  • Management Decisions and Cost Accounting:
  • What we’re doing right now is cost accounting.
  • Cost accounting lets us make management decisions, like:
  • determine the minimum price of a product or service
  • support cost engineering
  • make correct decisions about outsourcing
  • construction of portfolios of products or services
  • Activity Based Costing is a part of a whole Activity Based Management Model.
  • As the name suggests, it’s all about which activities and processes to focus on more.

  • Cost engineering: ensuring manufacturing efficiency and manages costs
  • Cost engineers:
  • cut the number and variety of components required
  • reduce wastage of raw materials / percentage of faulty items produced
  • simplify production processes to reduce labour time
  • share common components between different products or services
  • buy in sub-assemblies rather than making everything “in-house”
  • reduce storage and handling overheads by “just-in-time” stock delivery
  • Cost engineering can be applied at any time, not just at the start (like annually or something)

  • Manufacturing Learning Curve:
  • Manufacturing improves with experience.
  • This phenomenon was first encountered in World War 2, when scientists (Curtiss-Wright) noticed that the cost for a given aircraft model declined with increased production in accordance with a fairly predictable formula (citation).
  • Basically, the more something is produced, the cheaper it gets.
  • However, after a certain point it diminishes and eventually the change in cost becomes negligible.

  • The formula goes like this:

  • The variables mean this (credit goes to Kieran Allinson):
  • Cn = Cumulative average cost of n units
  • C1 = Cost for one unit
  • n   = Number of units produced
  • a   = Learning exponent
  • More or less, the more you produce, the more you learn how to produce the item so the cheaper you’re able to produce it. So producing more will make the average cost per unit less with time.
  • The efficiency gain is typically in the range 10% - 25% for each doubling

Procurement and Outsourcing

  • The Value Chain:
  • There is a sequence of activities that, together, create a product or service:
  • Inward Logistics: receiving, storing, and distributing inputs
  • Operations: transforming inputs into a finished item, e.g. manufacturing
  • Market and Sales: advertising and sales + sales administration
  • Distribution: delivering finished items to customers
  • Follow-up Services: maintaining value of delivered item
  • There’s a bunch of support activities too, such as infrastructure, H/R, development and procurement

  • How can we add value in this chain?
  • We outsource to companies who do it better!
  • We only outsource to companies who are good, so outsourcing decisions are important

  • Core competency: a harmonized combination of multiple resources and skills that distinguish a firm in the marketplace
  • Drucker claims businesses have only two functions: marketing and innovation
  • You don’t see Sony going into the mines to mine up some silicon for their next phone, do you?
  • No! They outsource.

  • Here’s where companies mainly outsource to:

  • Ethical Procurement and Outsourcing:
  • What is Sony morally responsible for?
  • Human rights?
  • Labour conditions?
  • Health and safety?
  • The environment?
  • Should Sony base their decisions on ethics or profit?
  • What about companies outside of Sony? Should they meddle with:
  • Parts suppliers?
  • Subcontractors?
  • Contract manufacturers?
  • Is it acceptable that some Sony televisions are completely manufactured by Flextronics but are branded as Sony products?
  • Personally, I don’t mind. But what do I know? I just write the notes.

Change Management

  • In 1905 and between 1907 and 1915, Albert Einstein published his theory of special and general relativity, changing the way everybody thought about the universe.
  • In the 1950’s, Grace Hopper pushed for a new programming language that would use entirely English words. Her ideas weren’t accepted for years, but she eventually created A-0 and an operational link-loader, laying the foundation for COBOL and changing the way people thought about programming languages.
  • In 1997, Steve Jobs returned to Apple Computer and changed it around, turning it into a consumer electronics company.
  • From 2000 to 2003, Hirohiko Araki changed Annasui’s gender from female to male on request from his publishers.
  • In late 2019, I changed the Notes Network document and made everything look a lot prettier.
  • Change is all around us, and it happens to everything.
  • Change can be good or bad, but one thing remains: it is a fundamental force of nature.

“Change IS nature, Dad. The part that we can influence. And it starts when we decide.”

  • Remy, Ratatouille

  • Alright, what about it? Why did I just tell you a Ratatouille quote?
  • Well, businesses change too, you know.
  • More often than you may think.
  • Change is necessary for a business to grow.
  • However, you need to be careful: some changes are bad, and some are good.
  • That’s why you need “change management” to make sure you make the right changes.

  • A company’s lifecycle usually goes like this:

  • They’re in a slump, then they boom, but if nothing changes, they die.
  • A company can change or “adapt” to survive and continue living, typically by pursuing a different business opportunity.
  • Google and Facebook decided to make money through advertising, but they didn’t start off like that; that was a “change”.
  • These “changes” are called strategic inflection points.
  • Like a living organism, they have to continue to shed their skin. Methods, focus and values have to change (for the better).
  • When companies start to decline, they may need to:
  • close or sell off failing divisions
  • sell it off to / merge with another company

  • Another example is ARM.
  • Basically, they used to make computers (like the BBC micro) but their processor supplier changed to some crappy plastic instead of the usual ceramic.
  • In response, Acorn (ARM before they became ARM) made their own called Acorn/Advanced RISC Machine (ARM) and became ARM.
  • Then they became a joint venture of Acorn, Apple and VLSI Technology.

  • Technologic strategic inflection points:
  • Grove stopped making DRAM chips and made micro-processors
  • Nokia started divesting in tires and TVs and globalised the company towards telecommunications technology.
  • Jobs returning to Apple

  • Here is how Jobs modelled his product line:

  • Some changes can be controversial, though.
  • There can be negative consequences:
  • financially
  • socially
  • in public relations
  • Then again, if the company fails, everyone loses their job, so sometimes compromises have to be made.

  • Alright, so let’s model a simple business.
  • Here’s our business model for ECS Incorporated:

  • Looking good!

  • What if we were to get rid of monads?
  • Aside from destroying the functional programming paradigm, we wouldn’t get that “loss” from the monads, right? We’d be saving money, right?
  • Let’s calculate it by getting rid of the monads (sorry, Julian)

  • First, we assume that £250 of the fixed costs are avoidable, and £108 of the fixed costs are unavoidable. All of the variable costs are avoidable.
  • So we can earn back £250 by ditching monads, but because £108 are fixed, we need to fork that out whether or not we still have monads.

  • What?! Our profit went down?!
  • This means the monads shouldn’t be discontinued.
  • The reason why our profits didn’t go up is because we still have unavoidable costs, even after we discontinue monads.

  • There’s something wrong with this analysis, though.
  • It only focuses on the present.
  • But our decision is about the future!
  • Therefore we also need to consider:
  • What are the trends?
  • Is this year a blip?
  • Will monads recover or do badly next year?
  • What are the unavoidable fixed costs?
  • Can we change the contract to cover them, or can we cancel them?

  • Projectification:
  • Inflection points are more likely to happen in technology businesses
  • New technology creates new businesses and destroys old ones
  • In projectification, operations are categorised into “projects”.
  • Tech can be product development projects.
  • Marketing campaigns can be projects.
  • This has affected management and organisational structures.

  • Everything is a project. So what?
  • Change can also be a project.
  • Some people claim it’s a completely distinct area of management.
  • Some change projects fail.
  • If they’re done right, they might not.
  • You need to consider:
  • people might feel threatened by change
  • people might work to undermine change passively / aggressively
  • Successful change projects require:
  • trust
  • persuasive vision
  • executive sponsorship / ownership

  • Lewin wrote about a three step organisational change process:
  1. Un-freezing to overcome inertia and dismantle the existing mind set
  2. Making the change
  3. Re-freezing to restore order and evaluate benefits
  • Winston Churchill said this:
  • “However beautiful the strategy, you should occasionally look at the results”
  • “A pessimist sees the difficulty in every opportunity; an optimist sees the opportunity in every difficulty”
  • Did he really say that? Who knows.
  • Kübler-Ross likened business change to the grieving process:
  • denial, anger, bargaining, depression and acceptance

Management and Leadership

Approaches to management

  • Drucker’s List of Management Functions
  • Set the team’s / organisations’ objectives
  • Provide and organise the resources to achieve the objectives
  • Motivate staff to achieve the objectives
  • Monitor staff performance against the objectives
  • Improve performance by continually developing yourself and your staff

  • Because the purpose of business is to create and keep a customer, the business enterprise has two - and only two - basic functions: marketing and innovation.

  • Theory X, Y and Z by McGregor and Maslow
  • People who are category X:
  • are driven by monetary concerns
  • will avoid work where possible
  • lack ambition & dislike responsibility
  • are indifferent to organisational needs
  • lack creativity and resist change
  • People who are category Y:
  • are driven by job satisfaction
  • actively seek work
  • show ambition and seek responsibility
  • are committed to organisational objectives
  • are creative and welcome change
  • People who are category Z:
  • recognise the need for self-fulfilment or transcendence

  • Hawthorne Experiments
  • Famous 1920s experiments involving manual workers at GEs Hawthorne plant, which found no correlation between productivity and working conditions
  • Belonging to a group creates status and belonging
  • Productivity was increased by treating workers with respect
  • rather than changing working conditions
  • Of course, if working conditions are very poor, productivity falls

  • Hawthorne effect: experiments with human test subjects are more likely to be successful because the subjects know it’s an experiment

  • Management by Walking About
  • Also known as walking the corridors, go see, or (in Japan)
  • gemba gembutsu genjitsu (real place, real work, real facts)
  • better than a weekly status report from all staff
  • Builds trust and understanding
  • Lets you listen to staff, their ideas and problems
  • you get to know them and their motivations better
  • you can answer their questions directly
  • You can look for examples of good practice to share
  • you can look for bad practices and deal with them
  • You can observe inter-staff working relations

  • Sources of power

Approaches to leadership

  • Leadership Grid (Blake and Mouton)

  • As a manager, you need a good balance of administrator and leadership.
  • You need to be a good administrator because, as a manager, you need to know what you’re talking about.
  • You need to have good leadership in times of crisis and significant change.
  • One approach is called “masterful inactivity”:
  • Argue that change is cyclical and the current crisis is only temporary
  • Basically, “just wait and hope it solves itself”.
  • Sometimes this works, and it’s used in politics (as I’m sure you know)
  • However, in modern business, “only the paranoid survive” and there are always changes to be made.
  • There are other approaches, or types of leadership.

  • Types of leadership:
  • Transactional
  • Reward good effort and performance with prizes, bonuses and promotions
  • Use coercions to correct poor performance or compliance with reduced career progression, less interesting work and dismissal
  • Basically, reward the good, punish the bad
  • The leader should be able to deliver their promises and threats, otherwise they’ll lose credibility and authority (basically, they’ll be a crap manager)
  • Transformational
  • Proactively change culture to implement new business practices
  • Use the four ‘I’s:
  • Ideals: motivate employees by acting as an ideal role model
  • Inspiration: use charm to inspire extraordinary effort
  • Individual consideration to make everyone feel special
  • Intellectual stimulation promotes creative and innovative solutions
  • Transformational boosts satisfaction with the leader...
  • ... but transactional boosts performance more.
  • Charismatic
  • Uses good communication skills to reach employees at an emotional level
  • Basically, your leader is Jesus
  • Charismatic has a greater emphasis on a “vision” compared to transformational which is just motivating people
  • Can be used for politics and religion, not just business
  • Risks:
  • Tunnel vision
  • Excessive dependence among staff
  • Situational
  • The leader changes their style of leadership depending on the employees they are managing.
  • Employee type is split into two properties, which can be high or low:
  • Commitment - how motivated you are
  • Competence - how good you are at the job
  • Because there are two properties with two possible values, an employee can belong to one of  different categories, described in the table below:

Motivation and Reward

  • Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs:
  • If you didn’t do Media Studies GCSE, Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs is, well, a hierarchy of needs.
  • The bottom layer is what’s most important, and each layer is more important than the layer above it.
  • It forms the basis for the McGregor’s theories.
  • The bottom third relates to X, the middle third relates to Y and the top third relates to Z.

  • Management by Objectives / Results:
  • Objectives are set in appraisal meetings
  • The employee and manager sets these together
  • At the end of the year, performance is reviewed and new objectives are set
  • It’s basically a year-long Scrum sprint
  • Bonuses and promotions depend on achieving / exceeding objectives
  • You’re not told what to do, you decide what you want to achieve

  • Popularised by Drucker’s Practice of Management (1954)
  • Now lots of companies, like HP, use this

  • There is a contrast in factory workers: can be paid as piece workers or fixed amount per item produced

  • Performance Appraisal Meetings:
  • Appraisal meetings are constructive opportunities to reflect
  • requires suitable time, space, duration and summary of previous meeting with agreed objectives
  • Objectives must be consistent with role / job description
  • If goals are not met, employee will explain and maybe targets will be adjusted
  • There may be negative perceptions:
  • tick box filling, subjective evaluations, overt criticisms / threats, defensiveness
  • Maybe it’s better to just have frequent discussions rather than formal high-tension performance appraisal meetings

  • 360 Degree feedback:
  • To address subjective ratings, we can use multiple raters from all the areas the employee interacts with e.g. people who work for them, people they work for etc.
  • This could be dubious because anonymous reviewers may harbour grudges
  • To be honest, 360 degree feedback is basically a buzzword for asking other people what they think of you.

  • Scott Adam’s Company Model:
  • Companies with effective employees and good products do well
  • Minimise activities that are one level removed from people and products
  • Do not tinker with the process of performance appraisal meetings and stuff; be consistent with management
  • Have an Out At 5 (OA5) manager who:
  • stays out of the way
  • eliminates the assholes (yes, the slides say that)
  • make sure the employees learn something every day
  • create an environment that supports curiosity and learning
  • teach employees how to be efficient
  • The problem is, how can you tell if a manager satisfies all those criteria? How do you define and examine “support for curiosity and learning”?

  • Adam’s Equity Theory:
  • If rewards are not fair, staff lose motivation
  • Staff will eventually compare their input / reward ratios
  • This also applies to you lot, too: “There’s so much law stuff to learn... is it worth getting a high mark for this? Maybe I’ll just settle for a pass or something”

  • Reward → Inequitable reward: Employee feels they’re doing more work than they’re rewarded, so they get mad
  • Reward → Equitable reward: Employee feels they’re getting the right amount of reward for their work, so they work at the same rate
  • Reward → More than equitable reward: Employee feels they’re getting more reward than what they’re working for, so they’ll either continue at the same rate or feel guilty and work harder

  • Does Performance Related Pay Work?
  • Green & Heywood (2008) reports that performance related pay increase productivity, effort and earnings but also increases variability, lowering morale of less productive workers
  • Job satisfaction is highest where there’s no performance pay or bonuses. Job security also declines under such schemes. It mainly depends on the type of worker and the company.
  • High performance workplaces create belonging, esteem & commitment (also piece rates increase efforts more than time rats and performance related pay)
  • Job satisfaction declines with education level and company size (public sector workers tend to be more satisfied)

  • Pay and Satisfaction are Only Loosely Related
  • The better your pay, the less satisfied you are with your work
  • There is a stronger link between pay level vs pay satisfaction rather than pay level vs job satisfaction

  • Diener and Tay (2015) studied well-being and found higher average income countries means better well-being, social support, freedom, water quality. Income equality also matters

  • Team Based Rewards:
  • In many cases, performance depends on a team and not the individual
  • Are team based rewards better than individual?
  • DeMatteo (1998) reviewed this and found that it varied, but there are increases between 28% to 76%
  • It’s unclear under what conditions team rewards become effective
  • Employees and employers are concerned about “free riding” (basically, people in the team carrying other people)
  • Game Theory simulation suggests that group based systems outperform individual or mixed systems, and cooperative behaviour is better

  • The approaches to team-based rewards are:

  • Here’s what DeMatteo found about effectiveness of team based rewards:

  • Profit Sharing and Employee Share Scheme:
  • Employees may have the right to buy shares
  • Such schemes give workers a long term stake and motivates them to work in the company’s best interests
  • Tax breaks for the employer may encourage such schemes
  • A profit sharing scheme rewards employees for one year’s results, which is safer because the bonus can be varied up and down with profits
  • More incentives:
  • Overtime payments
  • Company cars or subsidized travel
  • Sabbatical leave (unpaid additional holidays)
  • Free coffee
  • Christmas parties
  • Continuing Professional Development (CPD), e.g. Conferences
  • T-shirts
  • Long service awards

Production and Quality Management

  • Have you ever bought something and then realised it was crap?
  • How about a piece of software you downloaded before you realised it’s awful?
  • The people who made those didn’t have good quality control.
  • That’s what we’re going over today!

  • The slides go over how to measure quality first before defining what quality actually is.
  • I’ll go over what quality actually is, which is probably the most interesting part of this chapter (which says a lot about this section).
  • Feigenbaum said: “Quality is a customer determination which is based on the customer’s actual experience with the product or service, measured against his or her requirements, stated or unstated, conscious or merely sensed, technically operational or entirely subjective, always representing a moving target in a competitive market”
  • What? You didn’t fully read that paragraph? I don’t blame you.
  • Basically, whether you can clearly point out what’s wrong with it or if they just say “idk, there’s just something about it I just like”, that all factors into the quality of a product. It is subjective to the customer. If the customer doesn’t like it, the quality suffers.
  • To sum it up in a sentence, it’s what the customer wants and what the company provides.
  • And now, I’m going to show you the tyre-on-a-tree quality assurance meme that is shown at least once on every soft-skill module slides. Are you ready?

  • Statistical quality control relies on repeatable processes and detailed measurements.
  • First, you need to define an:
  • acceptable failure rate
  • acceptable failure modes
  • Then, you measure and test to ensure failure rate is lower and that failure modes do not occur.
  • Six Sigma is a set of techniques and tools that strives to reduce the number of defects to 1 in a million.

  • Service industries may be happy with < 10-3 dissatisfied customers (image having 0.001 customers)
  • banking services, for example, may be relatively “sticky” (they don’t care as much)
  • Which rates the top 10 UK banks from 70 – 84% customer satisfaction

  • Techniques such as six sigma uses probability distributions, like these:

  • When doing quality management, your measurements need to be reliable and precise.
  • Drucker: “If you can’t measure it, you can’t manage it. Or not. I just write the notes.”
  • Ok, he didn’t say that last part, but the point is that you need to have some way of measuring something to manage it, and that includes quality.

  • Failures are often time dependent.
  • This is called the bathtub curve.

  • Continuous Improvement is a philosophy of continuously improving working practices, according to Kaizen (seems Kaizen isn’t great at definitions if they use the word they’re defining in their definition...)
  • Shewart goes on to say that it includes the stages:
  • Plan
  • Do
  • Check / Study
  • Act / Adjust (PDCA / PDSA)
  • Deming thought this was pretty cool and took it to Japan in the 1950’s.
  • Deming taught:
  • better design of products to improve service
  • higher level of uniform product quality
  • improvement of product testing in the workplace and in research centres
  • greater sales through global markets
  • Deming also emphasised “profound knowledge” through appreciating a system, understanding variation, psychology and epistemology

“You cannot improve what you do not understand”

  • Quality Control: maintain standards by testing all or a sample of items
  • (checking for defects)
  • Quality Assurance: maintain standards by providing confidence that errors will be prevented by proper processes
  • (establishing processes that will prevent defects)
  • Total Quality Management: everyone is responsible for maintaining standards
  • (making everyone responsible for preventing defects)

  • Any system has a natural rate (Kanban, devops, takt time)

Scientific & Quantitative Management

Company lifecycle

  • Lifecycle: a predictable sequence of stages of growth and change
  • Stages:
  1. Birth
  2. Growth
  3. Decline
  4. Death
  • You cannot predict when an organisation reaches “maturity”, because it can always grow again

  • How to extend company lifespan:
  • Growth - quicken / manage growth
  • Decline - avoid / reverse decline
  • Death - prolong life, or know when to bury

Birth

  • Birth of company:
  • Entrepreneurship - create a new company
  • Intrapreneurship - apply an idea to an existing company

  • Business ideas come from:
  • Finding the idea
  • Creating a business from the idea

  • Joys and sorrows at birth:
  • Enthusiasm
  • Innovative
  • Small and flexible
  • intimacy
  • all 4 one, one for all

  • uncertainty
  • vulnerable
  • credibility issues
  • inexperienced
  • limited capital

Growth

  • Gibrat’s Law: growth of a firm is a random process; basically, no-one knows
  • Patterns of growth are also random, like:
  • Rapid
  • Incremental
  • Episodic
  • Plateau

  • Penrose’s theory: growth is a result of managerial competence and “learning by doing”; a company doesn’t plan to grow
  • This also works the other way: if a company focuses too much on growth, inefficiency sets in and growth rate reduces

  • Growth isn’t always good, but it’s not inevitable

  • Marris’ Theory of ‘Managerial’ Capitalism: the optimal point of growth is naturally determined by:
  • managers trying to maximise growth rate
  • shareholders trying to maximise share prices
  • If managers increase the growth rate too much, the shareholders won’t get as much dividends.
  • If the shareholders increase the share prices too much, there won’t be enough money going back into the company.
  • So an optimised point of growth rate and share prices is found for a balanced growth.

Market Analysis and Price Setting

Market analysis

  • When you have a product, you need to analyse the market that product lies in.
  • How are you going to sell computer parts if you know nothing about the technical market?
  • There are 4 stages to market analysis:
  1. Industry overview
  • This is a general overview of the industry.
  • There are two main things to look out for:

Market Share

Total Volume

  1. Target market
  • Who will buy and/or use your product?
  • Perhaps take a leaf out of Interaction Design and make personas and stuff?
  1. Competition
  • Who are making similar products to you?
  • Who are you competing against?
  • For example, if you’re making beans, one of your competition would be Heinz.
  • If you’re making ketchup, one of your competition would be, uh, also Heinz.
  • You should also do research on how they’re doing, their sales, their values etc.
  1. Pricing and forecast
  • How should you price your product and how well will it do in the future?

  • What? You have no idea how to price stuff, except from that profit model equation we learned in Andy’s section?
  • Don’t worry; in just a moment, you’ll see a few methods on how to price products.
  • For now, let’s talk about public sectors.

Public sector

  • If you’re like me and you have less general knowledge than a plank of wood, let me tell you what a public sector is.
  • Public sector: a part of the economy composed of both public services and public enterprises.
  • Basically, they’re services and goods provided by the government for the general public, including:
  • Military
  • Law enforcement (police)
  • Infrastructure (roads, bridges, tunnels, water supply, sewers, electrical grids, telecommunications etc.)
  • Public transport (trains, the tube etc.)
  • Schools
  • Health care
  • The government itself

  • Alright, that’s great, but why should we care? Why should I know about schools if I’m planning to sell a graphics card?
  • If you access data on current spending habits in a range of different public sector bodies, you can earn some valuable market analysis.
  • If schools need beefier computers to help teach kids machine learning or something, but spending has been quite scarce on public schools at the moment, you might want to consider opting for a cheaper solution as opposed to a premium high-end product.

  • You never know when you might hit a gap in a market that you’re able to fulfil: even if that gap belongs to a public sector.

  • For resources about public sector analysis, check out Statista, a statistics and reports website, or Mintel, a market reports website about market reports and industry trends.

Pricing

  • Gross profit = Revenue - Cost
  • That means all the money coming in minus all the money going out.

  • You also need to pay attention to price elasticity.
  • Price elasticity: a measure of the relationship between a change in the quantity demanded of a particular good and a change in its price [citation].
  • What does that even mean?
  • If a product has high elasticity, a small change in price will yield a big change in demand, and therefore, quantity (number of products sold to customers). That’s called price elastic.
  • If a product has low elasticity, a small change in price will yield a small change in demand and quantity. That’s called price inelastic.
  • Generally, price inelastic is better than price elastic, hence the green and red.

  • For example, let’s look at petrol.
  • Almost every car needs petrol. For a few people, driving isn’t essential, but for most, they need to drive. Since they need to drive, and most people use cars that use petrol, those people need to buy petrol.
  • There’s no “alternative” to petrol if you have a car that takes petrol, so even if the price of petrol fluctuates, people will still buy petrol.
  • That means petrol is price inelastic.

  • Now, let’s look at bread.
  • Let’s say you go to Tesco and find Tesco bread for 55p and Kingsmill for 65p.
  • If you’re a student, you’ll probably get the Tesco bread for 55p because it’s cheaper and is pretty much the same (unless you really love Kingsmill).
  • However, if Tesco were to increase the price from 55p to 65p, the Tesco bread will now be the same price as the Kingsmill bread.
  • Therefore, us students will be more likely to buy the Kingsmill bread for the same price.
  • Even though it’s just a 10p difference, that 10p was the dealbreaker because there are better alternatives.
  • That makes Tesco bread price elastic.

  • Here’s a list of examples:

Price inelastic

Price elastic

Petrol

Heinz soup

Salt

Shell petrol (if Shell is too expensive, people will buy from other stations)

A good produced by a monopoly

Tesco bread

Tap water

  • [citation]
  • You can also visualise this with a linear graph:

  • There’s also psychological pricing.
  • That’s when people price stuff as £9.99 instead of just saying £10.
  • It doesn’t have to be one off a whole number; you can also have €0.88 as well.

  • Remember that price represents value.
  • Also remember that there’s a difference.
  • Price is how much money the buyer is giving to buy that product.
  • Value is how much worth the product has in the buyer’s eyes.
  • If your price correlates well with your value, you have a decent price.
  • If you have a lower price, that gives off the impression that your product is “lower value”.
  • If you have a higher price, that gives off the impression that your product is premium and of “higher value”.

  • There are a range of strategies to pricing as well:
  • Cost-plus pricing: adding a bit extra to your total costs to get your price
  • Competitive pricing: setting a price based on competition prices
  • Price skimming: set a high price first, lower it as market evolves
  • Penetration pricing: set a low price first, raise it later when we get more “popular”
  • Price bundling: combine products together to add value, and therefore increase price

  • Here’s a bunch of industrial pricing strategies:

New product pricing situation

Competitive pricing situation

Price skimming

Leader pricing

We initiate a price change and expect the other firms to follow (basically, we alpha our competition)

Penetration pricing

Parity pricing

We match the price set by the overall market or the price leader (basically, we beta towards firms using Leader pricing)

Experience curve pricing

Set price low at first, then reduce costs through accumulated experience (similar to penetration pricing)

Low-price supplier

We always strive to have the low price in the market (think Lidl or Aldi)

Product line pricing situation

Cost-based pricing situation

Complementary product pricing

We price the core product low when complementary items such as accessories, supplies, spares, services etc. can be priced with a high premium (think The Sims, or any EA / Activision game)

Cost-plus pricing

Price bundling

Bundle a bunch of products together that offer the customer savings as opposed to buying them all individually (think Humble Bundle)

Customer value pricing

Offer different versions of the product, with varying number of features available (Lite version, Standard version, Premium version)

  • Here is a pricing strategy that the US healthcare company IDR Medical adopts:

  • The steps basically are:
  1. Determine minimum price
  2. Determine maximum price
  3. Pick 5 prices between min and max price
  4. Survey people with those 5 prices
  5. Look at your survey results
  6. Pick an optimised price

  • There’s also a research paper that says:
  • “selecting the correct pricing strategy for a certain product-firm situation directly impacts product profitability and return-on-investment”
  • Basically, pick the right pricing strategy and your product will be more profitable.
  • I thought that was kind of obvious, because a condition for being the “correct” pricing strategy would be the pricing strategy that maximizes profits the most.

Team Lifecycle

  • I’m going to spoil you for this section by telling you the summary at the start:
  • Goal setting improves performance if goals are difficult and specific
  • Different team roles exist, and there are personal preferences
  • Teams go through different stages as they form
  • Interaction is important – it really does matter if you’re kind and dependable

Locke’s goal setting theory

  • “Do your best!”
  • What? My best?
  • How much is my best?
  • How do I know when I’m doing my best and when I’m not?

  • Edwin Locke and Gary Latham studied goal setting and established their goal setting theory, so stupid vague goals like that would be replaced with goals that are difficult and specific.
  • When goals are difficult and specific, people work harder to achieve them.
  • But how do you come up with these goals?
  • Follow these 5 principles that each goal should have:
  • Clarity: Clear, accurate, precise
  • Challenge: Difficult but realistic; a fun level of challenging
  • Commitment: Everyone must agree with these goals
  • Feedback: Knowing how well you are making progress towards your goal
  • Task complexity: Keep It Simple, Stupid! Split the goal if it’s too complex

  • Going back to the “do your best” goal, it was roasted in this quote:
  • “maximum effort is not aroused under a do best goal. This is because the ambiguity inherent in doing one’s best allows people to give themselves the benefit of the doubt in evaluating their performance.”
  • The moral of the story is: don’t do your best. Complete your goals instead.
  • Don’t believe in yourself. Believe in me! Believe in the me who believes in you!

  • Hmm? You want an example?
  • Instead of Scouts saying “do your best”, they should set goals like:
  • Pitch our scout tent in under 2 minutes 30 seconds
  • Train 90% of our members to light a fire using a flint by the 21st November
  • Wash 180 cars at the next fundraiser

  • Now you can actually see and strive for your achievements instead of a vague “do your best”.
  • Besides, isn’t “do your best” a bit overdone? It’s really lost its power. You hear it and it doesn’t motivate you or anything.
  • However, when you look at these goals, they seem impressive but doable. They make you want to achieve them, like Steam / PSN achievements or something. It gives you something to strive for, and will ultimately lead to a sense of accomplishment.

  • May be too preoccupied to communicate effectively
