Tuckman’s model of group development

  • Remember forming, storming, norming and performing?
  • Yeah, it’s just that again.

  • If you’ve got a really bad memory (or if you just don’t care enough to remember), here’s a refresher:
  • When you meet a new group, you go through a couple of phases:
  1. Forming: You’re on your best behaviour
  2. Storming: It doesn’t go as planned and you see the bad in people
  3. Norming: You accept that nobody is perfect and try to make things work
  4. Performing: You’re in perfect harmony with your group
  5. Adjourning / Mourning: Leaving your group

Drexler & Sibbet team performance

  • This is similar to Tuckman, but it’s more of a model you follow and less of a “repeated observation”.
  • There are seven stages to this model, four for creating the team and three for sustaining the team:
  1. Orientation: Why am I here?
  2. Trust Building: Who are you?
  3. Goal Clarification: What are we doing?
  4. Commitment: How will we do it?
  5. Implementation: Who does what, when and where?
  6. High Performance: Wow! (We’re doing well)
  7. Renewal: Why continue?

Others

  • Here’s something Google uses:

  • Basically, who is on the team doesn’t matter as much as how well a team collaborates, structures their work and contribute.

  • There’s also the Barnum Effect, which states that:
  • “a common psychological phenomenon whereby individuals give high accuracy ratings to descriptions of their personality that supposedly are tailored specifically to them, that are in fact vague and general enough to apply to a wide range of people”
  • Basically people think that a description is tailored to them, when really it’s so general it could apply to anyone (like star signs).

Product Evaluation

  • In this section, we will be evaluating products.
  • When we evaluate products, we care about what the customers think.

  • Conventional product development process: relies on intuition throughout the product development stages
  • Reliable and successful products are based on the needs of the user.
  • Take into account all human-related design conditions:
  • Physiology
  • Psychology
  • Cognition
  • Behaviour
  • We don’t make products for the designer: we make them for the customer
  • Even if we’re not-for profit

  • Here’s a representation of ISO 2500 for software product quality:

  • Engineers change the world, but the world has to move along with them
  • We can make cool stuff, but how can we apply it for customers in the real world?
  • Solve the problem; don’t serve ideas

  • We have an example here called Shot Buddy.
  • I’d come up with a funnier example, but I can’t be bothered and these slides are awful. Sorry!
  • Basically, it’s a tool that brings you back the ball when you shoot it in basketball. It’s used for training.

  • First, we determine the target market.
  • Professional / Amateur?
  • Age range?
  • We figure this out by brainstorming:
  • Anyone team member who should know?
  • Family member?
  • Friend?
  • Any experience?

  • Then, we set out a problem statement:
  • “Design a basketball return device for players from about age 10 to age 18 that will automatically return the ball to the shooting player.”
  • Then we break it down:
  1. Return missed shots near the hoop
  2. Return missed shots even when they aren’t hitting the hoop or the backstop
  3. Track where the shooter is on the court
  4. Return the ball to the position of the shooter
  5. Return the ball quickly
  6. Do not block the shooter’s access to the basket
  7. Fit any kind of hoop that a young player might have (e.g., a height adjustable hoop)
  8. Be easily set up on a hoop and court
  9. Fit hoops set up on home courts (eg. free standing systems, or garage or home wall-mounted hoops)
  10. Be able to be stored in small space
  11. Withstand the elements if left attached to a hoop for an extended period of time
  12. Return shots taken from the wings of the baskets (not just in front of the basket)
  13. Return balls with enough energy to reach a shooter standing as far away as the three-point line
  14. Return the ball accurately—so the shooter doesn’t have to move to get the ball

  • Can we structure this better?
  • Yes! With affinity diagrams.
  • For any Xenoblade fan, affinity will be a familiar concept.
  • Unfortunately, this is nothing like that.
  • Affinity diagrams help organise large groups of information into meaningful categories.
  • It’s like the “output” of a brainstorming session, and helps illustrate relationships between groups:

  • This’ll help us focus the team’s design scope and identify areas to focus during research.

  • So far, is the team’s intuition reliable?
  • We can get more reliable information through the customer co-creation model.
  • The Co-Creation Model establishes levels of consumer involvement in a product or service.

  • We can pick one out of four of the involvement levels:
  • Submitting: customers send in ideas, company can either accept or reject ideas but most of the work is done by company
  • Tinkering: original idea is done by company, but customers can modify what has already been built (think games with level creators, like Super Mario Maker or Little Big Planet)
  • Co-Designing: problem has already been defined, but customers guide the selection (think Threadless, where an online community create designs but the shop is run by the company)
  • Collaboration: the company literally just works with the customers all the way through, in a collaboration

  • We can also use product design surveys.
  • What are they?
  • Product design surveys are those surveys that have a bunch of statements and you pick a number from 1-5 on how much you agree / disagree with it.
  • You’ve most likely done one before.

  • The good thing about these is that they’re quantitative.
  • Because they’re represented in numbers, we can collect them up and reason about them.
  • We can even convert the results of these into customer requirements and will form the customers’ opinion about the quality of the product.

  • The product needs to satisfy:
  • Customer needs
  • Organisational needs
  • Regulatory needs

  • Customer requirements can be classified into four categories:
  • Expecters (identifiable via benchmarking)
  • Spokens (identifiable via surveys)
  • Unspokens (identifiable via ethnography)
  • Exciters (identifiable via research / innovation)
  • It’s also important to identify and satisfy the critical success requirements of the target market.

  • Here’s some more customer requirements from product design surveys and classification:
  1. Weatherproof—System should not rust from being exposed to rain and snow to give the option of leaving it in its in-use position for long periods of time.
  2. Accurate Shot Return—An effective ball return system must be able to return the ball to the place of the shooter at the time when the ball leaves the shot return system.
  3. Tool-less Installation—System does not require any tools to be used in order to assemble, disassemble, or install; this includes hand tools or power tools.
  4. Five-year Lifetime—This includes the ability to handle environmental factors as well as dropping hazards from heights up to the maximum usage height of the product.
  5. Quick Return—The Shot-Buddy must return balls quickly, even if they are missed shots. In practice, a shooter can get into a rhythm which helps with building and maintaining a particular shooting “touch.”
  6. Ability to Store in Garage—System should fit it in a small portion of the owner's garage or a shed without having to significantly adjust the placement of other belongings.
  7. Compatibility with Most Basket Configurations—Basketball return system must be compatible to attach to any brand of basketball hoop.
  8. Does not Jam—The Shot-Buddy must return shots that are coming from all angles and at different velocities without letting the ball get stuck in the system and fail to return.
  9. Ability to Catch Most Shots (Missed and Made)—The Shot-Buddy must work with a wide range of shots, both falling into the basket and missing the basket.
  10. Non-obtrusive—The Shot-Buddy cannot limit the number of shots that can be taken by having components that block a shooter’s access to the basket on the floor or in the air.

  • It’s not enough to have customer requirements.
  • We need to convert them to testable engineering characteristics.
  • They need to capture:
  • Parameters
  • Design variables
  • Constraints identified through:
  • Research
  • Benchmarking
  • Reverse engineering
  • Here’s some examples from our basketball product:
  1. Catch area—the volume around the basket that indicates the zone in which any basketball thrown will be returned to the shooter
  2. Probability of jamming—the configuration (mouth size, length, number of turns) of the ball return guide will determine the likelihood of a basketball getting stuck.
  3. Accuracy of ball return—% of time the ball returns to the lane of the shooter
  4. Average time of ball return—length of time from shot passing the height of the basket to when it is returned to the shooter.
  5. Sensing position of shooter—a key functionality of the Shot-Buddy is to determine where the shooter is on the court in order to accurately aim the ball’s return.
  6. Lane change time—time it takes the ball return aiming device to rotate through a lane.
  7. Lane span—degrees in radians that the lane traces out in rotation centered on the basket.
  8. Energy or torque to rotate ball return subsystem—the Shot-Buddy must include a moving system to aim the ball to the lane of the shooter.
  9. Weight
  10. Time to install system—length of time it takes for a homeowner to assemble and mount the system and get it working

  • Once we’ve got the product design surveys customer requirements and created engineering characteristics from them, we can combine them to make...
  • ... quality function deployment!
  • I know, I know: that doesn’t sound very interesting. Just hear me out.
  • Quality Function Deployment: a method of ordering engineering characteristics based on their criticality to the customer requirements.
  • What does that even mean? “Criticality”? What’s so “critical” about a machine that spits a ball back at you?
  • When I say the “criticality” of engineering characteristics, I mean how much of the customer requirements we will fulfil by satisfying that engineering characteristic.
  • What? It still doesn’t make sense?
  • Let me show you an example then:

  • As you can see, we have all the engineering characteristics on the top and the customer requirements on the left.
  • For each “cell”, a number between 1 to 10 details how much that engineering characteristic will satisfy that customer requirement.
  • On the top we have “improvement directions”. That shows if we want to maximise or minimise that engineering characteristic (for example, the arrow is down for “jamming probability” because we want to minimise the probability of the device jamming)
  • For example, look up “weatherproof” with “weather resistance”. That’s a solid 9, because increasing our weather resistance will obviously make it weather/waterproof!
  • If you look up “tool-less installation” and “material rigidity”, it’s a 1. I suppose making the product robust will reduce the need for using tools to fix the product? It’s not a very strong correlation, but it’s a correlation nonetheless.
  • For every other pairing that are not applicable, it’s left blank, meaning 0.
  • Make more sense now?
  • All of these scores are collected and ranked at the bottom.
  • As you can see, the “catch area” engineering characteristic is the most critical and affects the most customer requirements.

  • Sick of product evaluation yet?
  • Don’t worry; this is the last bit.
  • Everything above helps us to decide if the new product is a good investment.
  • The resulting documentation is typically called a new product marketing report.
  • The full report includes:
  • the business objectives
  • product details
  • required technology
  • competing products
  • projected sales
  • marketing strategy
  • capital requirements
  • development cost and time
  • expected profit over time
  • shareholder returns
  • The engineering design tasks are compiled into product design specifications (PDS).
  • The PDS forms the reference document for the design and manufacture of the product, and documents all outcomes of the product development process.

Projects: Introduction and Life-Cycle

  • Remember when we spoke about the life-cycle of an organisation?
  • Birth, Growth, Decline, Death?
  • If not, it’s in the Company Lifecycle section, a few headings up.
  • Well, projects have a life-cycle too. We’ll be going over that in this section!

Types of Projects

  • Innovation starts with an identified problem.
  • One person (or a group) comes up with a solution.
  • However, transforming that idea into reality is rarely one person’s effort.
  • Most of us here will either:
  • Find solutions
  • Work to make ideas reality
  • Fail this module and work at Sainsburys
  • When we do, we will be working on a project.

  • What’s a project, exactly?
  • Project: A temporary endeavour undertaken to produce unique product, service, or result.
  • This is opposed to operations, which are ongoing and repetitive (like this module).
  • What do we mean by “temporary”?
  • We don’t mean “having a short duration”. A project could be really long.
  • We mean that a project needs to have a projected “ending”.
  • A project ends when one of these conditions are true:
  • The project's objectives have been achieved
  • It becomes clear the objectives cannot be met
  • Funding is exhausted (or no longer available for allocation)
  • The need for the project no longer exists (customer no longer wants it, there is strategic change / change in priority)
  • Requisite resources (human / material) no longer available

  • Project characteristics:
  • Unique
  • Uncertain
  • Temporary
  • Defined Deliverable
  • Constrained

  • Project constraints:
  • Time
  • Budget (resources)
  • Quality

  • Project management (PM): Application of knowledge, skills, tools, and techniques to project activities to meet the project requirements.
  • It integrates about 50 logically grouped project management processes, categorised into five Process Groups:
  • Initiating
  • Planning
  • Executing
  • Monitoring and Controlling
  • Closing
  • Those groups make up the project life-cycle, but we’ll get into that in a minute.

  • Engineers and managers have to work together to make a project work, hence Engineering Management and Law.
  • Did you know that there is a global demand for managers who have technical knowledge with a good understanding of business principles and corporate dynamics?
  • Basically, managers who actually know what they’re talking about.

  • Things vary based on the nature of the project, like:
  • Resources
  • Depth of planning
  • Areas of emphasis
  • Therefore, projects can be classified based on these attributes.
  • Projects in the same classification may share similar project management processes.
  • Newer projects can also “take lessons from” older projects in the same category.

  • So what are these categories?
  • Here are the categories:

Examples

  • Every project is unique, is novel and has a “transient existence” (it will end, unlike JoJolion)
  • However:
  • Some projects are more different from others.
  • Some are more similar to each other
  • Some are more complex than others
  • Some are more routine than others
  • But the categories above do not express this!
  • Therefore we have a further categorisation based on experience:
  • Runners: Virtually routine batch processing. The company is very familiar with it and what it entails. We’ve done it so many times it’s boring.
  • Example: Maintenance Projects

  • Repeaters: We have done similar things many times before. Knowledge of how to manage this project exists in the company.
  • Example: A video game company making another sequel to a big series

  • Strangers: We may have done something similar previously, but there are significant unfamiliar aspects.
  • Example: Apple making new computers but with their own processors

  • Aliens: Completely not like any project previously done.
  • Example: Apple making a car, Microsoft making robust software, EA making a good game (the last two are jokes)

  • This is kind of like a scale.
  • Project risk and PM effort goes up as you go from runners to aliens.

Project Life-cycle

  • There are four stages to a project’s life-cycle:
  1. Concept / Initiation
  • Birthing the project
  • Includes:
  • Business Case (how will this affect the business)
  • Feasibility Study (can we do this?)
  • Technical (do we have the tech?)
  • Economic (do we have the money?)
  • Legal (is it legal to do this?)
  • Operational (do we have enough manpower?)
  • Project Charter (what are we actually doing)
  • Project Team (who will be working on this)
  • Most projects do not go beyond this stage.
  1. Planning
  • Organising / Preparing
  • Includes:
  • Project Schedule (what are we doing)
  • Budget (how much money can we spend)
  • Quality Plan (how to upkeep quality)
  • Risk Plan (how to mitigate risks)
  • Communications Plan (how do we talk to each other)
  • Procurement Plan (where will we get our stuff from)
  • Tenders
  • Technical / Commercial Qualifications
  • Request for Proposal
  • Supplier Contract / Sub-contract
  1. Execution
  • Carrying out the actual work
  • Includes:
  • Scheduled work packets with associated expenditure
  • Monitor and control
  • Time
  • Cost
  • Quality
  • Change
  • Risk
  • Procurement
  • Documentation
  1. Closure
  • Ending the project
  • Includes:
  • Commissioning / Hand-over
  • Documentation (lessons learned)
  • Project Review
  • Disband / Reassign Team
  • Perhaps celebrate... or cry

  • Projects are different from products: products can be the result of a project.
  • This is different from the life-cycle of a company or a product, but they should still be taken into account too.

  • Most projects have these life-cycle stages, but the activities in these stages can vary.
  • Projects can either be:
  • Predictable: plan-driven, typically Repeaters and Runners. Outputs are pre-defined, then scope changes are carefully managed
  • Adaptive: change-driven, typically Strangers and Aliens. Output is developed over multiple iterations and detailed scope is defined for each iteration only as the iteration begins

Cost / Resource variation across the lifecycle

Risk and uncertainty and Cost of changes

Project Management and Controls

Project Activity Network

  • A project activity network can help you manage the activities within a project, their durations, their order and how much they can be delayed by.
  • It’s kind of like a Gantt chart, but with boxes and more emphasis on being “early” and “late”.

  • Each activity has a box with fields, like so:

Early Start

Identifier Number

Early Finish

Activity Float

Activity Descriptor

Late Start

Activity Duration

Late Finish

  • Early Start: The earliest time at which this activity can start
  • Early Finish: The earliest time at which this activity can end
  • Identifier Number: The “ID” of the activity (doesn’t have to be a number)
  • Activity Float: The most amount of time this activity can be delayed by
  • Activity Descriptor: A description of this activity
  • Activity Duration: How long this activity will go for
  • Late Start: The latest time at which this activity can start
  • Late Finish: The latest time at which this activity can end

  • For example, an activity could look like this:

  • What does this mean?
  • The earliest this activity can start is 5 minutes in. If the activity is 5 minutes long, the earliest it will finish is 10 minutes in.
  • However, if we wait 5 minutes to start this activity but we’re delayed by 1 minute, the latest we can start is 6 minutes in. Therefore, the latest we’ll finish this activity by is 11 minutes in.

  • That’s cool, but there’s no order. If there’s an activity B, how do we know to do A before B?
  • These boxes are supposed to be connected into a DAG.

  • When many activities can start after one finishes, that’s a burst point.

  • When one activity can start after many activities end, that’s a merge point.

  • That’s cool too, but how do we fill in all the fields?
  • If you’ve ever done Dijkstra’s algorithm by hand in Decision 1 A Level Maths, then this’ll feel familiar to you.
  • We need to do a forward pass from the initial activity to fill out the early fields, then do a backward pass from the last activity to fill out the late fields.
  • I’ll show you an example:

  • We start with A. A has no dependencies, so we can start working on that immediately, making Early Start = 0.
  • It has a duration of 5 minutes, so Early Finish = 5m.
  • B, however, does have a dependency: A. A’s early finish ends at 5 minutes, so B can start straight afterwards, making B’s early start 5 minutes.
  • B also has a duration of 5 minutes, so Early Finish = 10 minutes.
  • We can keep going until we’ve filled every activity in.

  • But wait! There’s a merge point from B and C to D. Which Early Finish does D use: B’s Early Finish of 10m or C’s Early Finish of 11m?
  • The rule is to always use the longer duration, so D will use C’s 11m.

  • Now we can start the backwards pass.
  • For the final activity, Late Finish = Early Finish, so D’s Late Finish is 24m.
  • Late Start = Late Finish - Duration (it’s like we’re working backwards)
  • So D’s Late Start is 24m - 13m = 11m.
  • For other activities, Late Finish = Late Start of the next activity.
  • So B and C’s Late Finish will be 11m.
  • We can keep going until we’ve filled everything in.

  • But wait again! A is a burst point between B and C. Does A pick B’s Late Start or C’s Late Start?
  • When we do a backwards pass, we pick the shortest duration, as opposed to a forward pass where we pick the longest duration.
  • Therefore, A will pick C’s 5m.

  • Finally, we can calculate Activity Float, or SLACK.
  • This one’s easy and doesn’t rely on order:
  • Activity Float = Late Start - Early Start
  • So we can just go around and apply this to all activities.
  • I’d do that for this example, but the one from the slides gives more insight. It’s the same example, but with just more activities:

  • Looking at the red numbers (Activity Float), we can’t afford to delay on activities A, C, D, F and H.
  • However, we can delay the other activities by varying amounts.
  • The path from A to C to D to F to H is the critical path and cannot be delayed.
  • Project duration can be reduced by:
  • Eliminate tasks on the critical path
  • Replan serial paths to be in parallel
  • Overlap sequential tasks
  • Shorten the duration of critical path tasks
  • Shorten early tasks
  • Shorten longest tasks
  • Shorten easiest tasks
  • Shorten tasks that cost the least to speed up
  • The effectiveness of these methods depends on:
  • Project constraints
  • Client expectations
  • Project manager’s own organisation

  • Delaying activities is useful when you need to crash the project.
  • What’s crashing? I’m glad you asked...

Crashing Projects

  • Projects are constrained on time, cost and quality.
  • Sometimes, we need to accelerate projects.
  • When we accelerate a project, we are performing project crashing.
  • Why do we crash projects?
  • Aggressive / Ambitious Scheduling
  • Change in the (Business) environment (perhaps rivalry)
  • Project is behind schedule and need to be shaped in
  • Avoid slippage costs (hence a trade-off)

  • How do we determine when we need to crash a project?
  • Resource availability (cost, personnel, equipment, etc.)
  • Cost Considerations (crashing may gain time, but will incur extra costs)
  • Management disposition (perhaps not enough management)

  • So how can we crash a project?
  • while (true) { }?
  • Not that kind of crash... here are the crashing options:
  • Improving efficiency of use of current resources
  • Cut off unnecessary bureaucracy (e.g. middle management)
  • Improve motivation of team members
  • Improving work methods / equipment
  • Electronic communications instead of meetings
  • Paying specialists for specific tasks (includes sub-contracting)
  • Reducing project scope
  • Removing “minor” aspects of a project
  • Compromise quality
  • A bit risky; there can be consequences
  • Fast-tracking
  • Rearrange schedule to have more activities in parallel
  • Might not be obvious at first
  • You can do this by scrutinizing the critical path for possibilities of shortening longer tasks

  • Have you ever heard of the expression “crushed time, boomed cost”?
  • Me neither.
  • When we crash a project, we don’t have to crash the entire thing in one go: we can crash the activities individually.
  • However, crashing usually costs more money, because we’re trying to speed things up.
  • So what’s the trade-off between how much money the crashing will cost and the speed increase of the crash? If we can calculate a trade-off, we can decide if crashing is a good idea.
  • Here’s a graph of activity cost against activity duration:

  • If we can find the gradient of the slope, that’ll give us a pretty good figure of a trade-off.
  • The equation is this:

  • There’s no specific “range” of a slope indicating a good crash or bad crash. It depends on the project itself and the penalties of being late.

Project Control

  • Cost tracking: comparing the estimates with actual costs incurred during execution
  • Costs include:
  • Labour costs
  • Material costs
  • Project support costs (admin costs, like consumables, travel etc.)
  • Schedule tracking: comparing scheduled work with actual work executed in relation to time
  • With this, you can track if a project is ahead (lead) or behind (lag)
  • It focuses and compares:
  • Scheduled Start and finish time for each scheduled.
  • Actual start and finish time of each
  • Percentage completion of the project
  • Estimated completion date
  • Milestones reached
  • Deliverables accomplished
  • Tracking these two helps track the performance of the project.

  • Earned value: value of planned work that has been accomplished to date.
  • It provides a reliable indication of the performance of the project.
  • It consists of three elements:
  • Budgeted cost of work performed (BCWP) - The value (based on the budget) of the work completed to date
  • Budgeted cost of work scheduled (BCWS) - The planned value of the work scheduled to have been completed to date
  • Actual cost of work performed (ACWP) - The value of the work performed based on the actual expenditure to date
  • These three are the basis for Variance Analysis.
  • What is Variance Analysis?
  • Variance Analysis: a quantitative investigation of the difference between actual and planned behavior [citation].
  • Well, whatever. Just memorise these:

  • Cost Variance (CV) represents the difference between what was expected to be spent for the work performed and what was actually spent.

  • Schedule Variance (SV) is the difference between the value of the work actually performed and the value of the work scheduled to be performed for a specified period.
  • Budget at Completion (BAC) is the estimated total cost of the project or a work package when completed; when combined with project contingency or management reserve funds, BAC equals the total project budget.
  • Estimate to Complete (ETC) is an estimate of how much more money the project will require to be completed.

  • Estimate at Completion (EAC) is the current measured (actual) cost plus the estimated cost for the remaining work.

  • Cost Performance Index (CPI) is a numeric representation of how effective the project has been to date in terms of cost.

  • Doing this performance checking in the first place might be a trigger for project crashing. Why would you be checking performance in the first place if your project didn’t need crashing?

Project Closure

Project Closure Report

  • A project closure report is made to determine if:
  • The project achieved its objectives
  • The business benefits stated in the business case were realised
  • Otherwise there’s no clear indication whether the project was a success or failure.
  • Takes additional time and budget to formally close a project and review its level of success.
  • It’s kind of like a project retrospective.
  • You can also decide if it’s better to:
  • Close the project altogether
  • Start a new one

  • You can also think of it like a formalised end of a project.
  • Provides confirmation that the criteria for customer acceptance have been met
  • Requests sign-off from the project sponsor to close the project.

  • The report includes:
  1. Detailed list of project completion criteria
  2. Confirmation that all completion criteria have been met
  3. List of outstanding business activities, risks and issues.
  4. Set of actions needed in order to:
  • Hand over project deliverables and documentation
  • Terminate supplier agreements
  • Release resources to the business and inform stakeholders of the closure
  • Official request for project closure approval.

  • Validating the project completion:
  • Has all completion criteria been met?

  • Criteria is met, but are there outstanding actions / items?

  • Identifying the required closure activities:
  1. Handover of deliverables
  2. Documentation
  3. Sub-contractor / supplier terminations
  4. Resources release
  5. Communication

Post Implementation Review

  • Assesses the overall success of the project
  • Identifies lessons and makes recommendations for future projects
  • Conducted after official project closure is approved and all activities are completed.
  • Good practice is to wait a little to see how the benefits play out.
  • Produced by independent / unbiased person.

  • Review of the project’s performance against the original targets:
  • Scope, Budget, Schedule, Resource allocation
  • Checking conformance against the PM processes originally set out:
  • Time / Cost management, RM (risk management), Procurement, Comms, Quality
  • Measures deviations from forecasted benefits in the Business Case:
  • Operational efficiency, cost reduction, increased market share

Quantitative Risk Management

  • Ready for a history lesson?
  • Risk ‘Pooling’ or ‘diversification’:
  • Chinese merchants travelling on the Yellow River used to distribute all their goods across everyone’s boats, so if one boat was lost then each merchant would only lose a small proportion of their cargo.
  • The Babylonians used to do this too with camel trains.

  • Risk transference:
  • In insurance, a contract is drawn up where a reimbursement for financial losses caused by some specified peril is promised in return for a payment of an insurance premium.
  • In other words, risk of financial loss is said to be transferred from the insured to the insurer through the mechanism of the insurance contract.
  • So when you break your phone or something, instead of forking out a huge sum for a replacement, it’s “transferred” to the insurance company.

  • That’s cool, we’ve learned about risk analysis for, like, the millionth time now.
  • Why do we even do it?
  • To self insure (because insurance is expensive)
  • To comply with regulation
  • To get better credit ratings
  • Shareholders and markets want it
  • Regulators want it
  • To improve governance
  • To improve strategic decision-making
  • To add value across the organisation
  • To enhance management (the best reason, apparently)

  • What is risk? There are multiple meanings:
  • General: exposure to danger
  • Health and safety: probability that a person will be harmed
  • Project management: anything that might affect the objectives of the project
  • Risk also means “uncertainty that matters”

  • There is a difference between risk and uncertainty.
  • Risk is the “effect of uncertainty on objectives”
  • Uncertainty is “a situation in which something is not known”
  • ... and yet “risk analysis involves a detailed consideration of uncertainties”

  • Risk Management (RM): The identification, assessment and prioritisation of risks
  • It’s an operational issue: one of the key project management competencies
  • ... and a strategic issue: defining a level of risk that is acceptable

  • Risks need to be balanced with the reward. “No action” is also technically a risk.
  • Only 39% of executives in a 2010 survey reported a “strong risk management culture”
  • “Risk management is what helps you identify the potential crisis that will cause your schedule to fall apart”

  • There are a variety of different approaches to risk:
  • Portfolio
  • Google divide their operating budget into a ratio:
  • 70% - core business: search optimisation, advertising
  • 20% - next gen: gmail, maps, analytics, trends
  • 10% - far-future: glass, cars, robots
  • Strategy
  • Gore is a US manufacturer of advanced materials, and any employee can suggest a new project.
  • Evaluation of projects are split into 3 metrics: Real, Win, Worth
  • They also adopt a “waterline” concept: if it’s below the “waterline” (would sink us), we don’t do the project.

  • There’s also TTP who uses the basic model of “fees for time” and won’t take any project that could kill the company.
  • Systematic
  • You define a Risk Register, where you include stuff like likely low-impact events and unlikely high-impact events
  • Also develop delivery schedules with large safety margins
  • All partners are involved in the risk management process
  • The Olympic Delivery Authority for the London 2012 Olympics applied this

  • Risk in banking:
  • This guy named Tom said that the key risks of banking are:
  • Credit, Liquidity, Interest rate, Conduct and Operational Risk

This is, uh, Tom.

  • Keep it simple.
  • What can go wrong?
  • What is the impact if it goes wrong?
  • How do you know if it has gone wrong?

  • Issues for managing risk in engineering:
  1. Engineering risk management sometimes has a ‘Linnean’ character (named after the botanist Carl Linnaeus) insofar as it must be exhaustive in categorising engineering risks (for design/construction/materials etc.) in order to stave off potential litigation. In other words it’s a research job!
  • If that made no sense, try this explanation:
  • It means you need to be thorough. For example: In the UK if there's a workplace death in a factory during a process, the Health and Safety Executive will automatically sue your company.

  • If any are true:
  • You did not have Risk assessments for the process.
  • The victim was not violating the assessed process. (IE, they did the correct thing but your processes were flawed).
  • Management was not enforcing these policies if the employee didn't follow them properly.
  • Then the directors of the company can go to prison or the company can get a massive fine.

  • You need to consider and mitigate every risk as mistakes can be catastrophic (if you build a bridge from the wrong materials and it falls down then you're liable).
  1. Risk management can involve anticipating risk and / or becoming resilient to the risk you haven’t been able to anticipate. In complex large scale contracts there are ALWAYS important risks that have not been anticipated and transferred adequately in the risk provisions of the contract. Hence mechanisms like ‘online dispute resolution’ are becoming more important as a means to solve the ‘who pays for unforeseen losses’ issues that inevitably crop up – thereby avoiding expensive litigation.

  • Risk Management methods:
  • Risk identification: Might include creation of a risk register
  • Brainstorming
  • Delphi technique
  • Interviewing
  • Root cause analysis
  • Checklist analysis
  • Assumption analysis
  • Diagramming techniques
  • Cause and effect diagrams
  • System or process flow charts
  • Influence diagrams
  • SWOT analysis
  • Expert judgement
  • Risk analysis: Identify likelihood and potential impact, qualitative and quantitative
  • Qualitative:
  • Risk probability and impact assessment
  • Probability and impact matrix
  • Risk categorisation
  • Risk urgency assessment
  • Expert judgement
  • Quantitative:
  • Probability distributions
  • Quantitative risk analysis & modeling techniques
  • Sensitivity analysis
  • Expected Monetary Value analysis (EMV)
  • Modeling & simulation
  • Cost risk analysis
  • Schedule risk analysis
  • Response planning: Plan responses (great definition, huh)
  • Risk reassessment
  • Risk audits
  • Variance and trend analysis
  • Technical performance measurement
  • Reserve analysis
  • Status meetings

  • Pitfalls with risk analysis:
  • People believe that if we have a risk register, we are managing risk
  • People don’t understand the risk process
  • Stakeholders are unclear about what risk is
  • Identifying risks is fine but then people run out of steam

Technological Innovation cf Business Innovation

  • Take a breather! If you’ve made it this far, you’re doing well.
  • Worry not; this section is pretty chill.

Innovation

  • What is innovation?
  • Pick a definition:
  • “The development and implementation of new ideas” (Van de Ven 1986)
  • “The successful exploitation of new ideas” (Cox, 2005)
  • Hmm... they’re both pretty good...
  • Let’s look at some products.

Product

Description

How about these weird smartwatch things? Is this innovation?

Well, they’re new, but they’re not successful.

Have you ever seen someone walking around with one of these?

I swear they tried to make these kind of things, but failed because the tech to make it renders it unusable.

How about these iPads?

iPads are cool and all, but are they new?

We had the Linus Write-Top back in 1987.

We also got the GridPad two years later.

Ah, here we go! Successful and new.

A car. Did you know it can take you from one place to another way faster than walking?

I’m just kidding. There’s something new about this car, but I don’t know what. It was on the slides. It does look kind of cool, though.

  • Alright, we get it: innovation means successful and new products.
  • Huh? Products?
  • Just products?
  • We can have innovative services too, can’t we?

  • In all sorts of sectors, like finance (mintos, TransferWise, Atom bank) or entertainment (Netflix, EA access, Steam)
  • How about a combination of product and service, like Sonos + Alexa?
  • Services are extremely serious. Just look at all that red on this graph!

  • How about innovative business models?

  • Yeah! We can have innovative everything!

3 reasons why innovation is difficult

  • However, innovation is difficult.
  • Why?
  • Uber is pretty innovative, don’t you think?
  • How many rides happen with Uber per day?
  • There were 17 million a day back in May 2019.
  • Didi, Uber’s old competitor, had even more with 30 million.
  • Damn, imagine implementing a scalable service to handle that load!
  • Yeah, that’d be pretty tough.

  • Innovation can also depend on business environment, for example when Uber’s China unit merged with Didi Chuxing.

  • Regulations can make things difficult though. Amazon Prime Air is an example of this.
  • Imagine drones racing around everywhere dropping off parcels. I don’t think the government would like that.

  • Technology can make things difficult, too.
  • Watch this video about robots getting abused.
  • When will delivery by robot become mainstream? When the technology is there, I guess.
  • For now, though, robots can still be kicked around and bullied, making parcels very easy to steal from them (unless they’re Robocop or something)

  • A combination of these problems can be found in autonomous vehicles.

  • So that’s our three challenges to innovation:
  1. Business environment might not support innovation
  2. Regulations
  3. Technology

TRL: A technology development model

  • What’s TRL (Technology Readiness Level)?
  • It’s a measurement system made by NASA to gauge the maturity level of a technology.
  • You can use it to see how far away a piece of tech is from launch.
  • The levels go like this:
  1. Basic Principles Observed and Reported
  2. Potential Application Validated
  3. Proof-of-Concept Demonstrated, Analytically and/or Experimentally
  4. Component and/or Breadboard Laboratory Validated
  5. Component and/or Breadboard Validated in Simulated or Realspace Environment
  6. System Adequacy Validated in Simulated Environment (prototype demonstration)
  7. System Adequacy Validated in Space
  8. Actual system completed and 'flight qualified' through test and demonstration (ground or space)
  9. Actual system 'flight proven' through successful mission operations
  • Basically, a technology starts at “level 1” and goes up through levels all the way up to level 9, where it’s ready for mass production.

  • However, not all technologies reach level 9.
  • Some of them die in the “valley of death”.

  • The valley of death is a range of TRL levels where a technology is likely to fail most.
  • Funding sources also vary with TRL levels:

  • At the start, they’re funded by unis and stuff, and by the end they’re funded by full-on businesses.
  • Here’s one last image:

Due Diligence, Liquidation, Administration

Due Diligence

  • Insolvency: When a firm has insufficient cash inflows to meet all of its cash outflows.
  • It may sell assets to stay afloat, and may continue to do this until it has nothing left (like in Monopoly if you keep mortgaging until you have nothing left)
  • There are two kinds:
  • Technical insolvency: the inability of the firm to meet cash payments on contractual obligations: accounts payable, wages, taxes, interest
  • Legal insolvency: a firm’s recorded assets amount to less than its recorded liabilities (not enough money to pay off liabilities)
  • So what do we do when we have insolvency?
  1. Do nothing, hope something will come along to save the day
  2. Seek adjustments with creditors outside of the judicial process (called a workout)
  3. Seek court relief in bankruptcy proceedings in the form of a reorganisation or liquidation
  4. Assign assets to a third party for liquidation
  5. Liquidate (sell everything)
  6. Attempt to sell out; look for a buyer
  • Aha! Look for a buyer.
  • That’s what we’re focusing on today.

  • Wanna hear a shocking story?
  • There once was a company named Ferranti.
  • It was a good company; had sales of around £800m.
  • In 1987, it bought the company ISC.
  • However...
  • ISC had boosted its profits by creating $1 billion worth of fictitious contracts and transactions
  • Had little legitimate sales
  • Existed on illegal arms deals
  • The purchase of ISC eventually over-burdened and killed off Ferranti.
  • They declared bankruptcy in 1991, suing ISC’s CEO and its auditors for negligence.
  • Damn. It’s like ISC was cursed, and Ferranti fell ill and died.

  • How can we not end up like Ferranti?
  • Well, naturally, we always like to run checks on stuff before we do stuff:

  • In the context of business, that’s due diligence: research and analysis of a company or organisation done in preparation for a business transaction.
  • Or, in more verbose terms, the processes of examining and developing an understanding of a company and its business operations before entering into a business transaction with, investing in, licensing assets or services of, or purchasing all or part of a business or its assets in order to make an informed decision.

  • There are four cornerstones of due diligence:
  1. The company
  2. Its operations (products, services and assets)
  3. Its value and value of assets
  4. Its people
  • The main objective is to verify that all four of these cornerstones are, well, nothing like ISC.

  • Possible sources of information could be:
  • Materials and data provided by the company
  • Response to due diligence questionnaire
  • Developed by the enquirer
  • Completed by the enquiree
  • Specific to the transaction
  • Advice from professional consultants
  • Publicly available data / info
  • Typical headings of due diligence questionnaire:
  1. Company/entity basic information
  2. Ownership of the key assets
  3. Financial and tax-related matters
  4. Significant agreements, contracts, and undertakings
  5. Legal questions common to most transactions
  6. Information about key personnel and employees
  • The fundamental content would follow the four cornerstones like:

  • To write a story about someone we don’t know very well, we first look for facts about the person, and then verify those facts.
  • That’s what we do with a due diligence plan: it’s like a manual for preparing the due diligence questionnaire.
  • It helps us set out what needs to be confirmed and the result from the point of view of the company itself.
  • The plan identifies general areas to be included in the due diligence review as well as issues necessitated by the structure and terms of the deal (basically, what we need to know that we’re not buying ISC two).
  • The plan must be based on the four cornerstones and include things like:
  • What is the nature of the transaction?
  • What must be understood and verified about the company in light of the proposed transaction?
  • How are the products, services, and assets of the company essential to the success of the transaction, and what issues need to be verified about these?
  • What needs to be understood and verified about the business operations?
  • Is the valuation appropriate in light of the transaction?
  • Are the key personnel capable of meeting the terms of the proposed deal?

Case Study

  • Let’s actually try this out with a case study!
  • Try and pretend you’re a detective or something (bonus points if you’re an Ace Attorney or a Danganronpa fan)

  • We want to buy a company called AB Bacus. Here’s our conversation with them:
  • I am interested in purchasing AB Bacus, an Internet greeting card company. It offers customized gift cards from a variety of apparel, jewellery, electronics, appliance, and other large retailers. What raised my interest in Abacus include:
  • Its relationship with large retailers
  • Its customer list, and, most
  • Its web site and order processing software.
  • I don’t want all of ABB’s business — only certain assets: the web site, the ABB software, certain trademarks/trade names they use for the gift card business, the customer list, and the agreements with the stores.
  • I don’t want the ABB employees, except one to help with the transfer of the retailer relationships to my company.
  • From this alone, we can compile some question-answer logs:

  • We can also create a due diligence plan overview:

  • Let’s talk to ABB some more. Red is us, blue is them:
  • “I have tested your services by ordering various merchant gift cards. I am impressed with the ease of use of the web site and the order process.”
  • “Thank you”
  • “Now, from what I understand, you developed this software in-house, not off-the-shelf program anyone can purchase, right?”
  • “We created the software. No one else has it or offers it as a licensable product ABB owns it. I admit I am not a tech person, Claire my former partner created it but has now left us; I purchased all her shares”
  • “Great! because I wont be interested in the transaction if Claire owns the software”
  • “No I bought all her shares, so that should put you at ease.”
  • “Settled. Now let’s talk about your contracts with the major retail chains…”

HOLD IT!

  • There’s something fishy about the ownership of the software...
  • If Claire left, and this guy purchased her shares, does that transfer her intellectual property to him?
  • Now due diligence must focus on answering the question “who owns this software”.

  • Remember, the due diligence plan is like a “blueprint” for the due diligence questionnaire. Let’s not roast this guy over the software right now; we’ll give him a chance to speak in the questionnaire we make from this plan.
  • For now, let’s talk about something else:
  • “Ok, we discussed the software, can we now turn to the contracts ABB has with the big chain stores”
  • “You can have these contracts. As part of the deal, I will just notify the retailers that your company bought the business. That shouldn’t be any issue.”
  • Lawyer: “there is a problem regarding the contracts between ABB and its retailers. I have been reviewing them, it is clear that each contract requires consent from the owner before it can be assigned to your company.”
  • “What a hassle! There are a lot of contracts, and I was assured that the contracts are assignable during our August 31 meeting.”
  • We should confirm more things about the contracts, like if the contracts are actually assignable:

  • We can also go on to do a plan about customer transfer and so on:

  • You get the picture.

  • Due diligence helps in deciding if the deal is worth the money.
  • It focuses on identifying significant components of a transaction and issues arising thence.
  • It is not a set process in where one size fits all.
  • It must be tailored to the specific terms of the proposed transaction.
  • A due diligence plan helps in tailoring the checks based on the 4 cornerstones.

  • I wonder what would’ve happened if Ferranti had followed due diligence...

Corporate Social Responsibility; Conflicts of Interest, Health and Safety

CSR

  • CSR has tonnes of aliases:
  • Corporate Social Responsibility, Corporate Responsibility, Sustainability, Sustainable Development, Corporate Citizenship, Corporate Philanthropy, Venture Philanthropy, Social Entrepreneurship, Social Enterprise, Corporate Community Involvement, Ethical Business, Ethical Supply, Single Planet Economy, Green Business, Green Supply Chain Management, Environmental Purchasing, Purchasing Social Responsibility, Ethical Sourcing, Socially Responsible Purchasing, Corporate Environmental Responsibility, Corporate Altruism, Corporate Social Opportunity, Corporate Compassion, Business and Human Rights, Corporate Citizenry, Enlightened Enterprise, Business for Society and Environment, etc.
  • There are two main definitions:
  • CSR is “a concept whereby companies integrate social and environmental concerns in their business operations and in their interaction with their stakeholders on a voluntary basis”
  • CSR is “the responsibility of enterprises for their impacts on society”

  • There are common themes to CSR:
  • Internalising: managing externalities e.g. pollution, calculate social and economic cost of relocation or downsizing and include these in any cost-benefit analyses
  • Internalise costs of production
  • Price to recognise full costs of production:
  • Full cost accounting
  • True cost economics
  • This way cost-benefit calculations will reflect the true costs and benefits to all stakeholders, e.g. calculate social and economic cost of relocation or downsizing and include these in any cost-benefit analyses
  • CSR as a voluntary activity
  • Multi-stakeholder orientation
  • Practices and values
  • Transparency
  • Beyond philanthropy
  • Openness in reporting
  • However… CSR is an essentially contested construct

  • We mentioned externalities before. What is that?
  • Externalities: consequences of production born by society
  • They’re typically impacts on parties that are not directly involved in the transaction.
  • An example would be the world: global warming.
  • Here’s a scary collage:

  • Cultural variations:
  • USA - a long history of philanthropy, little state funded welfare
  • Europe - heavier regulation - often more defensive
  • France  - strong social bent but anti-philanthropy
  • Germany - social and environmental sustainability
  • Scandinavia - strong on social and environmental issues
  • Japan - a public duty; lifetime responsibility to employees; integrated into the way of doing business
  • Far East - Corporate governance / transparency (corruption)
  • UK - government involved in many initiatives e.g. sustainable procurement

  • Carroll’s Pyramid of CSR:

Philanthropic Responsibilities

Be a good corporate citizen: contribute resources to the community; improve quality of life.

Ethical Responsibilities

Be ethical, obligation to do what is right, just and fair. Avoid harm

Legal Responsibilities

Obey the law: Law is society’s codification of right and wrong. Play by the rules of the game.

Economic Responsibilities

Be profitable

  • It’s a bit debatable, because it says being profitable is more important than obeying the law.
  • Baden thought it sucked, so he changed it a bit:

Economic Responsibilities

Be profitable

Legal Responsibilities

Obey the law: Law is society’s codification of right and wrong. Play by the rules of the game.

Ethical Responsibilities

Be ethical, obligation to do what is right, just and fair. Avoid harm

  • Corporate Social Performance Model:

Stakeholders

  • Stakeholders aren’t just people who pour money into the company.
  • Stakeholder: any group or individual who can affect or is affected by the achievement of the organization’s objectives
  • There’s many different kinds of stakeholders:

Stakeholder

Stakeholder description

S1: Project proponent

A public agency who initiates and funds the proposed reclamation works

S2: Resident engineer

A private engineering consultancy (appointed by S1) who undertakes site investigation and Environmental Impact Assessment; designs the reclamation method and supervises the works of S3

S3: Contractor

A private contractor company (employed by S1) to construct an artificial island by reclamation

S4: Subcontractor and supplier

Subcontractor and supplier companies including backfilling; supplying and manufacturing of steel for seawall construction

S5: Independent environmental checker

An independent unit (employed by S2 under statutory requirements) to review the environmental monitoring and auditing works done by S6; and to report to S11

S6: Environmental team

An independent unit (hired by S3 under statutory requirements) to undertake environmental monitoring and auditing on the works of S3; and to report to S5

S7: Maritime engineering consultant

A private consultancy (hired by S3) to assist S3 in developing marine traffic schedules; and addressing marine safety and regulatory issues

S8: Environmental specialists in marine ecology

Independent and qualified specialists (hired by S6) to conduct impact monitoring on ecology in the nearby waters, in particular Chinese White Dolphins

S9: Marine Bureau

A government bureau in charge of port control; shipping register and licensing; navigational issues

S10: Civil Aviation Bureau

A government bureau in charge of air traffic flow control; managing aviation safety; setting and implementing relevant statutory regulations

S11: Environmental Protection Bureau

A government bureau in charge of environmental protection and environmental

S12: District Board

Local authority to advise the government on district administration and affairs

S13: Green groups

Stakeholders that care about environmental stuff

S14: Transport trades

Transport operators who provide public transport services in the water or air near the construction site

S15: Contractors of interfacing projects

Contractor companies of interfacing construction projects undertaken concurrently with the case project in or nearby the construction site

Local residents, fishermen groups, general public

  • Stakeholder management is a key tool for ethical management.
  • The first step of stakeholder analysis is to assess the influence and importance of each individual stakeholder:
  • Influence: the extent to which a stakeholder is able to affect the organisation; a measure of power
  • Importance: the extent to which a stakeholder’s problems, needs and interests are affected by the organisation’s activities.
  • Low influence, low importance: no power and doesn’t care
  • High influence, low importance: has lots of power, but doesn’t really care
  • Low influence, high importance: cares about it deeply but can’t do anything about it
  • High influence, high importance: has the power to act upon which they care deeply
  • Primary stakeholders are important and influential
  • Secondary stakeholders are either important or influential

  • This ladder of participation gauges how much influence stakeholders have over company operations. If the text is too small, check out the slides:

  • Let’s look at two examples:
  • Construction of two tunnels under the city of Malmo: through surveys construction company identified six critical stakeholder groups that could influence the project.
  • They had focus groups and meetings to identify needs of these stakeholders and proactively address their needs.
  • Met with public, had open communication, involved media.
  • They did their stakeholder analysis and incorporated CSR and now they’re all good!
  • Expansion of track in the city of Lund: no stakeholder management process, company ignored public opposition, and politicians and the media started to side with public.
  • Company did not respond to media thus increasing their opposition.
  • 6-year project delay.
  • They didn’t do stakeholder analysis and now they’re suffering!

  • ... and now, to conclude the quantitative section of Engineering Management and Law, get ready for pictures of Apple getting roasted!

Legal Topics

Introduction to Law

  • Constitution: collective term for the established laws in a country
  • It can be written as either:
  • One document
  • Discoverable from different sources

  • The UK has a written but uncodified constitution.
  • When it’s uncodified, you can make incremental changes.
  • Flexibility can be an advantage, but it’s also an uncertainty.
  • As opposed to the one in America, where it is written and it’s a lot harder to change it (usually).

Common features of Constitutions

  • The rule of law:
  • Everyone is equal before the law
  • You can’t be punished except if you break the law
  • The Separation of Powers:
  • Three branches of government are separate: Executive, Legislature and Judiciary
  • It’s so that nobody can abuse power
  • No Retrospective Laws:
  • A law must be fully in effect before people can officially break them (before criminal sanctions are imposed)

Sources of Law

  • National Law - Statutory Legislation - the main, overarching laws
  • Case Law - Interpretation of law - what do the laws actually mean? Interpreting the law itself
  • International Treaty law - how we interact with other countries, like trading goods, data protection, internet etc.
  • EU Law - Laws passed by the European Union
  • ECHR - European Court of Human Rights (separate from EU law)
  • Conventions / Customs - ‘soft’ law, historic rights, usually through the crown, it’s just “the way we’ve always done things”, not really enforceable

Purpose of Law

  • Includes rules that:
  • Command
  • Regulate
  • Facilitate
  • Guide
  • Also provides remedies and sanctions to transgressions (an act that goes against a law, rule, or code of conduct; an offence)

  • Criminal law - regulates actions contrary to established laws
  • Often used to protect public
  • Basically, stuff like theft and murder

  • Civil law - used to right a civil wrong
  • Claimant must prove their case on the balance of probabilities
  • One party must show they have the “greater right” than the other party
  • Two parties: Claimant vs Defendant
  • “he said” “she said”
  • For example, claiming stuff after a divorce, like houses or children

Legislation

  • Primary legislation (a.k.a statutes): made by parliament themselves (House of Commons, House of Lords, monarch). Cannot be challenged
  • Delegated legislation: not made by parliament, but is delegated by them. Can be challenged.
  • Three types:
  • Statutory instruments
  • Orders in council
  • By-laws (lower authority, like collecting rubbish in a town)

Judge stuff

  • A judge uses previous cases to judge a later case

  • Statutory interpretation:
  • literal - how it’s written
  • golden
  • mischief - if a statue is contradictory
  • purposive - came from EU

  • Judicial reasoning terms
  • Stare Decisis - standing by previous decisions
  • Ground rules of ‘binding precedent’
  • Ratio decidendi - a binding precedent
  • Obiter Dicta - a persuasive precedent

  • A judge may (ROD):
  • reverse decision of a lower court
  • overrule principle of law from earlier case
  • distinguish facts in an earlier case

  • Alternatives to the court system to solving disputes (ADR - Alternative Dispute Resolution):
  • Arbitration - bring in a specialist to resolve it, called an arbitrator (who is independent and fair)
  • Mediation - third party acts as a messenger between two parties, called a mediator
  • Conciliation - like mediation, but the messenger offers solutions
  • Tribunals - extension of the court system that deal with public relations. Usually faster and cheaper

  • If you don’t need a court to resolve a dispute, use ADR (alternative dispute resolution)

Contract Law

  • A contract is a bargain between 2 or more people.
  • Buying a sandwich is technically a contract.
  • It’s intended to be legally binding and enforceable by law.
  • Agreements:
  • Written
  • Oral
  • Inferred by conduct

  • There are six criteria for a contract to be enforceable:
  1. An offer made by the promisor
  2. An acceptance of the offer by the promisee
  3. Consideration in the form of money or a promise to do or not do something
  4. Mutuality between parties to carry out the promises of the contract
  5. Capacity of both parties in mind and age
  6. Legality of terms and conditions
  • If this doesn’t make sense now, don’t worry; we’ll go over this.

  • Freedom to contract: parties are free to make their own contracts
  • Courts and statutes may imply terms into contracts
  • Businesses use standard forms of contracts

  • Contracts are everywhere

  • Bilateral contract: a promise made in return for a promise; each party must perform some action
  • Think of the “and” operator.
  • Example:
  • A person offers their home for sale, and a buyer agrees to pay $150,000 to purchase the home
  • (Buyer pays $150,000) && (A person gives away their home)
  • At first, they can seem unilateral, and they are, but as soon as one party starts performing their respective action, it becomes bilateral.

  • Unilateral contract: one party promises to perform some action.
  • Think of the “implies” operator.
  • Example:
  • “I will give £10 to the first person who buys me a cup of coffee”
  • (Buys a cup of coffee) → (Give £10)

  • Invitation to treat: asking for a negotiation
  • This phase includes all the pre-contractual stuff like asking about the product / service and all that.
  • Adverts and products on shelves usually fall under this category
  • Invitation to treat can become an offer.
  • Requesting information is not an offer (e.g. “how much is it?”)
  • However, if it’s now an offer, requesting information is capable of acceptance
  • Offer: asking to enter some kind of contract
  • This is the “yes” or “no” phase, where the contract will either terminate or accept.
  • Offer must be certain and not vague
  • Acceptance means accepting an offer and a contract is formed.
  • Acceptance must be a mirror image of the offer
  • A contract is formed immediately after an accepted offer
  • Carlill vs Carbolic Smoke Ball Co. (1893):
  • D advertised that they would pay £100 to anyone who caught the flu after using one of their smoke balls.
  • They deposited £1000 into the bank as evidence of their sincerity.
  • Mrs Carlill bought the smoke ball and caught the flu.
  • Decision: Advert was an offer to the whole world, and was a unilateral contract of “buy our ball and get flu” → “we give you £100”
  • Fisher vs Bell (1961):
  • A flick knife was on display by the shop window, being offered for sale.
  • Is this an offer or invitation to treat?
  • Decision: Invitation to treat, because pre-contractual discussions can still happen after the customer walks in.
  • However, because of the Restrictions of Offensive Weapons Act 1959 it was an offence to offer that flick knife for sale anyway.
  • Pharmaceutical Society of GB vs Boots Cash Chemist (1953):
  • A display on supermarket shelves is an invitation to treat
  • Customer makes an offer to buy the goods at the cash desk
  • The contract is completed when the cashier accepts the offer
  • Very similar to my existing example below
  • Partridge vs Crittenden (1965):
  • Advert for sale of a wild bird was not contrary to the Protection of Wild Birds Act - offering a wild bird for sale because:
  • Advert = invitation to treat
  • Harris vs Nickerson (1873):
  • A man saw an advert about a product being sold at an auction.
  • The man travelled all the way there to buy it.
  • The product was withdrawn from the auction, so the man got mad and sued, claiming the advert was an offer and that the product should’ve been sold.
  • Decision: Advert is an invitation to treat, not offer, so the man loses [citation]
  • Lefkowitz vs Great Minneapolis Surplus Stores (1957):
  • The defendant was selling coats. He put up an advert saying “first come first served”. A guy came in wishing to buy it, but the defendant refused and said it was only for women.
  • Decision: An advert can be considered an offer if it leaves absolutely no room for negotiation. If not, it’s an invitation to treat.
  • Harvey vs Facey (1893):
  1. H to F: ‘Will you sell us Bumper Hall Pen? Telegraph lowest cash price’
  2. F to H: ‘Lowest price for Bumper Hall Pen, £900’
  3. H to F: ‘We agree to buy Bumper Hall Pen for £900 asked by you’
  • Message #2 was a statement of price, not an offer to sell.
  • Termination of offer: when the transaction is no longer an offer
  • “An offer may be accepted at any point until it is terminated or revoked Dickinson v Dodds (1876)”
  • You can use words: “I don’t want to buy this Jotaro Kujo PVC figure anymore”
  • You can also use actions, for example, dying
  • Acceptance is also a termination of offer, but only acceptance leads to a complete contract.
  • A reliable third-party can be used to convey this message (like the post office).

  • The offeror can also terminate an offer, called a revocation.
  • It needs to be communicated to the offeree
  • To revoke a unilateral offer, the revocation information must be given the same prominence as the original offer
  • Hyde vs Wrench (1840):
  • W offered his farm for £1000
  • H negotiated and wanted £950
  • W refused
  • H said he would pay the full £1000
  • Decision: no contract; W had already rejected
  • Routledge vs Grant (1828):
  • G offered to buy R’s house and gave him 6 weeks to accept
  • G withdrew offer before 6 weeks up
  • Decision: G entitled to do so – he can withdraw his offer at any time until it has been accepted
  • Acceptance: both parties agree to the contract
  • Acceptance can only be made by the offeree (the shop owner can’t just say “you’re buying this” and force the contract)
  • There must be a positive action to trigger acceptance, like a “yes, I want to buy that”
  • Silence will usually not constitute a valid acceptance
  • Like termination of offer, a reliable third-party can be used to convey this message.
  • Acceptance is the second criteria required for a contract to be enforceable.
  • Battle of the forms:
  • A “battle of the forms” commences when two parties want to make a contract, each party wanting to form it on their own terms.
  • Usually this arises from A trying to buy goods from B, and A offering to buy them under A’s terms and B wanting to sell them under B’s terms.
  • Who wins? Do they duke it out in an epic battle?
  • No; the “one who shoots last” wins.
  • What does that mean? It means that each party suggests a terms and conditions until the last party suggests a terms and conditions such that no party objects to it.
  • Basically, they go back and forth suggesting terms and conditions until all parties are OK with it. So nobody really “loses”.
  • [citation, citation]
  • Bloom vs American Swiss Watch Co (1915):
  • Reward for information leading to arrest of jewel thief
  • Claimant gave information before he knew of reward
  • Claimant was not entitled to reward
  • Moral of the story: the offeree must know of the offer because they can accept it. You can’t just go “I didn’t know that; I did that already so I deserve the reward!”
  • Entores vs Miles Far Eastern Corp (1955):
  • C in London made offer to D in Amsterdam by telex
  • D in Amsterdam accepted offer and telexed C in London
  • With instantaneous forms of communication, the standard rule of acceptance being effective is when the recipient receives the acceptance message.
  • Basically, acceptance can be done remotely.
  • Adams vs Lindsell (1818):
  • D makes an offer to C on the 2nd but arrives at the 5th.
  • C posts acceptance on the 5th but doesn’t arrive until the 9th.
  • D sells goods to another party on the 8th, before C’s acceptance arrives.
  • Decision: acceptance happens upon posting the letter, not when the letter is received
  • Byrne vs Van Tienoven (1880):
  • 1st: D posts letter offering to sell goods
  • 8th: D posts letter withdrawing offer
  • 11th: C telegraphs accepting offer
  • 15th: C confirms acceptance by letter
  • 20th: C receives letter of revocation from D
  • Decision: Revocation can only take effect before acceptance, and since C received revocation after they accepted (even though it was posted before), the contract stands

  • The offeree must know of the offer before they can accept it

  • Example:
  • Invitation to treat: Seeing the tin of beans on the shelf with a price tag of £1. Customer asks staff “excuse me, how much is this tin of beans?”, staff says “uh... the price tag is right here, sir”, customer says “Oh! 😅 Thanks”
  • Offer: Customer goes to the checkout with the tin
  • Acceptance: Customer takes out cash to pay (that action can trigger an acceptance)
  • Contract complete: The cashier accepts the offer and the customer walks away with beans

  •  Termination of offer : The customer dies, or the customer tells the cashier that they don’t want to pay for it

  • What about electronic contracts?
  • Is an advert on a website an offer or an invitation to treat?
  • If an e-commerce site has a bug and accidentally set their prices a bit too low and people start bulk-buying everything, they can’t go back on their word; even after fixing the bug they have to go on with the contract. Does not apply if buyer knows this is a mistake or if the price is clearly wrong (see case below).

  • Chwee Kin Keong v Digilandmall.com (2004):
  • Six friends placed orders for 1,606 HP printers on a website.
  • The website had a bug: it was selling them for $66 each instead of $3,854 each
  • They basically earned a profit of $6,083,528
  • The friends argued that they were not aware that the price was a mistake, and the company argued that the friends took advantage of the mistake (which is a bit obvious; what group of friends buys 1,606 printers?).
  • Decision: the contract was void. They decided the friends should’ve known that the price was absurdly low [citation].

  • Agreement:
  • The vast majority of contract agreements are not and do not need to be in writing
  • Contracts are formed at the moment of reaching agreement – offer met with an acceptance - (assuming all other requirements are met)
  • Commercial organisations need to make sure that they do not become bound before they intend to

  • Include the words ‘subject to contract’ in correspondence (a legally recognised technique to avoid being bound too soon)
  • The purpose is to indicate that agreement has not been reached and any contract will not be concluded until a final written document is produced (and signed)
  • HOWEVER, starting action in the performance of the contract may lead to the conclusion that the ‘subject to contract’ stipulation has been waived

  • For a contract to be an enforceable legal relation, it needs to be stated as such
  • If not, we’ll assume it’s not

  • Simpkins vs Pays (1955):
  • Mrs Pays, her granddaughter and lodger enter into a competition each week.
  • They agree to share any prizes.
  • Entries are sent in Mrs P’s name.
  • One week they win £750. But Mrs P refuses to share money.
  • Decision: From facts there was an intention to enter into legal relations - Lodger entitled to 1/3rd of winnings.

  • People who are unable to enter certain types of contracts:
  • Minors
  • People with mental disabilities; incapacitated
  • Intoxicated people (usually not an excuse)

  • You can make contracts with minors, but there’s some extra ground rules:

  • Some contracts are illegal and are made void due to public policy or that they involve criminal actions

  • For a contract to be enforceable, there must be an exchange of consideration.
  • What is consideration?
  • Consideration: the exchange of one thing of value for another.
  • Consideration is the third criteria required for a contract to be enforceable.
  • Consideration can be used in both unilateral and bilateral contracts.
  • The law only cares that both considerations (things of value to be exchanged) are of some value; it doesn’t care if they’re of equal value. Basically, the law won’t protect you from being ripped off.
  • Even disposed items can be a legal consideration.

  • Past consideration: Consideration before a contract is completed is not adequate for a binding contract
  • Have you ever watched the film Aladdin?
  • Do you remember the scene where Genie takes Aladdin and Abu out of the Cave of Wonders before he actually wishes it? (It’s the first 20 seconds)
  • That’s an example of past consideration: Genie’s action was performed before the contract was made (before Aladdin accepted the contract by wishing).
  • Therefore, Genie cannot deduct a wish from Aladdin.

  • A party to a contract cannot use what they are required to do as a public duty as consideration in a contract.
  • However, if they do more than their public duty, that would be good consideration.

  • Contract variation (agreement to accept less): Part-payment of a debt will never be valid consideration. You can’t buy something for £1 with a 50p coin.
  • However, there are two exceptions:
  • If your part-payment is accompanied by another form of consideration, such as goods or services (you balance out what you can’t pay with something else)
  • If the payment had been given in a different form, time or place (be careful, this exception is subject to heavy scrutiny)
  • Contract variation (agreement to accept more):
  • Under the rule of the past case just below, an existing duty is good consideration in a contract variation if:
  • the variance is an offer to pay more
  • the offeror gains a practical benefit or obviates a “dis-benefit” by paying more
  • there is a lack of duress
  • Williams vs Roffey Bros (1990):
  • Building contractors were hired to work on flats
  • There was a penalty clause in the contract if the workers took too long doing the job
  • The initial contract price was too low and the customer didn’t want to hit the penalty clause so the customer agreed to pay them extra for each flat.
  • The customer only gave part-payments for each flat, claiming the contractors didn’t give “consideration” because they were already under a contractual duty to complete the work.
  • Decision: Consideration was provided, so customer needs to pay the rest.
  • The worker was working on the rooms so that was his existing "duty", and they were getting paid for it, then the contractor decided to pay more (to avoid some penalty clause), and the contractor's argument was that the workers didn't have consideration to make them dish out the full payments, in other words the contractors were basically saying that the workers need to do extra because they're paying them extra (which is a bit bs because the whole point of paying extra was so that the workers could finish their initial job)
  • Then after that case it was decided that if you're already doing a job (a duty) and the contract is undergoing variations, the existing job (duty) you're doing is good enough consideration (meaning you don't need to do anything extra) given that:
  • you're getting paid more (the variation is extra payments)
  • the payer gets some benefit or avoids some kind of trouble by paying more
  • there's no duress (no blackmail or anything like that)
  • Doctrine of Promissory Estoppel: The concept that a promise can be legally upheld after a promisee has suffered a loss as a result of relying on that promise.
  • I found an example, but it’s kind of long; check it out here if it’s still unclear.

  • Privity of Contract: only the parties within a contract may be sued / sue.
  • Exceptions:
  • Contract is made by agent in collateral contracts
  • Property is transferred in trust to another party
  • Contract has been made under an insurance agreement for the benefit of another
  • Restrictive covenants are imposed on property

  • Contracts (Rights Of Third Parties) Act 1999: if you’re not a party to a contract, you can still sue for your rights under the contract as long as:
  • the contract explicitly states your rights
  • the purpose of the contract is to benefit you

  • Terms and Representations:
  • Term: a “fact” within a contract
  • Includes:
  • Conditions
  • Warranties
  • Innominates (or intermediates)
  • Representation: an exaggeration or something that isn’t meant to be taken at face-value
  • For example, “Red Bull gives you wings” doesn’t mean it’ll actually give you wings; it’s a representation.
  • How can we tell the difference between term and representation?
  • We can distinguish them by looking at:
  • Terms that are meaningless and cannot be enforced
  • Importance of the statement
  • Special knowledge
  • Statement made in an assuring or promissory way
  • Verification

  • Two ways to make a contract:
  • Oral
  • Written
  • Making the contract is the first criteria required for a contract to be enforceable.
  • Methods of incorporating express terms into a contract:
  • Signature
  • Limitations:
  • Misrepresentation of document effect / extent
  • Document must be “contractual”
  • Doctrine of Non Est Factum (“Not my deed”) (basically someone who can’t read signing a contract)
  • Notice
  • First rule: Terms must be contained in “contractual” document
  • Second rule: Reasonable notice of the terms must be given at or before the time the contract is made
  • Custom - a consistent course of dealing

  • Sometimes, we can’t explicitly state every single term in a contract.
  • Therefore some terms need to be implied.
  • Implied terms are usually ones aimed at protecting the party with the weaker bargaining power.
  • Terms are implied into contracts by statutes (e.g. the Sale of Goods Act (SoGA) 1979, Unfair Contract Terms Act (UCTA) 1977 etc.)

  • Exclusion (exemption) & Limitation clauses: clauses that seek to limit or exclude (exempt) a liability that would otherwise exist.
  • Basically, it’s like a “patch” that prevents some unwanted hacky back-door situation that basically breaks the contract.
  • It must:
  • clearly express cover of the situation it seeks to exclude
  • not be ambiguous
  • be reasonable
  • not break any other existing statutes
  • They may also be implied

  • Photo Production v Securicor Transport (1980)
