  • Securicor entered contract to guard Photo Productions Factory
  • There was an exclusion clause that exempted Securicor from any damages by one of its employees (so if Securicor knocked over a vase or something, they wouldn’t get in trouble).
  • However, one of Securicor's guards deliberately set fire to the factory!
  • Because of that exclusion clause, Securicor didn’t get in trouble.
  • The guard probably did, though.

  • Unfair Contracts Terms Act 1977
  • This Act governs the use of exclusion clauses
  • It stops exclusion clauses from excluding liability for death or personal injury due to the other party’s negligence
  • So, basically, Securicor can burn down factories but they can’t kill or hurt anyone.
  • In other words, if a company kills someone or really hurts them, they can’t get away scott free using an exclusion clause.
  • To test if an exclusion clause is reasonable, it undergoes the “Reasonableness Test”.

  • Restraint clauses
  • Contracts of employment: Employees cannot reveal employer trade secrets and cannot work for a competing firm when they leave.
  • Contracts for the sale of business: A seller cannot set up competition with their buyer.
  • Solus agreements: A seller with a supplier can only get products solely from that supplier (no cheating on them)

  • Only valid if a person seeking to enforce it can show if the restraint is reasonable
  • e.g. if you were working for a government defence agency, they could stop you from working globally
  • Points to reasonableness:
  • Whether the business interest is one that can be protected
  • Length of time restraint lasts
  • Width of the geographical area the restraint covers

  • Factors that can invalidate contracts:
  • Misrepresentation
  • Duress (threats, blackmail etc.)
  • Mistakes
  • Illegality
  • Undue influence (one party is under the influence of the other, like parent and child)

  • Misrepresentation
  • A misrepresentation is where:
  • there is a false statement of material fact
  • it is known to the representee
  • it must be intended to be acted upon...
  • ... or it must have been acted upon already
  • It’s not enough to find something that’s false; the statement needs to have been acted on too (or intended to be acted upon)

  • Did the person making the statement have special knowledge or simply pass on false information?
  • Was the statement important to the innocent party?
  • Did the person making the statement invite the innocent party to verify the truth of the statement?
  • Was statement one of fact or opinion?
  • Did the statement induce the innocent party to enter the contract?
  • Was the statement one of genuine intentions?
  • Did the statement become untrue before the contract is concluded?

  • Half truths: when you only say half of the truth and neglect to say the other, very important, half
  • Statement of law cannot give rise to misrepresentation
  • Silence and Non Disclosure: you’re not making a representation, however a gesture could be representation

  • Bisset vs Wilkinson (1927)
  • Buyer wanted to buy some land for a sheep farm
  • Buyer: How much sheep can I hold?
  • The seller never used it as a sheep farm, so they guessed.
  • Seller: I don’t know, about 2000?
  • The buyer buys it and finds out it can’t hold 2000 sheep.
  • The buyer sues the seller for misrepresentation, but since it was a statement of opinion and not fact, it wasn’t misrepresentation.

  • Aprilia World Service vs Spice Girls Ltd:
  • Spice Girls Ltd promised to promote Aprilia World Service in return for a sponsorship on a world tour.
  • Before the contract was signed, Geri Halliwel told everyone she was leaving.
  • They didn’t tell Aprilia World Service.
  • Geri left 3 weeks after the contract was signed.
  • Aprilia World Service would not have entered the contract if they knew Geri was leaving.
  • Turns out the participation in the promotion amounted to a misrepresentation by conduct: they should’ve told Aprilia World Service that Geri was leaving.

  • Contract terminology:
  • VOID: a contract is void if it no longer has any legal effect and is not recognised as a contract anymore
  • VOIDABLE: the contract is still valid, but the injured party can choose whether to:
  • enforce the contract (and will continue to be legally enforceable)
  • or avoid the contract (then it will be void)
  • UNENFORCEABLE: it may be a legal contract, but it’s not legally recognised until the other party carries out their side of the bargain

  • Types of misrepresentation:
  • Fraudulent: you know the statement is false, but you make the false statement anyway
  • Negligent: if you make a statement you believe to be true, but have no actual proof of it
  • Innocent: you are mistaken; you make a false statement in the mistaken belief that it was true

  • Remedies & Damages for misrepresentation:
  • So you have misrepresentation. What happens?
  • If fraudulent or negligent, the contract could be made voidable (not void straight away)

  • Misrepresentation Act 1967:
  • Where a person has entered into a contract, after a misrepresentation and
  • as a result they have suffered a loss...
  • ... they can claim damages even though the misrepresentation had not been made fraudulently...
  • ... unless the party making the statement proves that the misrepresentation was made innocently (thought it was true upon making the contract)

  • Mistakes:
  • Common: both parties make the same mistake
  • e.g. the subject matter perishes, and both parties still think the subject matter hasn’t perished (relevant to fresh goods like fish or meat)
  • For non-perishable goods, it could be a common mistake that the goods actually exist
  • Mutual: the two parties are at cross-purposes with each other (they do not understand each other because the parties are talking about different things without realising it)
  • Example:
  • Seller: Wanna buy product A?
  • Buyer: Ooh, product B looks like
  • Seller: So, how about it? Wanna buy it?
  • Buyer: Sure!
  • Mutual mistake: seller thinks buyer wants to buy A, buyer thinks they’re buying B. Purchase contract is voidable.
  • Unilateral: one party is mistaken and the other party knows they’re mistaken
  • If the mistake relates to the fundamental core of the contract, it can be voided
  • Mistake as to identity:
  • Mutual mistake as to identity: a mistake on the identity of the subject matter
  • Common mistake as to identity: a mistake on the identity of the other party
  • Not really a problem if parties meet face-to-face, but can be a problem if they meet at a distance (online, post etc.)

  • Duress and Undue Influence:
  • If one party is forced or “subject to undue influence” into a contract, it is voidable.
  • Duress refers to the actions that force a party into a contract, including:
  • Violence
  • Economic pressure (e.g. debt, or any kind of contract agreement after extortion)
  • Undue influence: one party is under the influence of another
  • Child - Parent
  • Client - Solicitor
  • Patient - Doctor
  • Husband - Wife (any sort of intimate relationship cuts both ways)

  • Illegality:
  • Types of contracts that are immediately void (and illegal):
  • Contracts to commit a crime or tort (e.g. assassination)
  • Contracts damaging to foreign relations
  • Contracts to promote corruption in public life
  • Contracts to defraud the treasury (e.g. tax fraud)

  • Bringing a contractual agreement to an end:
  • Discharge of Contract
  • Four ways to discharge a contract:

  • Agreement: both parties agree to discharge the contract
  • Performance: both parties have “completed their job”
  • Exceptions:
  • Substantial performance (not done a good enough job)
  • Divisible contracts (if only part of the contract is complete, you can split the contract into smaller contracts, e.g. something being delivered on a regular basis)
  • Acceptance of partial completion by the other party (if part of the contract is completed by one side, and that side expects something in return for that partial completion)
  • Prevention of completion by the other party (if one party wants to stop the other party half-way through their “job”, they are still entitled to full payment)
  • Frustration: contract becomes impossible or illegal to perform, by no fault of either party (because that would be a breach)
  • Frustrating events:
  • Destruction of subject matter (e.g. you order hardware parts, but then they are destroyed)
  • Personal service not possible (e.g. commission music artists to play guitar, but then they break their arm)
  • Common purpose of contract does not happen (Krell vs Henry is a good example)
  • Subsequent illegality (if something happens that makes the contract illegal to perform, e.g. trading with countries in war)
  • Government intervention (government basically stops you)
  • Breach: one party has failed to comply, even with obligation under the contract
  • It’s possible to continue with the contract if the innocent party drops charges
  • If the innocent party can prove their case, they will always be able to claim damages.
  • The party who failed to comply is liable for damages
  • If it’s severe, the contract will be repudiated (come to an end) + damages
  • Repudiation: where one party makes it clear they don’t want to be a part of the contract anymore

  • Remedies for Breach (what can you sue for)
  • Damages (most common remedy, and must be quantified to reflect the losses)
  • Types of damages:
  • Compensatory
  • Nominal
  • Restitutionary
  • Punitive (Exemplary, related to public policy)
  • Damages may be based on expectation/performance losses or reliance losses
  • Remoteness of damage:
  • Damages must not be too remote
  • Losses must be critical enough to naturally arise as a normal consequence of the breach
  • Losses must be a reasonable contemplation of the parties at the time when the contract was formed as being a probable consequence of a breach of contract (if you knew the party was going to do that when you formed the contract and you would’ve seen that as a breach, it’s severe enough to be damages)
  • Action for agreed contract price
  • Quantum meruit (as much as they have earned)
  • Specific performance (do something in return)
  • Injunction (enforces that they do what they didn’t want to do)
  • Repudiation (end the contract)
  • Hadley vs Baxendale (1854):
  • Crankshaft of mill broke
  • C got D to go and fix it and bring it back
  • D was neglectful and brought it back 7 days late
  • C couldn’t use the mill for those 7 days so C sued for loss of profit
  • Decision: loss of profit is too remote, D had no idea the mill wouldn’t be running while the crankshaft was gone
  • Equitable Remedies
  • Equitable remedies are discretionary, granted by the court if it is fair in all the circumstances to do so.
  • Basically, it’s when the court does something to ease a dispute if legal remedies or monetary compensation won’t cut it.
  • Equitable remedies may be awarded when damages would not adequately compensate the innocent party.
  • Injunctions: courts may direct a party not to take actions in breach of their contractual obligations.
  • Rectification: courts may order rectification of the contract so that the written contract is changed to accurately reflect the parties' intentions.
  • Specific performance: courts may order the party in breach of contract to perform their obligations under the contract (Moutford v Scott). They are generally used in contracts involving unique items.
  • Time Limits
  • Under the Limitation Act 1980, an action under a simple contract must be made within six years from the date when the right to the action arose.
  • There is no statutory provision for time limits to claim under the equitable remedies – however, being equitable, they must be sought within a reasonable time.

Tort Law

  • Criminal Law: Laws promulgated through institutions of (national) governance and primarily about punishing people who have committed recognised wrongs in that governed sphere (basically catching bad guys).
  • Civil Law: The law applied by the civil courts in the UK. Laws that regulate the dealings between private citizens that are not subject to interference by the state (divisions include the law of contract, torts, and trusts) (basically like the Mediators from Xenoblade X).
  • Tort: a civil wrong other than relating to a contract, e.g. personal injury, damage to property resulting from negligence, protecting against defamation of character, preserving personal freedom, enjoyment of property, commercial interests

  • Tort law is about protecting claimant’s rights and interests
  • Courts are also concerned about balancing the proactive risk analysis and practical reactive defences to risk management
  • Main remedy: compensatory damages

  • Claimant: the person bringing the claim
  • Defendant: the person against whom the claim is brought
  • Tortfeasor: the person who actually committed the tort (not always the defendant)

  • Ideally a tort case would go as follows:
  • C receives damages from D
  • C is the injured (wronged) claimant
  • D is the injurer (wrongdoer) defendant
  • Damages are paid corresponding to C’s loss

  • Tort of negligence: a tort in which a breach of a duty of care results in damage to the person to whom the duty is owed
  • Four elements of negligence claim:
  1. A duty of care is owed by tortfeasor
  2. That duty of care is breached
  3. The breach was the cause of the damage
  4. The damage is not too remote from the breach
  • A negligence claim will only be actionable if all four elements are present!

Element #1: A duty of care is owed by tortfeasor

  • Duty: some kind of responsibility that the tortfeasor owes the claimant
  • Duty of care: the level of care that the tortfeasor owes the claimant over some duty
  • That’s cool and all, but how do we actually know if someone owes someone else a duty of care?
  • Donoghue vs Stevenson (1932):
  • C’s friend bought her a bottle of ginger beer manufactured by D.
  • C drank part of it and as she topped up the glass the remains of a decomposed snail came out.
  • C became ill and sued D.
  • Decision: C was a customer to D’s product, so a customer like C was foreseeable to D, meaning D had a duty of care to C which was breached. D was liable to C.

  • Lord Atkin’s principle: people must take reasonable care not to injure others who could foreseeably be affected by their action or inaction
  • “Who, in law, is my neighbour?”
  • Those so closely and directly affected that I ought to have them in contemplation
  • Basically, your “neighbours” are people whom you can recall and contemplate before doing any sort of legal hoo-hah.
  • You don’t owe a duty of care to someone who is so distant you’d never even think of them.
  • It relates to close and direct relations.
  • Every person owes a duty of care to their neighbour.

  • If a duty has been established, then it’s assumed that there’s a duty of care too.
  • It’s fun to roast and sue someone for negligence, but remember that no liability for negligence is recognised unless there is a pre-existing duty to take care.
  • Basically, there has to be some kind of duty to be negligent of.
  • Carelessness is a part of ordinary life: humans aren’t perfect. We can’t sue someone for being human.
  • Human Rights Act 1998 - the court must consider the ECHR when determining whether to extend the duty of care in new situations concerning public bodies.

  • The 3-stage test of Duty of Care originated from Caparo vs Dickman (1990):

  • Home Office vs Dorset Yacht Co (1970):
  • Boys from a borstal (youth custody centre) were taken on a trip to Brownsea Island.  They escaped one night and in the process damaged a yacht belonging to Dorset Yacht Co.
  • The Home Office owed a duty of care to the claimants.
  • Due to the custodial nature of the boys confinement, their supervising officers were under a (proximate) public duty ensure the boys did not escape.  
  • The damage caused to the claimants’ property was reasonably foreseeable if the boys did escape
  • To be honest, this one’s a bit debatable because how would the Home Office know that the boys would smash up a yacht if they were to escape? Anyway, that’s what the slides say.

  • There’s more past cases about proximity:
  • Donoghue vs Stevenson (1932)
  • Evans vs Triplex Safety Glass Co Ltd (1936)
  • ... and ‘fair, just and reasonable’:
  • Hill vs Chief Constable of West Yorkshire (1989)
  • CBS Songs Ltd vs Amstrad Consumer Electronics (1988)

Element #2: Duty of care is breached

  • Did the defendant act with the degree of care and skill expected from the reasonable person or competent professional?
  • Basically, were they being stupid enough to breach their duty of care?
  • There is an objective standard of care test used in these cases:
  • Nettleship v Weston [1971] 2 QB 691
  • Mansfield v Weetabix [1997] EWCA Civ 1352 Court of Appeal
  • Mullin v Richards [1998] 1 WLR 1304
  • Orchard v. Lee (1932) EWCA 295    
  • Evans v Triplex Safety Glass Co Ltd (1936)
  • There’s also a test of experience, skill and judgement test:
  • Philips v Whitely Ltd (1938)
  • Condon v Basi [1985] 1 WLR 866 Court of Appeal
  • West Bromwich Albion Football Club Ltd v. El Safty (2006)
  • Wilsher v Essex Area Health Authority [1988] 1 AC 1074

  • How do you judge professionals?
  • Bolam vs Friern Hospital (1957):
  • Basically, the doctor was not in breach of duty.
  • However, from this case the House of Lords created the Bolam test:
  • "a medical professional is not guilty of negligence if he has acted in accordance with a practice accepted as proper by a responsible body of medical men skilled in that particular art . . . Putting it the other way round, a man is not negligent, if he is acting in accordance with such a practice, merely because there is a body of opinion who would take a contrary view."
  • Basically, you’re not negligent if you’re doing everything you’re supposed to and a board of nerds tell you you’re doing fine.
  • What if the method used by the “board of nerds” actually came from the defendant themselves?
  • In that case, it must be demonstrated that the method was based on logic and was defensible. This was done in Bolitho vs City & Hackney Health Authority (1997).

  • The balance of reasonable risk taking:
  • How can you tell if a taken risk was reasonable?
  • There’s some attributes you can use to help make a decision:
  • Probability of harm being caused to claimant
  • Bolton vs Stone (1951):
  • C injured by cricket ball - hit 100 yards over fence.
  • Happened 6 times in 30 years.
  • D not liable because 17 foot fence reasonable in circumstances.
  • Potential magnitude of harm likely to be caused to the claimant
  • Paris v Stepney [1951] AC 367
  • Haley v London Electricity Board (1965)
  • Wagon Mound No.2 1967 1 AC 617
  • The reasonableness and cost of taking precautions to prevent the harm
  • Latimer v AEC [1953] AC 643
  • The social utility of what the defendant was attempting to achieve
  • Watt v Hertfordshire [1954] 1 WLR 835

Element #3: Breach was the cause of the damage

  • To test if damage was caused by the breach, we do the “but for” test.
  • It’s a bit flawed, but it’s still used.
  • It goes like this: “But for the existence of X, would Y have occurred?” If the answer is yes, then X is an actual cause of Y.
  • Barnett vs Chelsea & Kensington HMC (1968):
  • C went to hospital complaining of vomiting but was sent home by the hospital doctor.
  • Later that night C died  (someone had put arsenic in his tea).
  • Hospital was not liable for negligence.  
  • 2 elements were satisfied -  Doctor owed a duty of care & breached that duty.
  • BUT final element was not present: C’s death was not as a result of breach as C would have died anyway – there was no antidote.

Element #4: Damage is not too remote from breach

  • The egg shell skull rule: the defendant must take the claimant as they find them.
  • Essentially, the frailty of the person who was injured cannot be used as a defense to limit the liability of the at-fault party [citation].
  • It was used in the following past cases:
  • Smith vs Leech Brain (1962)
  • Page vs Smith (1996)
  • Lagden vs O’Connor (2003)

  • It’s not all doom and gloom for the defendant; there are a variety of defences they can use too:
  • Illegality (the other person was doing something illegal when they were injured)
  • Consent (the other person acknowledged risk, either explicitly or implicitly)
  • Contributory negligence (claims that both parties are at fault, and the defendant will have their damages reduced)
  • Necessity (their actions prevented a greater harm, so their actions were reasonable under the circumstances)

Other Tort Law stuff

  • Remedies:
  • Remedies include damages and injunctions.
  • Damages awarded for personal injury include compensation for direct and indirect losses.
  • The aim is to place the injured party in the position he/she was before the tort had been committed.
  • Injunctions are orders from the court to prevent a party from performing a certain action.
  • Injunctions are used to prevent the commission of a tort (and is available at the discretion of the courts).
  • Injunctions are issued on the basis of the particular tort and the injunction may be prohibitory; mandatory; or interim.

  • It’s not only physical injury: this can apply to economic loss, too, in these cases:
  • Weller v. Foot and Mouth Research Institute (1966)
  • Spartan Steel v Martin & Co Contractors Ltd (1973)

  • Psychiatric injury, too, such as nervous shock:
  • Primary Victims:
  • Dulieu v White (1901)
  • Page v Smith (1995)
  • Rescuers:
  • Chadwick v British Rail (1967)
  • White v Chief Constable of South Yorkshire (1999)
  • Here’s a cool flow chart:

  • What are the requirements for being a secondary victim of a psychiatric injury?
  • A close tie of love and affection
  • Geographic proximity to the accident or its aftermath
  • Medically recognised psychiatric illness
  • This was applied in the cases:
  • McLoughlin v O’Brian (1982)
  • Alcock v Chief Constable of South Yorkshire (1991)

  • Let’s talk more about economic loss.
  • How do you recover from an economic loss?
  • When the loss is linked to physical damage / loss, then it’s recoverable.
  • However, actions will be allowed where a special relationship of proximity exists between the parties.

  • Hedley Byrne & Co Ltd vs Heller & Partners Ltd (1964):
  • Hedley Byrne (a firm) were considering whether to extend credit to a customer, Easipower. Hedley Byrne approached Easipower’s bank Heller & Partners for reassurance as to the credit worthiness of Easipower. Heller & Partners described Easipower’s financial position as they have enough resources for ordinary business proceedings, but stated that the report was given "without responsibility." On the basis of this information Hedley Byrne extended credit to Easipower.  Easipower went out of business and Hedley Byrne sued Heller & Partners.
  • Did Heller & Partners owe Hedley Byrne a duty of care?
  • Basically, the events went like this:
  • Hedley: Is Easipower worth extending credit to?
  • Heller: Yeah, they’re good, I think.
  • *Hedley extends credit to Easipower*
  • *Easipower goes out of business*
  • Hedley: wtf you told me they were good
  • Heller: 🤷‍♂️
  • Well? Are you dying to hear the answer?
  • What? No? You’re not on the edge of your seat to know the conclusion to this epic, thrilling case study?
  • The answer is no, Heller did not owe Hedley a duty of care.
  • This is because the report specifically stated that it was given “without responsibility”.
  • However, they recognised that a duty of care could exist:
  • A “special relationship” must exist between the parties (duty).
  • The (mis)statement was untrue, inaccurate, or misleading.
  • The person making the (mis)statement acted negligently in making the statement. (breach)
  • The other party relied on (mis)statement and it was reasonable for them to do so. (causation)
  • The reliance must have been detrimental to the other party  in the sense that damages resulted. (reasonable foreseeability)

  • Caparo Industries PLC vs Dickman (1990):
  • Caparo Industries purchased shares in Fidelity Plc, a company. In doing so they relied on the accounts prepared for Fidelity, which stated that the company had made a pre-tax profit of £1.3M.
  • In fact Fidelity had made a loss of over £400,000.
  • Caparo Industries brought an action against the auditors Dickman claiming they were negligent in certifying the accounts.
  • Did Dickman owe Caparo Industries a duty of care?
  • Summary:
  • Caparo: *buys shares in Fidelity*
  • Caparo: How much did you make?
  • Fidelity (Dickman): £1.3M
  • Caparo: oooh goody
  • *Caparo loses money*
  • Caparo: wtf
  • How about this time? Surely yes, right?
  • No! There was not sufficient proximity between Caparo and the auditors since the auditors were not aware of the existence of Caparo nor the purpose for which the accounts were being used by them.
  • Basically, there’s too much distance between Caparo and the auditors. They had no idea Caparo even existed, let alone use their accounts to gauge their profit.
  • But from this they did make the Caparo test to determine duty of care in negligence:
  • The harm or loss must be reasonably foreseeability
  • there a relationship of "proximity" or "neighbourhood"
  • and it must be fair, just and reasonable

  • For pure economic loss, the Unfair Contract Terms Act 1977 comes into play too, in these cases:
  • Smith v Eric Bush (1989)
  • James McNaughton Paper Group Ltd -v- Hicks Anderson & Co [1991] 1 All ER 134,
  • Yorkshire Enterprise Ltd v Robson Rhodes, unreported (1998) (QBD).
  • Here’s another cool chart:

Employment Law

  • The structure of the court system as it relates to employment law:
  • Supreme court
  • → Court of Appeal
  • → Employment appeal tribunal
  • → employment tribunal

  • Employees and independent contractors:
  • Contracts of service: employees / employee shareholders
  • Contracts for services: independent contractors

  • Tests to determine status:
  • Control test: is a person subject to the orders of the employer?
  • Integration test: is the work done as an integral part of the business?
  • Economic reality test: how far is a person in business on his own account?
  • Mutuality of obligations test: is the employer obligated to provide work and the employee obligated to accept it?
  • Multiple test

  • The multiple test:
  • Does the person have to turn up to work when expected?
  • If YES...
  • Do they have to do what the organisation tells them to?
  • If YES...
  • Are they expected to do it personally?
  • If YES...
  • Can they send someone else to do the work?
  • If NO...
  • Then they are an employee

  • Dismissal from employment:
  • Summary Dismissal: the employee is fired immediately with no warning or notice. Usually because employee performed an act of gross misconduct (did something really wrong).
  • Wrongful Dismissal: the employee was fired, where the termination was a breach of the contract of employment or some law (basically, you were fired illegally).
  • Constructive Dismissal: employer commits a fundamental breach of contract of employment, so the employee must resign because of the breach
  • Unfair Dismissal: The reasons for the dismissal, or the way that it was handled by the employer, was unfair

  • Potentially fair reasons for dismissal:
  • Capability
  • Conduct
  • Redundancy
  • Statutory bar
  • Some other substantial reason

  • Polkey v Dayton (1932):
  • An employer wanted to make an employee redundant, but did not consult him as was required
  • The employee claimed unfair dismissal
  • The employer argued that consultation would have made no difference to his dismissal
  • Decision: the employer’s argument was irrelevant, and the dismissal was unfair purely because of a lack of procedure. It doesn’t matter if the consultation wouldn’t have made a difference or not; they should’ve told them.

  • Equality Act 2010: protected characteristics:
  • age
  • disability
  • gender reassignment
  • marriage and civil partnership
  • pregnancy and maternity
  • race
  • religion or belief
  • sex
  • sexual orientation

  • Conduct seen as discriminatory by law:
  • Direct discrimination: discriminated against under one of the protected characteristics
  • Combined / Dual discrimination: discriminated against under two or more of the protected characteristics
  • Indirect discrimination: having a policy or practice which is applied equally to everyone, but with which it is more difficult for people of a particular protected characteristic to comply, and which cannot be justified.
  • Harassment: unwanted conduct related to a protected characteristic (other than marriage and civil partnership, and pregnancy and maternity) that has the purpose of violating a person's dignity or creating an intimidating, hostile, degrading, humiliating or offensive environment for that person [citation]
  • Associative discrimination: discriminated against because of someone else that he is associated with (e.g. discriminating against you because you have a gay friend)
  • Victimisation: Treating someone badly because they have done a ‘protected act’ (or because you believe that a person has done or is going to do a protected act) [citation]
  • Protected acts:
  • Making a claim or complaint of discrimination (under the Equality Act).
  • Helping someone else to make a claim by giving evidence or information.
  • Making an allegation that you or someone else has breached the Act.
  • Doing anything else in connection with the Act.
  • Perceptive discrimination: discriminated against because people perceive, or believe that he has the protected characteristic (but they don’t actually have to have it, e.g. if you look gay but aren’t but are still discriminated).

  • Occupational requirements:
  • Where being of aparticular sex, race, disability, religion or belief, sexual orientation, or age, or not being a trans, married, or a civil partner is an essential requirement for the work that is to be done
  • The requirement must be crucial to the post
  • It must not be a sham or pretext
  • Applying the requirement must be proportionate so as to achieve a legitimate aim
  • Examples:
  • An actor fulfiling a role with a certain age / sex / race
  • A penis model
  • A, uh... test subject for a new wheelchair for paraplegics (I don’t know, these are hard to come up with)

  • London Underground vs Edwards (1995):
  • E was a single parent with a young child. She worked as an underground train driver. Her employer announced a new shift system, which made it very difficult for her because of her child.
  • This was indirect discrimination. The ‘pool’ of comparison was all the other underground drivers to whom the new rota applied.
  • 100% of men could comply, but only 95% of women could.
  • This impacted more on women, and so the new rota was discriminatory.

  • Disability in law:
  • acceptable to treat a disabled person more favourable
  • impairment has a substantial and long-term effect on ability to carry out tasks
  • disability can be mental or physical and last longer than 12 months
  • Discrimination airising from disability: treated not favourably, not because of the disability itself, but because of an effect of it; a consequence of the disability.

  • Health and safety at work:
  • Health and Safety at Work Act 1974
  • Employers have to provide a safe and healthy place for their employees, workers and self-employed people
  • Safety regulations are enforced by the Health and Safety Executive and local authorities.

  • Civil law:
  • People who are injured or who have become ill because of their working environment or practices, may bring court action
  • Law of Negligence: Employers owe all employees a general duty of care in respect of their health and safety at work.

Industrial Law

  • I’m assuming Company Law and Directors Responsibilities, GDPR and Intellectual Property and Equality and Diversity Law; International cf UK Law are all encompassed in Industrial law because I can’t find slides for it.

Legal Personality

  • Under English Law every natural person has a legal personality from birth until death.
  • Individuals have complex rights and duties under the legal system determined by their actions and their current status in life.
  • Some artificial persons can also have a legal personality.

Business Organisations

  • Sole trader: one person unincorporated business
  • Ordinary (general) partnership: the partners have unlimited legal liability for debts. Partners share losses and profits
  • Limited Liability Partnership (LLP): has a separate legal personality and legal liability of partners is limited (basically the company is separate from the persons involved)
  • A limited company (Ltd): has a separate legal personality. Legal liability of shareholders is limited to a paid up value of their shares

Partnerships

  • Partnership Act 1890:
  • Section 1 - Definition of Partnership:
  • (1) Partnership is the relation which subsists between persons carrying on a business in common with a view of profit.
  • (2) But the relation between members of any company or association which is—
  • [(a) registered under the Companies Act 2006, or]
  • (b) Formed or incorporated by or in pursuance of any other Act of Parliament or letters patent, or Royal Charter...
  • ... is not a partnership within the meaning of this Act.
  • What does this even mean?
  • It means two entities in business can “partner up” and aspire for more profits, as long as the partnership wasn’t formed by any other act (such as the Companies Act 2006).

Companies

  • Company: a succession or collection of persons having at law an existence, right and duties, separate and distinct from those persons who are from time to time, its members.
  • A company incorporated under English law can normally be recognised from the suffix Limited, Ltd. or PLC, Plc.
  • Other countries / jurisdictions have different suffices, e.g. Inc., Corp., AG, S.A., N.V., B.V., etc.
  • An incorporated company:
  • Is a persona at law – an artificial, not a natural, person;
  • It has a separate legal entity – it can sue at law and be sued in its own right;
  • It has perpetual succession – its existence is maintained by the constant succession of new persons who replace those who die or are in some other way removed.

  • Limited company: A company is limited if the liability of its members is limited by its constitution.
  • There are two ways a company can be limited:
  • Limited by shares: Members liability is limited to the amount, if any, unpaid on the shares held by them (the owners are legally responsible for the debts, but only to the extent of the amount they invested in the company itself)
  • Limited by guarantee: Members liability is limited to such amount as the members undertake to contribute to the assets of the company in the event of its being wound up (usually used for non-profit organisations, the members agree to contribute an amount specified in the articles in the event of the company winding up, or being brought to an end)
  • If there is no limit on the liability of its members, the company is an “unlimited company”

  • Public company: a company limited by shares or by guarantee and having a share capital, whose certificate of incorporation states that it is a public company, which has complied with the requirements of the Act as to registration as a public company (stocks and stuff can be bought freely on the stock exchange)
  • Private company: a company that is not a public company (yes, the slides really say that)

  • A public company may be listed, i.e. listed by the UK Listing Authority which is part of the Financial Services Authority and admitted to trading on a regulated market such as the main market of the London Stock Exchange, or it may be an unlisted public company.
  • Basically, a “listed company” is on the stock exchange and stuff. An “unlisted company” isn’t.

Intellectual Property

  • Intellectual Property (IP) refers to things that are creations of the mind.
  • It provides ownership rights to the creators of works, and inventions.
  • IP can be owned in a similar way to physical property.
  • IP gives the creators the right to control the use of their work/mark/invention/design and use it to gain financial reward.
  • An IP doesn’t have to be a product; it could be a series or a franchise or something.

  • Types of IP:
  • Copyright: an automatic right
  • Copyright law is governed by the Copyright, Designs and Patents Act (CDPA) 1988 (as amended) that protects original materials including literary, dramatic, musical, artistic works, and typographical arrangements, produced by its owner.
  • Copyright is an automatic right and need not be applied for (but proof may be needed to establish ownership).
  • If you get it automatically, how do you know if you have copyright or not?
  • A copyright holder is entitled to protection where the work:
  • Is of a type protected by the CDPA 1988;
  • Has been produced in some tangible form;
  • Satisfies the requirement of originality; and
  • The owner/creator is a British citizen and/or the work
  • was first published in the UK.
  • The copyright must be expressed and fixed (such as written down), therefore ideas and thoughts are not copyright protected.
  • Creations in which copyright will exist:
  • Literary works – books, computer software programmes
  • etc;
  • Music and broadcasts – films, videos etc;
  • Artistic works – drawings, diagrams, logos etc.
  • Typological arrangements of published editions.
  • The owner’s legal rights enable him/her to:
  • Copy and distribute copies of the work to the public
  • Perform, show or play the work in public
  • Broadcast the work or include it in a cable programme service;
  • Make an adaptation of the work
  • Under the Artist’s Resale Rights Regulations 2006, an artist has the right (resale right) to a percentage of the selling price (resale royalty).
  • Moral rights:
  • Protection against the distortion of the owner’s work;
  • In relation to literary, dramatic, artistic or musical works, he/she has the right to be recognised as the author of the work whenever it is performed commercially or in public;
  • Literary, dramatic, artistic or musical works may not be falsely attributed to an author;
  • Where an undertaking has been made to make a film or take photographs for private consumption, he/she may not show or broadcast this to the public.
  • Depending on the form, copyright can exist for various periods of time.
  • Enforcement takes place when a case is brought to civil court.
  • Primary Infringement:
  • A substantial part of the work is copied.
  • It doesn’t consider the perpetrator’s motive or knowledge of the copyright’s existence
  • Infringement occurs when one or more of the exclusive ‘legal’ rights of the owner has been breached.
  • Secondary Infringement:
  • The defendant didn’t directly infringe the copyright, but they knowingly contributed to it.
  • For example, if the defendant provided another party with copyrighted material and they performed direct infringement [citation].
  • Criminal offences:
  • Offering copyrighted stuff for sale or hire
  • Imports copyrighted stuff for their own private or domestic use
  • Possess copyrighted stuff in business with intent to infringe
  • If found guilty, the defendant may be liable, on summary conviction, to imprisonment for a period not exceeding six months.
  • Where goods are imported into the UK, the owner may give notice in writing to the Commissioners of Customs and Excise that he/she is the owner of the copyright in published literary, dramatic or musical work; or the owner of copyright in a sound recording or film, and requests that the Commissioners treat the copies as prohibited goods.
  • Copyright is an automatic right, but it must be in permanent form (written, recorded etc.)
  • Duration:
  • Literary, dramatic, musical and artistic works: life plus 70 years (‘Sir Cliff’s law’).
  • Sound recordings and broadcasts: 50 years from first broadcast.
  • Typographical editions: 25 years from first publication.
  • Patents: an exclusive right given to an owner of an invention to make use of and exploit their invention for a maximum of 20 years.
  • Protection is granted to a patentable invention which can be:
  • a new product or way of making a product
  • a process that gives a new technical solution to a problem.
  • A patent must be registered
  • An example would be Dyson or Vienetta
  • Components of a patent:
  • Sharing innovation
  • Public interest
  • Monopoly
  • Encouraging innovation
  • Rights do not arise automatically - formal procedure
  • Properties of a patent:
  • A patented invention must be proven as novel and of industrial application.
  • The patent must be registered.
  • Registration prevents others from using or selling the product without permission.
  • The protection lasts for an initial four-year period (after which it can be renewed annually to a maximum of 20 years).
  • The owner of a patent is provided with a monopoly right to control the item.
  • Mechanisms exist where a person may request from the Comptroller-General to license a patented invention (after three years following the grant of the patent).
  • Licences, which may attract payment of royalties, can be sold to transfer exclusive or non-exclusive rights.
  • Essential elements for a patent:
  • Be capable of industrial application
  • Involve an inventive step
  • Be new
  • Trade Marks: protects the owner of any sign capable of being represented graphically which is capable of distinguishing goods or services of one undertaking from those of another.
  • must be registered to gain protection under Trade Marks Act 1994 (unregistered trade marks may be protected by the tort of passing-off)
  • Trade marks may consist of words, designs, numerals or the shape of goods / packaging.
  • A registered trade mark provides its owner with exclusive use of the mark.
  • Enforcement may take place through the civil and criminal jurisdictions.
  • Since 1st October 2007 it is possible to register a mark that is similar or the same as an existing mark (unless there is an objection).
  • How do you apply for one?
  • You can do it online or by post to the Trade Marks Registry.
  • Once you’ve registered, you can put the ® symbol next to the brand.
  • It’s valid for 10 years, but can be renewed every 10 years indefinitely.
  • Registration can also be made to the Community Trade Mark giving protection throughout the EU.
  • Design Rights: protects the visual look / appearance / shapes of products (such as the Coca-Cola bottles)
  • It covers the entire outward appearance of a product, including decoration, lines, contours, colours, shape, texture and materials.
  • A registered design may be 3D or 2D designs (unregistered design must be 3D).
  • It can be registered or unregistered
  • There is an automatic right to an unregistered design right for 15 years
  • This is a shorter period than registered designs and the owner has to demonstrate the transgressor deliberately copied the design (which can be difficult).
  • Designs may be registered at the Patent Office (Designs Registry) under the Registered Designs Act 1949.

  • For a registered design, the design must be:
  • new and have individual character
  • be fixed and original (not commonplace)
  • The registered design allows the owner exclusive rights and use of the product in the UK.
  • Exclusivity in a registered design lasts for 5 years and can be renewed up to a maximum period of 25 years.

  • To claim for infringement of the registered design right, the owner merely has to show the transgressor’s design is similar. He/she does not have to demonstrate intention to infringe the owner’s rights or direct copying of the design.
  • Registration may be made to the Office of Harmonization in the Internal Market to give protection to the design throughout the EU. The protection only lasts for three years.

  • Acquisition of IP rights:

Automatic right on creation

Must be registered

Copyright

Unregistered Design Right

Registered Design Right

Patent

Trade Mark

  • Duration of protection:

Copyright

Patents

Trade Marks

Design Right

70 years from death of author

20 years

10 years renewable indefinitely

Registered Design 25 years

50 years for sound recordings

Unregistered Design 15 years

  • Passing-Off:
  • A common law action exists where a business / individual attempts to pass him/herself or a product off as that of another business. Its aim must be to confuse / mislead the public.
  • Basically, a party releases a product or good (deliberately or unintentionally) to deceive the public into thinking it’s from another business they’re familiar with.
  • This is especially common with cheap booze (as a student, you may know)

  • Confidential Information:
  • Trade or technological secrets
  • Recipes
  • Processes
  • Procedures
  • Politically sensitive information
  • Examples:
  • KFC
  • Seager v. Copydex (1967)
  • Fraser v. Thames Television (1983)

  • Employees and Independent Contractors:
  • Generally, IP created by an employee in the course of employment will belong to the employer (although the employee may possess moral rights).
  • For example, Shigeru Miyamoto created Mario, Zelda and Donkey Kong, but the IP belongs to Nintendo because he’s a part of that company.

  • IP created by an independent contractor / freelance worker is more complicated.
  • The employer should establish an agreement with the contractor as to the ownership and exploitation of the IP.

Qualitative Management and Leadership

  • Multiple Criteria Decision Making / Evaluation: uses other decision criteria such as comfort, durability, sustainability, attractiveness, accessibility etc.
  • Pareto optimal solution is desirable.

  • Evidence-Based Decision Making: making decisions by weighing evidence with a diverse group
  • Arrow and Gibbard-Satterthwaite => there must be a way to break a voting tie

  • Decision Matrix: put choices in a matrix and calculate scores and totals to dictate what decision to make

  • Investment Appraisal
  • Capital Budget Decision / Capital Investment Appraisal: a decision-making process to decide which project to invest in
  • Objective: accept investments where returns outweigh capital

  • Six stages on capital budgeting:
  1. Identification Stage
  2. Search Stage
  3. Information-Acquisition Stage
  4. Selection Stage
  5. Financing Stage
  6. Implementation and Control Stage

  • Time value: value of money now compared to future
  • Future value: amount of investment growth after interest
  • Present value: value today of future cash flow

  • Methods that ignore time value of money:
  • Payback method: pick project with quickest payback period
  • Accounting Rate of Return (ARR): accept project if ARR is >= RRR

  • Methods that incorporate time value of money:
  • Discounted Cash Flows: estimates value of investment based on future cash flows
  • Net Present Value (NPV): calculates monetary gain by discounting cash flows to present point in time

  • Internal Rate of Return (IRR): discount rate that makes the NPV equal to zero

  • Agile Project Management cf Traditional
  • Agile manifesto:
  • Individuals and interactions over processes and tools
  • Working software over comprehensive documentation
  • Customer collaboration over contract negotiation
  • Responding to change over following a plan
  • Software is flexible

  • Waterfall:
  • Requirements → Design → Implementation → Verification → Maintenance

  • Death March project: a project with recurring schedule slips, negative effect on customer relationship, integration problems and testing period is reduced

  • Brooks Law: adding human resources to a late software project makes it later

  • Traditional trade-off: take two, leave one: Quality, Cost, Time
  • Missing: added value for the customer

  • Planning Poker: used to estimate tasks

  • Meetings:
  • Formal meeting at the start of sprint
  • Formal meeting at the end of sprint
  • At regular intervals
  • Daily scrum

  • Agile weaknesses:
  • May be misunderstood
  • Developers need high skill levels
  • Coordination across large projects is complex
  • Customers may not want it

  • Management of Accounting and Finance
  • The fundamental accounting equation: Assets = Liabilities + Equity
  • Double entry bookkeeping: For every debit, there is an opposite and equal credit (and vice versa)

  • Branches of accounting:
  • Financial accounting
  • Management accounting

  • Financial reports:
  • Balance sheet: assets, liabilities, equity at defined moment
  • Profit and loss report: income and expenses

  • International Financial Reporting Standard (IFRS): a standard for financial reports.
  • Helps prevent companies doing tax evasion by transferring profits to other countries.
  • Fundamental and enhancing characteristics:
  • Relevance
  • Faithful representation
  • Comparability
  • Verifiability
  • Timeliness
  • Understandability

  • Key metrics in financial analysis:
  • Market Capitalisation (market cap): share price × number of shares
  • Earnings Per Share (EPS): profit ÷ number of shares
  • Price Earnings (PE) Ratio: profit ÷ market cap
  • Beta: a measure of volatility cf the rest of the market

  • Management Accounting: analysing information to advise business strategy and drive sustainable business success (CIMA)

  • Budgeting:
  • Top-down approach: managers tell lower levels objectives
  • Bottom-up approach: lower levels tell managers achievables
  • Participatory approach: budget is negotiated between levels

  • Avoidable costs: can be eliminated or reduced by picking alternatives
  • Unavoidable (sunk) costs: already incurred and cannot be avoided
  • Cost centre: an identifiable part of an organisation where costs can be assigned / aggregated

  • Reasons to measure cost:
  • Determine selling price
  • Help with production planning
  • Maintain management control
  • Support management decision making
  • Costs can be aggregated by:
  • Element
  • Nature
  • Function
  • Behaviour

  • Cost classification:
  • Fixed: horizontal line
  • Variable: line with non-zero gradient
  • Semi-variable: variable with non-zero y intercept
  • Semi-fixed (stepped cost): staircase

  • Cost accounting and Profit Model:

  •  - profit
  •  - sales price
  •  - quantity sold
  •  - fixed costs
  •  - variable costs per unit sold
  • Can determine minimum cost of product with:

  • Kaplan and Norton’s Balanced Scorecard: scorecards to document how people see your company. Doesn’t include social, environmental or ethical aspects

  • Activity-Based Costing; Procurement
  • Overhead allocation / absorption / conversion: sharing overheads between products / services

  • Types of costs:
  • Direct costs: can be directly mapped to a product or service
  • Indirect costs (overheads): can’t be directly mapped; must be distributed
  • Tracing methods:
  • Cost tracing: map direct costs to products / services
  • Cost allocation: use estimates and models to apply costs

  • Financial statement includes:
  • Closing inventory: the stock a company has at the end of an accounting period
  • Net realisable value: estimated selling price of stock

  • Traditional Cost System (TCS): share overheads proportionally using a cost driver.
  • Traditional Cost System (two-stage allocation rate): share overheads over different cost centres
  • Activity-Based Costing (ABC): use multiple cost drivers and assign overheads via proportions of cost drivers

  • Cost accounting helps us make decisions like:
  • minimum price of a product or service
  • support cost engineering
  • make correct decisions about outsourcing
  • construction of portfolios of products or services
  • Cost engineering: manufacturing efficiency and manages costs

  • Manufacturing Learning Curve: the more something is produced, the cheaper it gets. Efficiency gain is in the range 10% - 25% for each doubling.

  • The Value Chain:
  • Inward Logistics
  • Operations
  • Market and Sales
  • Distribution
  • Follow-up Services

  • Core competency: harmonized combination of resources that distinguish a firm in the marketplace. Ethical values are important for outsourcing.

  • Financial

  1. Un-freeze to overcome inertia
  2. Make change
  3. Re-freeze to restore order

  • Management and Leadership
  • Drunker’s List of Management Functions
  • Set the team’s/organisation’s objectives
  • Provide and organise the resources to achieve the objectives
  • Motivate staff to achieve the objectives
  • Monitor staff performance against the objectives
  • Improve performance by continually developing people

  • Theory X, Y and Z by McGregor and Maslow
  • Category X: driven by money, avoids work, lacks ambition
  • Category Y: driven by job satisfaction, seeks work, shows ambition
  • Category Z: recognise the need for self-fulfilment or transcendence

  • Hawthorne Experiments: no correlation between productivity and working conditions
  • Hawthorne Effect: human subjects are more successful because they know it’s an experiment

  • Management by Walking About: manager goes around, looking, talking to people. It builds trust and understanding.

  • Sources of power:
  • Legitimate
  • Reward
  • Coercive
  • Expert
  • Charismatic

  • Leadership Grid (Blake and Mouton):

Low concern for tasks

High concern for tasks

High concern for staff

Country club management

Team management

Low concern for staff

Impoverished management

Task compliance management

  • Masterful inactivity: do nothing and hope problem solves itself

  • Types of leadership:
  • Transactional: reward the good, punish the bad
  • Transformational: change culture to implement new practices.
  • Ideals
  • Inspiration
  • Individual
  • Intellectual
  • Charismatic: good communication skills reach employees at emotional level
  • Situational: changes leadership style depending on employees
  • Employee properties:
  • Commitment: how motivated you are
  • Competence: how good you are

Low commitment

High commitment

High competence

Coaching (foster a more positive attitude and confidence to succeed)

Delegating (trust staff to complete the task successfully)

Low competence

Directing (clear instructions, regular checks, direct feedback)

Supporting (monitor and advise on better working practices)

  • Motivation and Reward
  • Maslow’s Hierarchy of Needs

  • Management by Objectives / Results: Objectives are set in appraisal meetings by employees and managers, and are aimed for.
  • Performance Appraisal Meetings: reviews performance and sets new objectives per annum.

  • 360 Degree feedback: management asks other people what they think of you

  • Scott Adam’s Company Model: minimise activities that are one level removed from people and products.
  • Out At 5 (OA5) manager:
  • stays out of the way
  • eliminates assholes
  • make sure the employees learn something every day
  • create an environment that supports curiosity and learning
  • teach employees how to be efficient

  • Adam’s Equity Theory:
  • Reward → Inequitable reward: doing more work than they’re rewarded, so they get mad
  • Reward → Equitable reward: getting the right amount of reward for their work, so they work at the same rate
  • Reward → More than equitable reward: getting more reward than what they’re working for, so they’ll either continue at the same rate or feel guilty and work harder

  • Performance related pay lowers morale of less productive workers
  • No performance pay or bonuses →  High job satisfaction
  • Higher education level / company size →  Job satisfaction declines
  • Better pay → Less satisfied with work
  • Link between pay level vs pay satisfaction > Link between pay level vs job satisfaction
  • Higher average income → better well-being, social support, freedom, water quality

  • Team-based rewards:
  • Incentive pay
  • Recognition
  • Profit-sharing
  • Gainsharing

  • Profit Sharing and Employee Share Scheme: employees can buy shares and motivate them, along with bonuses such as:
  • Overtime payments
  • Company cars or subsidised travel
  • Sabbatical leave

  • Production and Quality Management
  • Quality: the level of customer satisfaction of a product or service.
  • What the customer wants and what the company provides.

  • Statistical quality control: quantitative techniques to manage quality
  • You need to define an:
  • acceptable failure rate
  • acceptable failure modes
  • Six Sigma: a set of techniques and tools that strives to reduce the number of defects to 1 in a million. Uses probability distributions
  • Quality management needs to be reliable and precise.
  • Continuous Improvement: A philosophy of continuously improving working practices with the stages: Plan, Do, Check/Study and Act/Adjust.
  • Quality Control: Maintain standards by testing all or a sample of items
  • Quality Assurance: Maintain standards by providing confidence that errors will be prevented by proper processes
  • Total Quality Management: Everyone is responsible for maintaining standards

  • Steps to quality (the Japanese/Toyota way)
  • Real place (gemba)
  • Go and see (genbutsu)
  • Data and facts (genjitsu)
  • Principles (genri)
  • Standards (gensoku)

  • Root cause analysis: For every problem, ask ‘why’ 5 times in order to get 5 possible explanations for a problem.
  • Quality Diagrams and Tables: In order to visualise quality, a table can be generated with the types of failures and number.

  • Lean Thinking in Business Processes: It is important to identify and avoid excess documentation, complex product lines, not utilising talents.

  • ISO standard for quality management (ISO 9001-2015) that is categorised into:
  • Scope
  • Normative references
  • Terms and definitions
  • The context of the organisation
  • Leadership
  • Planning
  • Support
  • Operation
  • Performance evaluation
  • Continual improvement.
  • DMAIC is another quality assurance technique with less documentation than the ISO standard. There are only six stages:
  • Define - What is the problem?
  • Measure - What data is available?
  • Analyse - What are the root causes of the problem?
  • Improve - Do we have the right solutions?
  • Control - What do we recommend?

Scientific & Quantitative Management

  • Company lifecycle
  • Lifecycle of a company:
  1. Birth
  2. Growth
  3. Decline
  4. Death

  • Entrepreneurship: create a new company
  • Intrapreneurship: apply an idea to an existing company

  • Joys and sorrows at birth:
  • Enthusiasm
  • Innovative
  • Small and flexible
  • Intimacy

  • Gibrat’s Law: growth of a firm is random and unpredictable
  • Penrose’s theory: growth is a result of managerial competence and “learning by doing”

  • Marris’ Theory of ‘Managerial’ Capitalism: the optimal point of growth is naturally determined by:
  • managers trying to maximise growth rate
  • shareholders trying to maximise share prices

  • 5 stages of decline:
  1. Hubris Born of Success
  2. Undisciplined Pursuit of More
  3. Denial of Risk and Peril
  4. Grasping for Salvation
  5. Capitulation to Irrelevance or Death

  • Market Analysis and Price Settings
  • 4 stages of market analysis:
  1. Industry overview
  2. Target market
  3. Competition
  4. Pricing and forecast

  • Public sector: part of economy composed of public services and enterprises

  • Gross profit = Revenue - Cost
  • Price elasticity: a measure of a relationship between a change in the quantity and a change in price
  • Psychological pricing: setting prices at £0.99 or $0.88
  • Price represents value.

  • Pricing strategies:
  • Cost-plus pricing
  • Competitive pricing
  • Price skimming
  • Penetration pricing
  • Price bundling

  • US Healthcare pricing strategy:
  1. Determine minimum price
  2. Determine maximum price
  3. Pick 5 prices between min and max price
  4. Survey people with those 5 prices
  5. Look at your survey results
  6. Pick an optimised price

  • Team Lifecycle
  • Locke’s goal setting theory: set goals that are difficult and specific.
  • Follow 5 principles of goal creation:
  • Clarity
  • Challenge
  • Commitment
  • Feedback
  • Task complexity

  • Belbin’s Team Roles:
  • Plant: creative and problem-solving
  • Monitor Evaluator: logical and impartial
  • Specialist: in-depth knowledge
  • Resource Investigator: inquisitive and finds ideas
  • Teamworker: gels team together
  • Co-ordinator: focuses on team objectives
  • Shaper: drives team to work
  • Implementer: plans out strategy
  • Completer Finisher: polishes and scrutinises for errors

  • Tuckman’s model of group development: forming, storming, norming, performing, adjourning / mourning

  • Drexler & Sibbet team performance: four for creating the team and three for sustaining the team:
  1. Orientation: Why am I here?
  2. Trust Building: Who are you?
  3. Goal Clarification: What are we doing?
  4. Commitment: How will we do it?
  5. Implementation: Who does what, when and where?
  6. High Performance: Wow! (We’re doing well)
  7. Renewal: Why continue?

  • Barnum Effect: people think a description is tailored for them, when really it’s general enough to apply to anyone

  • Product Evaluation
  • Conventional product development process: relies on intuition throughout the product development stages

  • Steps to evaluation:
  1. Determine target market via brainstorming
  2. Set out a problem statement and break it down
  3. Create affinity diagrams
  4. Create Co-Creation Model: establishes levels of consumer involvement
  • Submitting: customers send in ideas
  • Tinkering: original idea by company, customers can modify
  • Co-Designing: problem has been defined, customers guide selection
  • Collaboration: company works with customers all the way through
  1. Fill out product design surveys
  2. Create customer requirements, sort into categories:
  • Expecters
  • Spokens
  • Unspokens
  • Exciters
  1. Convert them to testable engineering characteristics
  2. Create quality function deployment: a method of ordering engineering characteristics based on their criticality to customer requirements
  3. Create new product marketing report and product design specifications (PDS)

  • Projects: Introduction and Life-Cycle
  • Project: A temporary endeavour undertaken to produce unique product, service, or result.
  • Project characteristics:
  • Unique
  • Uncertain
  • Temporary
  • Defined Deliverable
  • Constrained
  • Project constraints:
  • Time
  • Budget (resources)
  • Quality

  • Project management (PM): Application of knowledge, skills, tools, and techniques to project activities to meet the project requirements.
  • Process groups:
  • Initiating
  • Planning
  • Executing
  • Monitoring and Controlling
  • Closing

  • Project category categories:
  • Aerospace / Defense Projects
  • Business and Organisation Change Projects
  • Communication systems Projects
  • Event Projects
  • Facilities Projects
  • Information Systems (Software) Projects)
  • International Development Projects
  • Media and Entertainment Projects
  • Product and Service Development Projects
  • Research and Development Projects

  • Experience-based categorisation:
  • Runners: routine batch processing
  • Repeaters: we know how to do it
  • Strangers: significant unfamiliar aspects
  • Aliens: completely new

  • Project Life-cycle:
  1. Concept / Initiation: Birthing the project
  2. Planning: Organising / Preparing
  3. Execution: Carrying out the work
  4. Closure: Ending the project

  • Predictable project: plan-driven, typically Repeaters and Runners
  • Adaptive projects: change-driven, typically Strangers and Aliens

  • Project Management and Controls
  • Project activity network: a diagram that helps manage activities in a project.
  • Early Start: The earliest time at which this activity can start
  • Early Finish: The earliest time at which this activity can end
  • Identifier Number: The “ID” of the activity (doesn’t have to be a number)
  • Activity Float: The most amount of time this activity can be delayed by
  • Activity Descriptor: A description of this activity
  • Activity Duration: How long this activity will go for
  • Late Start: The latest time at which this activity can start
  • Late Finish: The latest time at which this activity can end
  • Critical path: the path that cannot be delayed

  • Forward pass: filling out from initial activities to final activities
  • Early Start for initial activities = 0
  • Early Start = Longest early finish of dependencies
  • Early Finish = Early Start + Duration
  • Backward pass: filling out from final activities to initial activities
  • Late Finish for final activities = Early Finish
  • Late Finish = Shortest Late Start of next activity
  • Late Start = Late Finish - Duration

  • Project crashing: accelerating a project
  • Crashing options:
  • Improving efficiency of use of current resources
  • Improving work methods / equipment
  • Reducing project scope
  • Compromise quality
  • Fast-tracking

  • Cost tracking: comparing estimates with actual costs
  • Includes:
  • Labour costs
  • Material costs
  • Project support costs
  • Schedule tracking: comparing scheduled work with actual work

  • Project Closure
  • Project closure report: made to determine if objectives are met and if business benefits are realised
  • Includes:
  • Detailed list of completion criteria
  • Confirmation that all criteria have been met
  • List of outstanding activities, risks and issues
  • Set of actions needed to hand over deliverables, terminate agreements, release resources and officially request closure.

  • Identifying the required closure activities:
  1. Handover of deliverables
  2. Documentation
  3. Sub-contractor / supplier terminations
  4. Resources release
  5. Communication

  • Post implementation review: reviews project performance against original targets and checks conformance against PM processes

  • Quantitative Risk Management
  • Risk transference: financial loss is transferred to an insurer
  • Risk: effect of uncertainty on objectives
  • Uncertainty: a situation in which something is not known

  • Risk Management (RM): The identification, assessment and prioritisation of risks

  • Approaches to risk:
  • Portfolio: split operating budget by ratio
  • Strategy: split into Real, Win, Worth
  • Systematic: define a Risk Register

  • Issues for managing risk in engineering:
  • You need to mitigate every risk
  • There are always risks you will not anticipate

  • Risk Management methods:
  • Risk identification
  • Risk analysis
  • Response planning

  • Technological Innovation cf Business Innovation
  • Innovation: new and successful ideas
  • Anything can be innovative

  • Difficulties with innovation:
  • Business environment may not support innovation
  • Regulations
  • Technology

  • TRL: measurement system to gauge maturity level of tech. Goes from 1 to 9.
  • Valley of death: where most projects “die”
  • Funding sources vary depending on TRL level

  • Due Diligence, Liquidation, Administration
  • Insolvency: when a firm can’t meet their cash outflows with their inflows
  • Two kinds:
  • Technical: can’t meet cash payments
  • Legal: assets < liabilities
  • What to do with insolvency:
  • Do nothing
  • Seek adjustments with creditors
  • Seek court relief in bankruptcy
  • Assign assets to a third party
  • Liquidate
  • Attempt to sell out

  • Due diligence: research and analysis of a company before buying them out
  • Four cornerstones:
  1. The company
  2. Its operations
  3. Its value and value of assets
  4. Its people

  • Typical headings of due diligence questionnaire:
  1. Company/entity basic information
  2. Ownership of the key assets
  3. Financial and tax-related matters
  4. Significant agreements, contracts, and undertakings
  5. Legal questions common to most transactions
  6. Information about key personnel and employees

  • Due diligence plan: a manual for preparing the due diligence questionnaire
