  • Internalising
  • Voluntary activities
  • Multi-stakeholder orientation
  • Practices and values
  • Transparency
  • Beyond philanthropy
  • Openness in reporting

  • Externalities: consequences of production born by society
  • There exists cultural variations too.

  • Carroll’s Pyramid of CSR:
  • Philanthropic
  • Ethical
  • Legal
  • Economic
  • Baden’s revision:
  • Economic
  • Legal
  • Ethical
  • Corporate Social Performance Model:

  • Stakeholder: any group or individual who can affect or is affected by organisation achievements
  • Types:
  1. Project proponent
  2. Resident engineer
  3. Contractor
  4. Subcontractor and supplier
  5. Independent environmental checker
  6. Environmental team
  7. Maritime engineering consultant
  8. Environmental specialists in marine ecology
  9. Marine Bureau
  10. Civil Aviation Bureau
  11. Environmental Protection Bureau
  12. District Board
  13. Green Groups
  14. Transport trades
  15. Contractors of interfacing projects
  16. Local residents

  • Stakeholder management is a key tool for ethical management.
  • Influence: measure of power
  • Importance: measure of will
  • Primary stakeholders: influence and importance
  • Secondary stakeholders: either influence or importance

Legal Topics

  • Introduction to Law
  • Constitution: collective term for the established laws in a country
  • Types:
  • Codified: harder to make changes
  • Uncodified: can make incremental changes

  • The rule of law: everyone is equal before the law
  • The Separation of Powers: Executive, Legislature and Judiciary are separate
  • No Retrospective Laws: A law must be fully in effect before people can officially break them

  • Sources of law:
  • National Law - Statutory Legislation: the main, overarching laws
  • Case Law - Interpretation of law: Interpreting the law itself
  • International Treaty law: how we interact with other countries
  • EU Law: Laws passed by the European Union
  • ECHR: European Court of Human Rights
  • Conventions / Customs: ‘soft’ law, historic rights

  • Law includes rules that command, regulate, facilitate and guide
  • Criminal Law: regulates actions contrary to established laws
  • Civil Law: used to right a civil wrong. Must be proved on balance of probabilities.

  • Primary legislation (statutes): made by parliament themselves. Cannot be challenged
  • Delegated legislation: delegated by parliament. Can be challenged.
  • Types of delegated legislation:
  • Statutory instruments
  • Orders in council
  • By-laws

  • Statutory interpretation:
  • Literal
  • Golden
  • Mischief
  • Purposive

  • Judicial reasoning terms:
  • Stare Decisis - standing by previous decisions
  • Ratio decidendi - a binding precedent
  • Obiter Dicta - a persuasive precedent

  • ROD: Reverse, Overrule, Distinguish

  • Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR):
  • Arbitration
  • Mediation
  • Conciliation
  • Tribunals

  • Contract Law
  • Contract: a bargain between 2 or more people that is normally legally binding and enforceable by law.
  • Agreements can be written, oral or inferred by conduct.

  • Criteria for a contract to be enforceable:
  1. An offer made by the promisor
  2. Acceptance of the offer by the promisee
  3. Consideration (money or promise)
  4. Mutuality between parties
  5. The capacity of both parties in mind and age
  6. The legality of terms and conditions

  • Freedom to contract: parties can make their own contracts

  • Types of contracts
  • Bilateral contract: Both parties promise to do something (&&)
  • Unilateral contract: After one action, other party promises to perform another action (→)

  • Invitation to treat: An expression of willingness to negotiate.
  • Offer: Asking to enter a contract that has a “yes” or “no” answer.
  • Termination of offer: The transaction is no longer an offer
  • Acceptance: Both parties agree to a contract
  • Battle of the forms: both parties want to make a contract each party wanting to form it on their own terms.

  • People who are unable to enter certain types of contracts:
  • Minors
  • People with mental disabilities
  • Incapacitated and intoxicated people (usually not an excuse)
  • Contracts made with minors are voidable, valid and unenforceable.

  • Consideration: the exchange of one thing of value for another.
  • Past considerations: Consideration before a contract is completed is not adequate for a binding contract

  • Contract variation
  • Agreement to accept less - Part-payment is never valid consideration unless:
  • Part-payment is accompanied by another consideration
  • Payment had been given in another form, time or place
  • Agreement to accept more - An existing duty is good consideration in a contract variation if:
  • the variance is an offer to pay more
  • the offeror gains a practical benefit or obviates a “dis-benefit” by paying more
  • there is a lack of duress

  • Doctrine of Promissory Estoppel: A promise can be legally upheld after a promisee has suffered a loss as a result of relying on that promise.

  • Privity of Contract: Only the parties within a contract may be sued except
  • If the contract is made by agents in collateral contracts
  • The property is transferred in trust to another party
  • A contract has been made under an insurance agreement for the benefit of another
  • Restrictive covenants are imposed on property

  • Contracts (Rights of Third Parties) Act 1999: If someone is not a party to a contract, they can still sue for another person’s rights under the contract as long as
  • The contract explicitly states another person right
  • The purpose of the contract is to benefit another person

  • Terms: A “fact” within a contract. Includes Conditions, Warranties, Innominates (or intermediates)
  • Representation: an exaggeration that isn’t meant to be taken at face value. It can be distinguished by looking at:
  • Terms that are meaningless and cannot be enforced
  • Importance of the statement
  • Special knowledge
  • The statement made in an assuring or promissory way
  • Verification

  • Incorporating express terms:
  • Signature
  • Notice
  • First rule: Terms must be contained in “contractual” documents
  • Second rule: Reasonable notice of the terms must be given at or before the time the contract is made
  • Custom
  • Implied

  • Exclusion (exemption) & Limitation clauses: Clauses that seek to limit or exclude (exempt) a liability that would otherwise exist. It must:
  • clearly express cover of the situation it seeks to exclude
  • not be ambiguous
  • be reasonable
  • not break any other existing statutes

  • Unfair Contracts Terms Act 1977: stops exclusion clauses from exclusind death or personal injury

  • Restraint Clauses:
  • Contracts of employment: Employees cannot reveal employer trade secrets and cannot work for a competing firm when they leave
  • Contracts for the sale of business: A seller cannot set up another business in competition with their buyer
  • Solus Agreements: A seller with a supplier can only get products solely from that supplier

  • Factors that can invalidate contract:
  • Misrepresentation
  • Duress (threats, blackmail, etc)
  • Mistakes
  • Illegality
  • Undue influence (like parents and children)

  • Misrepresentation:
  • a false statement of material fact
  • it is known to the representee
  • it must be intended to be acted upon...
  • ... or it must have been acted upon already
  • Half-truths: when someone says only half of the truth
  • Silence and Non-Disclosure: Silence is not a representation however a gesture could be.
  • Statements of law cannot give rise to a misrepresentation.

  • Contract terminology
  • VOID: no longer has legal effect
  • VOIDABLE: injured party can void contract
  • UNENFORCEABLE: not recognised until the other party carries out their side of the bargain

  • Types of misrepresentations
  • Fraudulent: The statement is false but makes the statement anyway
  • Negligent: The statement is believed to be true but has no proof
  • Innocent: Mistakenly makes a false statement

  • Fraudulent or Negligent → Can make contract voidable

  • Misrepresentation Act 1967: party can sue for misrepresentation (if they suffered a loss from it) until the other party proves it was made innocently

  • Types of mistakes:
  • Common - Both parties make the same mistake
  • Mutual - The two parties are at cross-purposes with each other
  • Unilateral - One party is mistaken and other party knows it
  • Mistakes by identity
  • Mutual mistake as to identity - A mistake on the identity of the subject matter
  • Common mistake as to identity - A mistake on the identity of the other party

  • Duress and Undue influence: If one party is forced or “subject to undue influence” into a contract, it is voidable.
  • Duress: forcing a party into a contract with violence or pressure
  • Undue influence: one party is under the influence of another (e.g. child-parents, client-solicitor, patient-doctor or husband-wife)

  • Illegality - Types of contracts that are immediately void (and illegal)
  • Contracts to commit a crime or tort
  • Contracts damaging to foreign relations
  • Contracts to promote corruption in public life
  • Contracts to defraud the treasury (e.g. tax fraud)

  • Discharge of Contract: bringing a contractual agreement to an end
  • Requirements:
  • Agreement
  • Performance
  • Frustration
  • Breach

  • Remedies for breach (what you can sue for):
  • Damages
  • Compensatory
  • Nominal
  • Restitutionary
  • Punitive
  • Action for the agreed contract price
  • Quantum meruit
  • Specific performance
  • Injunction
  • Repudiation

  • Equitable Remedies: courts do something to ease a dispute if legal remedies or monetary compensation won’t cut it
  • Injunction - Courts direct a party not to breach
  • Rectification - Contract is changed
  • Specific performance - Courts order party to perform obligations

  • Time Limits: an action under a contract must be made within six years
  • No time limit for equitable remedies.

  • Tort Law
  • Tort: a civil wrong resulting from negligence, protection and preservation
  • Claimant: the one bringing the claim
  • Defendant: the one against whom the claim is brought
  • Tortfeasor: the one who committed the tort

  • Four elements of negligence:
  1. A duty of care is owed by tortfeasor
  2. That duty of care is breached
  3. The breach was the cause of the damage
  4. The damage is not too remote from the breach

  • Duty: a responsibility the tortfeasor owers the claimant
  • Duty of care: the level of care the tortfeasor owes the claimant
  • Lord Atkin’s principle: people have a duty of care to others who are foreseeably affected by their actions (also called neighbour)
  • 3-stage test of duty of care:
  1. Foreseeability: harm or loss must be foreseeable
  2. Proximity: must be relationship between parties (neighbours)
  3. ‘fair, just and reasonable’

  • Bolam test: a medical professional is not negligent if their practice was accepted by a responsible body

  • “But for” test: “But for the existence of X, would Y have occurred?”

  • Egg shell skull rule: frailty of a person cannot be used as a defense

  • Defendant defences:
  • Illegality: the other person was doing something illegal
  • Consent: the other person acknowledged risk
  • Contributory negligence: both parties are at fault
  • Necessity: it was necessary to prevent greater harm

  • Remedies:
  • Damages: compensation for personal injury
  • Injunctions: orders from the court to prevent a party from performing a certain action

  • Employment Law
  • The structure of the court system:
  • Supreme court
  • → Court of Appeal
  • → Employment appeal tribunal
  • → employment tribunal

  • Employees and independent contractors:
  • Contracts of service: employees / employee shareholders
  • Contracts for services: independent contractors

  • Tests to determine status:
  • Control test: is a person subject to the orders of the employer?
  • Integration test: is the work done as an integral part of the business?
  • Economic reality test: how far is a person in business on his own account?
  • Mutuality of obligations test: is the employer obligated to provide work and the employee obligated to accept it?
  • Multiple test

  • The multiple test:
  • Does the person have to turn up to work when expected?
  • If YES...
  • Do they have to do what the organisation tells them to?
  • If YES...
  • Are they expected to do it personally?
  • If YES...
  • Can they send someone else to do the work?
  • If NO...
  • Then they are an employee

  • Dismissal from employment:
  • Summary Dismissal: the employee is fired immediately
  • Wrongful Dismissal: the employee was fired: breach of the contract
  • Constructive Dismissal: employer commits breach of contract
  • Unfair Dismissal: The reasons for the dismissal was unfair

  • Potentially fair reasons for dismissal:
  • Capability
  • Conduct
  • Redundancy
  • Statutory bar
  • Some other substantial reason

  • Equality Act 2010: protected characteristics:
  • age
  • disability
  • gender reassignment
  • marriage and civil partnership
  • pregnancy and maternity
  • race
  • religion or belief
  • sex
  • sexual orientation

  • Conduct seen as discriminatory by law:
  • Direct discrimination: discriminated under one characteristic
  • Combined / Dual discrimination: discriminated under multiple characteristics
  • Indirect discrimination: policy applied to everyone, difficult for people of a characteristic
  • Harassment: violating a person's dignity or creating a bad environment for that person
  • Associative discrimination: discriminated because of someone else
  • Victimisation: Treating someone badly because ‘protected act’
  • Perceptive discrimination: discriminated against because people perceive that you have a characteristic

  • Occupational requirement: being of aparticular sex, race, disability, religion or belief, sexual orientation, or age, or not being a trans, married, or a civil partner is an essential requirement for work

  • Acceptable to treat a disabled person more favourable
  • Discrimination airising from disability: treated unfavourably because of disability effect
  • Employers owe employees a general duty of care in respect of their health and safety at work.

  • Industrial Law

  • Sole trader: one person unincorporated business
  • Ordinary (general) partnership: partners share losses and profits
  • Limited Liability Partnership (LLP): the company is separate from the persons involved
  • A limited company (Ltd): legal liability of shareholders is limited to a paid up value of their shares

  • Partnership Act 1890: two entities can partner up for profits as long as the partnership wasn’t formed by another act

  • Company: collection of persons having an existence, right and duties, separate from its persons
  • Incorporated company:
  • A persona at law
  • Has a separate legal entity
  • Has perpetual succession
  • Limited company: A company is limited if the liability of its members is limited by its constitution. Types:
  • Limited by shares: member liability is limited to account
  • Limited by guarantee: member liability is limited to undertaken assets

  • Public company: limited by shares or guarantee and having a share capital, has a certificate that complies with registration of public company. May be listed.
  • Private company: not a public company

  • Intellectual Property (IP): things that are creations of the mind
  • Copyright: an automatic right for creations
  • Patent: exclusive right for an invention idea
  • Trade Mark: protection for a graphically represented brand
  • Design Right: protects visual look / appearance of products

Automatic right on creation

Must be registered

Registered Design Right

  • Passing-Off: business attempts to pass a product off as another business to mislead the public
  • Confidential Information:
  • Trade or technological secrets
  • Recipes
  • Processes
  • Procedures
  • Politically sensitive information
  • Generally, IP created by an employee in the course of employment will belong to the employer (although the employee may possess moral rights)

Past Cases

  • This is a store of all the past cases we need to know, what happened in them, what the end results were and what we can learn from them.

Claimant vs Defendant

What happened

What we learn from it

Carlill vs

Carbolic Smoke Ball Co. 

(1893)

D advertised that they would pay £100 to anyone who caught the flu after using one of their smoke balls.

They deposited £1000 into the bank as evidence of their sincerity.

C bought the smoke ball and caught the flu.

Decision: Advert was an offer to the whole world, and was a unilateral contract of “buy our ball and get flu” → “we give you £100”

An advertisement for a “if you can do this, we’ll give you this” counts as an offer to the whole world

Fisher vs

Bell

(1961)

A flick knife was on display by the shop window, being offered for sale.

Is this an offer or invitation to treat?

Decision: Invitation to treat, because pre-contractual discussions can still happen after the customer walks in.

However, because of the Restrictions of Offensive Weapons Act 1959 it was an offence to offer that flick knife for sale anyway.

A simple advert for a product for sale counts as an invitation to treat

Pharmaceutical Society of GB vs

Boots Cash Chemist

(1953)

D introduces a new check-out system (like the ones in Sainsburys and Asda)

C calls into question the legality of this, since pharmaceutical products need a pharmacist by law.

Decision: The shop assistant (who is a pharmacist) chooses whether to accept or reject the offer anyway, so D is safe.

Goods on a shelf are an invitation to treat.

When the customer takes the goods to the till, that’s an offer to purchase.

Partridge vs

Crittenden

(1965)

D placed an advert in the classified section of a magazine for a rare bird for sale.

S.6 of the Protection of Birds Act 1954 made it an offence to offer those birds for sale.

D was charged and convicted.

Decision: D is not guilty; the advert was an invitation to treat, not an offer

Adverts in magazines are invitations to treat.

Harris vs

Nickerson

(1873)

D advertised some stuff for sale in the London papers about products in an auction.

C went to the auction on the last day, but the products were withdrawn.

C claimed that the advert was an offer.

Decision: The advert was an invitation to treat, not an offer.

Adverts in a newspaper are invitations to treat.

There is no obligation to sustain your consideration if there is no offer.

Conversely, you cannot expect an offeree to make a contract, or still have their consideration, if there is only an invitation to treat.

Lefkowitz vs

Great Minneapolis Surplus Stores

(1957)

D placed an advert for a fur coat on a “first come, first served” basis.

C came to buy it, but D said it was a “house rule” to only sell to women.

C’s argument was that it’s “first come, first served”, and since C was the first, their gender shouldn't matter.

Decision: Because it was “first come first served”, the advert is an offer, so D must uphold his end of the deal and serve C.

An advert with extra details like “first come first served” is an offer and not an invitation to treat.

Harvey vs

Facey

(1893)

Communication on the telegram:

C: "What is lowest price for Bumper Hall Pen"

D: "Lowest price is £900."

C: "We agree to buy"

C feels D has a contractual obligation to sell C the pen

Decision: There is no contract; simply stating the price is not an offer

Stating information about the product is not an offer.

Hyde vs

Wrench

(1840)

D offered to sell farm for £1k

C offered £950 and D refused.

C sought the original offer of £1k, but D still declined.

Decision: No contract. When C offered £950, that new offer destroyed the original offer, so the original offer can no longer be accepted.

Making a new offer after an existing one destroys that first offer, terminating it.

Routledge vs

Grant

(1828)

D offered to buy C’s house and gave him 6 weeks to accept

D withdrew offer before 6 weeks up

Decision: D had the right to do that because it wasn’t a proper offer

An offer can be withdrawn while it is still one-sided.

In contract law, one party cannot be bound whilst the other is not. That doesn’t make a proper offer.

Bloom vs

American Swiss Watch Co

(1915)

D held a reward for information about a jewel thief

C gave the information before they knew of the reward

C was not entitled to the reward.

Decision: C didn’t get the reward

You can’t enter and complete a contract if you didn’t even know it existed

Entores vs

Miles Far Eastern Corp

(1955)

C in London made an offer to D in Amsterdam by telex

D accepted the offer via telex as well.

Did acceptance happen when D sent it or when C saw the message?

Decision: When C saw the message

Over instantaneous forms of communication, acceptance happens as soon as the recipient sees the message.

Adams vs

Lindsell

(1818)

D makes an offer to C on the 2nd but arrives at the 5th.

C posts acceptance on the 5th but doesn’t arrive until the 9th.

D sells goods to another party on the 8th, before C’s acceptance arrives.

Decision: acceptance happens upon posting the letter, not when the letter is received

With mail, acceptance happens upon posting the letter, not when the letter is received

Byrne vs

Van Tienoven

(1880)

1st: D posts letter offering to sell goods

8th: D posts letter withdrawing offer

11th: C telegraphs accepting offer

15th: C confirms acceptance by letter

20th: C receives letter of revocation from D

Was the contract accepted or withdrawn?

Decision: The offer was already accepted on the 11th, so it was not withdrawn.

Revocation can only take effect before acceptance

Chwee Kin Keong vs

Digilandmall.com

(2004)

Six friends placed orders for 1,606 HP printers on a website.

The website had a bug: it was selling them for $66 each instead of $3,854 each

The friends argued that they were not aware of the mistake.

Decision: contract is void. The friends should’ve known it was absurdly low.

If a price mistake on an e-commerce site is absurd, you can’t exploit it.

Simpkins vs

Pays

(1955)

A grandmother, granddaughter and lodger entered a weekly competition.

They agreed that if any of them won, they would share the winnings.

D, the grandma, won money and refused to share.

C, the lodger, sued her.

Decision: There was a binding contract because of mutual agreement, so D should pay.

An informal legally-binding contract can be formed if there is a mutual agreement.

Williams vs

Roffey Bros

(1990)

D were hired to work on flats

There was a penalty clause in the contract if the workers took too long doing the job

C decided to pay D more to avoid penalty clause

C only gave part-payments for each flat.

They claimed D didn’t give good consideration for that pay.

Decision: D’s existing duty was good consideration, so C should pay in full

Existing duty is good consideration in contract variation if:

  • you’re getting paid more
  • the payer gets benefit or avoids some kind of trouble
  • there’s no duress

Photo Production vs

Securicor Transport

(1980)

C contracted D to guard the factory.

There was an exclusion clause that exempted D from damages.

D deliberately set fire to the factory.

Decision: Because of the exclusion clause, D got away with it

Exclusion clauses can exempt negligent damages.

Bisset vs

Wilkinson

(1927)

C purchased farm land to use as a sheep farm.

D estimated it would carry 2,000 sheep.

The estimate turned out to be wrong, so C sued D.

Decision: the statement was only opinion and not fact, so it’s not misrepresentation.

Opinions, such as estimates, cannot be misinformation.

Aprilia World Service vs

Spice Girls Ltd

(2000)

D promised to promote C in return for a sponsorship on a world tour.

Before the contract was signed, Geri Halliwel told everyone she was leaving.

D didn’t tell C.

Geri left 3 weeks after the contract was signed.

C would not have entered the contract if they knew Geri was leaving.

Decision: It is misrepresentation: they should’ve told Geri was leaving.

Not disclosing information that is critical to a contract counts as misinformation.

Hadley vs

Baxendale

(1854)

Crankshaft of mill broke

C got D to go and fix it and bring it back

D brought it back 7 days late

C couldn’t use the mill for those 7 days so C sued for loss of profit

Decision: loss of profit is too remote, D had no idea the mill wouldn’t be running while the crankshaft was gone

If the remoteness of damage is too remote (the other party wouldn’t even know it would be a problem), it does not count as a remedy for breach.

Donoghue vs

Stevenson

(1932)

C’s friend bought her a bottle of ginger beer manufactured by D.

C drank part of it and as she topped up the glass the remains of a decomposed snail came out.

C became ill and sued D.

Decision: C was a customer to D’s product, so a customer like C was foreseeable to D, meaning D had a duty of care to C which was breached. D was liable to C.

If a person is foreseeable, you have a duty of care to them.

Home Office vs

Dorset Yacht Co

(1915)

Boys from C escaped and broke a yacht from D.

Are they liable for damages?

Decision: Yes, because C should’ve foreseen this.

A duty of care is owed if a preventable action is foreseeable.

Bolam vs

Friern Hospital

(1957)

C was not given relaxant drugs by D before treatment.

C suffered fractures and sued D.

Decision: D is innocent because D was just following protocol.

Bolam test:

A medical professional is not guilty of negligence if he has acted in accordance with a practice accepted as proper by a responsible body of medical men skilled in that particular art...

Putting it the other way round, a man is not negligent, if he is acting in accordance with such a practice, merely because there is a body of opinion who would take a contrary view

Bolton vs

Stone

(1951)

D was injured by cricket balls from a club.

The field was surrounded by a 7 foot fence, the pitch was sunk 10 feet and the distance was just under 100 yards from C.

Was duty of care from C to D breached?

Decision: No, because they took all necessary precautions. Chance of harm is very slim; it’s just a coincidence.

If necessary precautions are in place, duty of care is not breached.

Barnett vs

Chelsea & Kensington HMC

(1968)

C went to hospital complaining of vomiting but was sent home by the hospital doctor.

C died (someone had put arsenic in his tea).

Decision: Hospital was not liable for negligence because C would’ve died anyway.

If the breach is not the direct cause of the damage, the negligence claim is void.

Hedley Byrne & Co Ltd vs

Heller & Partners Ltd

(1964)

C asked D about Easipower.

D gave C a report but said it was given “without responsibility”.

C extends credit to Easipower and they go out of business.

Did D owe C a duty of care?

Decision: No, because D gave it “without responsibility”

Duty of care is not owed if a statement exempts the party from it, such as “without responsibility”.

Caparo Industries PLC vs

Dickman

(1990)

C bought shares in Fidelity Plc.

From D’s report, they thought they’d make a profit.

In fact, they made a loss.

C sues D for negligence in certifying the accounts.

Decision: D did not owe C a duty of care because D and C are not neighbours; they are too remote. D didn’t even know C existed.

If there is too much distance between two parties, one cannot expect to be held liable for the other’s misfortunes, even if the cause was them.

Polkey vs

Dayton

(1932)

C was fired by D on the spot without being consulted beforehand.

C claimed unfair dismissal.

D claimed that it wouldn’t have made a difference.

Decision: D’s argument is irrelevant. The dismissal was unfair due to lack of procedure.

Dismissal must be preceded by a consultation (unless it’s gross misconduct).

London Underground vs

Edwards

(1995)

C introduced a rota which was harsher on women than on men.

D is a woman who sued.

Decision: a new rota needed to be made.

Changes in which categories of a particular sex, race, disability etc. are handicapped are not allowed to be passed through.
